notes: On 24 February 2023, Ukrainians and Russians opposing the invasion of Ukraine marked the one year anniversary of Russia's invasion of Ukraine holding an anti-war protest-rally outside the Russian consulate in Limassol before marching to Limassol pier. They were holding banners and placards, and a variant flag of Russia without the red color, and they shouted slogans for the withdrawal of Russian troops.

On 24 February 2023, Ukrainians and Russians opposing the invasion of Ukraine marked the one year anniversary of Russia's invasion of Ukraine holding an anti-war protest-rally outside the Russian embassy in Nicosia before marching. They were holding banners and placards, and a variant flag of Russia without the red color, and they shouted slogans for the withdrawal of Russian troops.

On 22 February 2023, about 150 migrants clashed in the overcrowded Pournara refugee reception center in Kokkinotrimithia. The clashes were over following police intervention. 2 migrants and 1 police officer were injured.

On 22 February 2023, at least 60 Pafos quarry workers blocked traffic with almost 60 trucks around the Presidential Palace in Nicosia demanding the expansion of the Androlikou quarry and the delay of the plans for the Akamas natural park.

On 22 February 2023, about 10 individuals, likely far-right, wearing masks and hoodies entered a lecture hall in the Cyprus University of Technology TEPAK (CUT) Student Development center in Limassol shouting homophobic slurs during a student union event organized by LGBT group ACCEPT and started destroying property. 1 of the rioters set off a fire extinguisher. There were 5 arrests in the following days.

assoc_actor_1: Labor Group (Cyprus); PEO: Pancyprian Federation of Labour; SEK: Cyprus Workers Confederation
notes: On 20 February 2023, employees in the hospitality industry, supported by SEK and PEO, walked of their jobs and rallied in Pafos carrying placards. The protesters demanded the restoration of ATA (CoLA: Cost of Living Allowance) and the re-introduction of collective labor agreements. On 23 February, following a long strike and the Labour ministry acting as an intermediary in negotiations, the protesters' demands were met.

On 5 February 2023, 3 Greek Cypriot farmers riding their vehicle in the buffer zone (coded to Potamia) were shot at with an automatic rifle. One of them was injured in the shoulder and underwent surgery for a non-life threatening wound. The Greek Cypriots reported that Turkish soldiers on a military vehicle shot at them, but the United Nations could not verify the allegations. Police launched an investigation. The Turkish Cypriot administration denied that Turkish soldiers shot at the Greek Cypriots.

Elections/referendum: On 5 February 2023, Greek Cypriots held the first round of Presidential elections (coded to Nicosia). 2 candidates, Nikos Christodoulides, a center-right former foreign minister, and Andreas Mavroyiannis, supported by the communist-rooted party AKEL, reached the second round that would be held the following Sunday. Peace efforts with the Turkish Cypriots, migration, the economy and allegations of corruption in the current government were the main issues. The candidate of ruling party DISY came third and the candidate of far-right ELAM came fourth. Nikos Christodoulides was elected as the new President of Cyprus, inheriting the challenge of reviving stalemated reunification talks with the breakaway Turkish-Cypriots.

Property destruction: On 3 February 2023, early in the morning, unidentified assailants torched, using flammable liquid, a vehicle belonging to the town council of Pyrgos in Limassol district. The vehicle, which was burned to the ground, was parked outside town hall.

assoc_actor_1: KTAMS: Cyprus Turkish Civil Servants Trade Union; Labor Group (Cyprus)
notes: On 1 February 2023, members of KTAMS participated in a one-hour protest-strike outside the European University of Lefke, where they lit fires and held a press release. The motive for the protest was not included in the report.

On 1 February 2023, employees of J&P, a Cypriot company based in Saudi Arabia, rallied outside national broadcaster RIK in Nicosia before the televised debate of the presidential candidates ahead of elections on 5 February, to protest over unpaid wages and social insurance.

On 31 January 2023, Pafos concrete manufacturers and quarrying companies protested that quarries are being phased out. The demonstrators, who were holding placards, blocked off with heavy vehicles a section of the Limassol to Pafos highway for 2 hours. The regional spokesman for concrete manufacturers and the president of the concrete manufacturers' association and the European quarries association held speeches. Police forces were redirecting traffic.

On 31 January 2023, students and parents marched in Famagusta with the slogan 'Do not let other Helins die', following the murder of a teenage girl in Trikomo. The protesters, including the girl's family who made statements against the mishandling of the reporting of the murder, her classmates, members of NGOs and other demonstrators, were carrying placards and banners demanding equality and an end to femicides.

assoc_actor_1: CTP: Republican Turkish Party; Independence Road; Women (Cyprus); Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus)
notes: On 27 January 2023, following the fatal beating of a teenage girl, members of CTP and Independence Road rallied carrying banners outside Iskele (Trikomo) District Court, protesting against patriarchy, as the murder suspect was brought to court. The protesters made a statement to the media demanding justice, saying femicides are political and accusing the government of failing at making institutional arrangements to prevent violence against women. Strong police forces were observing the demonstration.

assoc_actor_1: CTP: Republican Turkish Party; Women (Cyprus); Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus)
notes: On 26 January 2023, Turkish Cypriots from 40 organizations rallied carrying banners in Northern Nicosia, demanding religious classes be optional and the dismissal of the Head of Religious Affairs, Ahmet Unsal, appointed by Turkey, for his anti-feminist stance. The demonstrators also marched to the offices of Kibris newspaper shouting 'We don't want sexist media' after the newspaper described the latest femicide of a teenage girl as a crime of passion. The CTP Women's organization chair made a statement to the media on behalf of the demonstrators.

notes: On 22 January 2023, members of rival soccer teams (although both right-wing and supporting 'enosis' with Greece) APOEL, 200 of which arrived from Nicosia, and APOLLON, clashed with each other over disputes on where they would be placed during the 49th memorial service for EOKA leader Georgios Grivas Digenis in Limassol, and then they attacked police officers at the scene. Six police officers and two members of the public were injured while cars, shop windows, and rubbish bins were damaged. The rioters were armed with stones and firecrackers. There was heavy police presence, including 80 police officers, plus riot police and MMAD, after they had been warned by the EOKA Fighters' Associations about potential unrest, but police was accused of mishandling the fighting. In the following days, police arrested 8 rioters.

On 22 January 2023, family and friends of murdered soldier Thanasis Nicolaou, whose death was initially deemed a suicide, held a protest outside the presidential palace in Nicosia, demanding clarification over how events unfolded and the administration of justice. One of the criminal investigators, candidates for the presidency of the republic and party representatives attended the protest.

On 21 January 2023, following the anniversary of the arrest of Aleksei Navalny on 17 January 2021, about 200 Russians of Limassol, members of the anti-war movement 'No to war! Cyprus' rallied in solidarity with political prisoners in Russia and to protest against Vladimir Putin and the invasion of Ukraine.
On 20 January 2023, residents of 4 communities in the district of Larnaca rallied at Alaminos to protest plans to move a poultry farm from Limassol to the area.

Security measures: On 20 January 2023, the Republic of Cyprus begun to erect a barbed wire fence at Athienou with the intention to eventually extend the existing fence along the entirety of the Green Line, among other security measures, to prevent irregular migrants from entering from the north through the buffer zone.

assoc_actor_1: KTAMS: Cyprus Turkish Civil Servants Trade Union; Labor Group (Cyprus); Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus)
notes: On 18 January 2023, members of KTAMS and Kamu-Is rallied in Northern Nicosia over the working conditions at the Motor Vehicles Unit, protesting that the Transport Minister, Erhan Arikli, did not keep his promises.

assoc_actor_1: Greek Ethnic Group (Cyprus); Police Forces of Cyprus (2013-2023)
notes: On 18 January 2023, around 80 Greek Cypriots and Syrian asylum seekers clashed with each other following a traffic accident in Limassol involving 4 vehicles, after the people involved in the accident called for support from their friends and relatives. 3 Syrians, including a minor, were arrested for pushing police officers, who arrived at the scene.

On 17 January 2023, the government in Northern Cyprus published in the official gazette a decision, that would be followed by signing a protocol with the Turkish government, to grant the right of usage of the Gecitkale (Lefkoniko) airport to the Turkish military forces in Northern Cyprus.

On 14 January 2023, members of the Animal Party rallied outside Limassol Zoo demanding its closure, following a series of scandals related to animal deaths at the facility.

Property destruction: On 11 January 2023, unidentified assailants, likely far-left, smashed the glass front of the ultranationalist Grivas Digenis association in Limassol and caused additional damage to the entrance. They also sprayed slogans calling them 'fascists' and threatening to burn the association down.

On 8 January 2023, members of the Kurdish Cypriot Cultural Centre 'Theofilos Georgiadis' marched in Nicosia, following the killing of 3 Kurds in Paris on 23 December 2022, blaming the French government for not protecting Kurds, so that French-Turkish relations would not be disturbed. The demonstrators also blamed NATO and the European Union for their politics of appeasement regarding Turkey and protested that Turkey had been bombing Kurdish targets even before Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

notes: On 4 January 2023, members of the Association of Love and Brotherhood (Sevkad) rallied outside mosques in Nicosia holding banners reading 'Life, Faith, Jihad' and called for Sharia.

Property destruction: On 2 January 2023, unidentified perpetrators, likely far-right, uprooted from its location and destroyed the new street name sign bearing the name of Dimitris Christofias (a late President of Cyprus and General Secretary of AKEL, who was supporting talks with the Turkish Cypriots and the reunification of the island). The street had just been renamed from Geri Avenue to Dimitris Christofias Avenue. This was a replacement to a previous sign that had been defaced 24hrs after the renaming ceremony.

Other: On 1 January 2023, following a decision by the Council of Ministers in Northern Cyprus (coded to Nicosia) the Turkish satellite Turksat stopped broadcasting the channel of the opposition SIM. Turkish Cypriot media reported this as an act of censorship.

On 27 December 2022, a municipality employee in Kato Dikomo / Dikmen fired shots against the mayor after the latter gave a warning to employees, telling them they should follow the rules, which he had accused them of going against. The mayor was taken to hospital for an injury to his ankle and other employees intervened to put a stop to the fight, leading to another employee getting injured. The attacker was arrested.

Elections/referendum: On 25 December 2022, Turkish Cypriots voted in local government elections in Northern Cyprus (coded to Nicosia) for the first time after reforms, that had sparked protests, reduced the number of municipalities from 28 to 18. Participation in the elections increased from 64,1% to 68,85% with a win for the opposition parties. CTP was the party with the most elected mayors. A woman was also elected mayor for the first time. The application for the mukhtar/mayor candidacy of another woman, a Greek Cypriot Maronite, was not approved on security grounds. The Foreign Affairs ministry in Northern Cyprus denied that she was rejected because she is a Maronite. On 28 December, new mayors received their mandate without incident.
On 24 December 2022, students and about 70 parents rallied outside the office of the Education Ministry in Pafos to protest against the twice-yearly exams.
On 22 December 2022, members of the Pafos Sailing Club rallied at the municipal swimming pool of Pafos to protest that they were not allowed access to the pool.

On 21 December 2022, Armenian protesters organized by the Armenian National Committee of Cyprus rallied outside the embassies of the United States and Russia in Nicosia to protest against the blockage of the Lachin corridor. The leader of the Solidarity Movement was present.

On 21 December 2022, Turkish-Cypriot school janitors, organized by Kamu-Is, marched to the Presidency in Northern Nicosia for their rights and they demanded a collective labor agreement. They also protested for the second day that janitors in public schools were dismissed because they were union members.

On 21 December 2022, during the hearing against a Ukrainian woman facing charges of carrying a weapon to cause terror over an incident on 22 August, Russians protested outside Larnaca court demanding protection. The protesters rallied under strong police presence carrying Russian flags and shouting slogans.

On 20 December 2022, Turkish-Cypriot school janitors, organized by Kamu-Is, rallied outside the ministry of Labour and Social Security in Northern Nicosia for their rights and they demanded a collective labor agreement. They also protested that janitors in public schools were dismissed because they were union members.

assoc_actor_1: APC: Animal Party Cyprus; Cyprus Green Party
notes: On 18 December 2022, protesters organized by The Animal Party, the Movement of Ecologists and the citizens' group The Garden is Ours, rallied in Limassol following the latest death of an animal and demanded that Limassol Zoo close down.

On 17 December 2022, Turkish Cypriot motorcyclists organized by the Motorcycle Committee rallied outside the prime minister's office in Northern Nicosia over the failure of the Finance Ministry to implement a promised tax cut.

actor1: Police Forces of Cyprus (2013-2023) Port and Marine Police
notes: Other: On 17 December 2022, Port and Marine police intercepted a small speedboat carrying 18 migrants (10 men, 3 women, 5 children) who were sailing off the Coast of Cape Greco and transported them safely to Ayia Napa. One of the men was arrested for steering the boat and the rest were transferred to the Pournara migrant reception center.

PEO union joined the demonstration and stepped in to represent the migrants, also assisting them by offering food and help to keep up their fight and by filing a complaint with the labor ministry.

On 15 December 2022, Turkish-Cypriot school janitors, organized by Kamu-Is, rallied outside the Ministry of Education in Northern Nicosia protesting against the subcontractor system and demanding fair treatment. The protesters lit a fire and boiled stones in a pot. The leader of Kamu-Is held a speech.

Before marching they rallied outside Wolt's corporate offices. PEO union joined the demonstration to express solidarity.

Before marching they rallied outside Wolt's corporate offices. Members and officials of PEO joined the demonstration expressing their solidarity.

On 15 December 2022, Turkish-Cypriot trainee teachers at the Ataturk Teachers Academy (AOA) marched to parliament in Northern Nicosia protesting that a pending draft bill would endanger the future of the Academy. The demonstrators held speeches and accused the government of ignoring them and intentionally attempting to shut down an 85-year old institution, the only institution training teachers.

assoc_actor_1: KTOEOS: Cyprus Turkish Secondary School Teachers Union; Teachers (Cyprus); KTAMS: Cyprus Turkish Civil Servants Trade Union; Labor Group (Cyprus); Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus)

The leaders of KTOEOS and KTAMS made statements.

On 14 December 2022, about 150 Wolt food delivery drivers, all migrants from low-income nations, marched in Nicosia on the second day of their strike over pay cuts, demanding fair rights amid increasing prices in food, petrol and utility bills. Before marching they rallied outside Wolt's corporate offices. During the demonstration, a police officer started screaming at the protesters telling them they have no right to march, although they repeatedly told him that they had already secured permission by the police.

Security measures: On 14 December 2022, construction work started to build a fence to create a second perimeter around the Pournara migrant reception center in Kokkinotrimithia for police to patrol and prevent migrants from leaving the camp. The decision to construct an additional fence was made following extensive rioting in October.

On 13 December 2022, about 20 underage youths in Ypsonas in Limassol district rioted to celebrate on the date 1312, standing for ACAB (All Cops Are Bastards). The youths were carrying sticks and clubs and set trash dumpsters on fire. They hurled rocks at the firefighters and a petrol bomb at 2 police cars, who were called at the scene. The petrol bomb exploded on the roof of one of the police cars. The incident ended in a car chase during which police fired 3 warning shots. The driver escaped but police were informed of an injured minor receiving treatment at the hospital for a graze on his face. He was wearing an ACAB uniform, admitted he was the driver of the car being chased earlier and claimed his injury was caused by a bullet, blaming the police. A medical examiner and the ballistic report refuted the claims. A judge denied an arrest warrant request for the minor by Limassol police.

On 12 December 2022, employees hired for work participated in a 2-hour strike-protest outside the Kouklia municipality building protesting that they perform additional duties above their pay grade without compensation. Municipality staff joined their protest in solidarity.

On 10 December 2022, on Human Rights Day, and also the exhumation date 2 years before of the body of Thanasis Nicolaou (a conscript whose death 17 years ago, initially deemed a suicide, was this year linked to murder), his mother Andriana and her supporters, who arrived from all over Cyprus demanding justice, rallied outside the attorney-general's office in Nicosia to protest over delays in bringing the murderers, along with anyone that covered up the incident, before justice. The demonstrators carried banners and shouted slogans.
On 8 December 2022, unidentified assailants used a fragmentation grenade to cause an explosion damaging the door and the lobby of the Pyrgos community council building in Limassol district.

On 8 December 2022, during the night, 3 APOEL FC supporters attacked an African man on his way to work at a bakery in Pafos. One of the men hit him with a club and sprayed him with toxic fumes. Police was investigating this as a racist crime.

assoc_actor_1: ELAM: National Peoples Front; Government of Cyprus (2013-2023)
notes: On 8 December 2022, about 300 demonstrators rallied outside the House of Representatives in Nicosia during a voting to end funding to activities commemorating controversial historic leader Georgios Grivas, who had fought the campaign for the independence of Cyprus against British rule, but later he fought for union with Greece. The demonstrators chanted abusive remarks against members of Parliament and hurled a rock in the parliament building. Police closed off the road outside the House and set up barricades. Members of ELAM and an ELAM MP were present. About 20 rioters vandalized the offices of socialist party EDEK smashing the glass window and tossing a flare inside causing a fire. The bill was defeated.

On 6 December 2022, representatives of local governments of communities in Famagusta district in the Republic of Cyprus rallied outside parliament in Nicosia to protest for the bill regarding local government reforms, which had already passed, to take effect.

On 3 December 2022, shop owners on Makarios Avenue in Nicosia blocked the road carrying placards to protest for an accessible and sustainable shopping area after changes in the traffic system affected their businesses.

On 2 December 2022, the radiology team of Pafos general hospital staged an impromptu two-hour protest-strike citing heavy workload and staff shortages.

On 1 December 2022, lawyers rallied outside the district court of Limassol during a scheduled 2-hour strike to protest against new rules issued by the Supreme Court that would open the way for 'express trials'. On 1 December 2022, about 100 members of SYKALA, the association of depositors with now-defunct Laiki Bank whose savings got wiped out in the 2013 bail-in, rallied outside a TV station in Nicosia shouting slogans during the 2nd televised debate of the 3 presidential candidates. On 1 December 2022, lawyers rallied outside the Supreme Court in Nicosia during a scheduled 2-hour strike to protest against new rules issued by the Supreme Court that would open the way for 'express trials'. This was part of a protest by the Cyprus Bar Association in all districts of the Republic of Cyprus.

On 1 December 2022, lawyers rallied outside the district court of Pafos during a scheduled 2-hour strike to protest against new rules issued by the Supreme Court that would open the way for 'express trials'. This was part of a protest by the Cyprus Bar Association in all districts of the Republic of Cyprus.

On 1 December 2022, lawyers rallied outside the district court of Famagusta in Paralimni during a scheduled 2-hour strike to protest against new rules issued by the Supreme Court that would open the way for 'express trials'. This was part of a protest by the Cyprus Bar Association in all districts of the Republic of Cyprus.

On 29 November 2022, parents of secondary school children protested in Larnaca against overcrowded classrooms, demanding the improvement of teaching conditions, and expressed their opposition to quarterly exams.

On 24 November 2022, teachers organized by their unions rallied outside the presidential palace in Nicosia to protest over a contentious education bill. They came to a compromise with the government during the demonstration.

Police searched his home and confiscated his mobile phone, a USB and 2 books they considered to be propaganda material. BKP and leftist political parties raised concerns over press freedom in Northern Cyprus. On 23 November, he was released on bail.

On 22 November 2022, Kurds living in Cyprus held a demonstration in Nicosia calling for an immediate halt to Turkish airstrikes in Rojava, in northern Syria and Iraq, after Ankara blamed Kurdish militants for the blast on Istanbul's Istiklal Avenue. The Kurdish Movement in Cyprus met the EU Commission in Cyprus Representative and then the House Speaker. They then marched to the embassies of the United States and Russia.

actor1: Police Forces of Cyprus (2013-2023) Port and Marine Police

They had set sail from Syria. One of the minors was arrested for steering the vessel and the rest were transferred to the Pournara migrant reception center.

On 20 November 2022, Kurds of Limassol held a demonstration calling for an immediate halt to Turkish airstrikes in Rojava, in northern Syria and Iraq, after Ankara blamed Kurdish militants for the blast on Istanbul's Istiklal Avenue. The protesters, including the Cyprus-Kurdish Solidarity Association, marched from the Kurdistan Cultural Centre Theofilos towards the Limassol district administration located in Governor's Square carrying placards against Turkey.

On 20 November 2022, on World Children's Day, children rallied in a central Pafos square carrying placards to protest for their rights, and particularly the right to live in a just and peaceful world.

On 20 November 2022, female non-commissioned officers in the National Guard protested with relatives and friends outside the presidential palace in Nicosia over what they called unacceptable proposals submitted by the Ministry of Defence to meet their demands for more equal treatment.

On 19 November 2022, Turkish Cypriots married to Turkish nationals and their children marched from Ledra Palace to the Interior Ministry of the internationally recognized Republic of Cyprus in Nicosia with the slogan 'Mixed marriages are not a crime' and carrying banners in Greek, Turkish and English, to protest that their children are denied citizenship. They accused the government of the Republic of Cyprus of using arbitrary methods with no legal basis to delay their applications, denying the right to apply to children born from one Turkish parent, while children, whose one parent is from another country, are allowed to apply so long as one parent is Cypriot.

On 19 November 2022, residents and their community mayor of the village of Ayios Amvrosios blocked traffic access at the Kantou-Omodos road for one hour holding banners and shouting slogans, demanding a winter fuel allowance. Residents and community leaders of neighbouring villages, who were already receiving the subsidy, joined the protest.

actor1: Police Forces of Cyprus (2013-2023) Port and Marine Police

They had set sail from Syria. One of the men was arrested for steering the vessel and the rest were transferred to the Pournara migrant reception center.

On 18 November 2022, dozens of students at a technical school in Nicosia rallied outside the school on the sidewalk of a busy avenue, holding placards with slogans about the principal bullying students and calling for him to resign. They protested that he handed out suspensions for no reason. Police observed the rally as a precaution.

On 17 November 2022, on the anniversary of the 1973 Athens Polytechnic student uprising against the military dictatorship in Greece, hundreds of students organized by PSEM marched to the United States embassy in Nicosia carrying Greek and Cypriot flags to protest against wars and fascism and against Washington's support for the dictatorship at the time. The 1967-1974 junta in Greece and EOKA B had organized the coup intending to unite Cyprus with Greece, triggering Turkey's invasion of Northern Cyprus and occupation of the north to this day. They were holding banners reading 'imperialism is the enemy' and 'NATO CIA Betrayal'.

assoc_actor_1: AKEL: Progressive Party of Working People; Greek Ethnic Group (Cyprus)
notes: On 17 November 2022, on the anniversary of the 1973 Athens Polytechnic student uprising against the military dictatorship in Greece, 4 Greek Cypriot youths wearing T-shirts reading 'Omonia Fanatics' (Omonia is the Football Club affiliated with AKEL) burned Greek flags and unfurled the flag of the Republic of Cyprus in Empa (likely blaming Greece for the 1974 coup and the subsequent invasion of Northern Cyprus by Turkey).

On 17 November 2022, on the anniversary of the 1973 Athens Polytechnic student uprising against the military dictatorship in Greece, Cypriot resistance fighters for democracy, and against the coup aiming to unite Cyprus with Greece in 1974, rallied outside parliament in Nicosia against the government's decision to fund the building of a museum about George Grivas, the leader of EOKA B. They protested that this would be an insult to the dead of the resistance and of the subsequent Turkish invasion.

On 15 November 2022, early in the morning, a Nigerian refugee, whose asylum seeking documents were at an advanced stage and was about to leave the overcrowded Pournara migrant reception center in Kokkinotrimithia, reported that she was attacked and raped by 5 Nigerian asylum seekers inside the camp. She reported the incident on the 16th.

On 15 November 2022, students marched in Limassol condemning the north's unilateral declaration of independence (UDI) in 1983, 9 years after the Turkish invasion, and protesting for a bizonal and bicommunal solution to the Cyprus problem. This was part of demonstrations across all major cities in the Republic of Cyprus by thousands of students organized by PSEM and POFEN. At the same time, the north was celebrating the anniversary with the annual military parade and other celebrations. The UDI was condemned by UN Security Council resolutions 541 (1983) and 550 (1984), which called it legally invalid and called for its immediate withdrawal. The TRNC is recognized as a state only by Turkey.

On 15 November 2022, students marched in Pafos condemning the north's unilateral declaration of independence (UDI) in 1983, 9 years after the Turkish invasion, and protesting for a bizonal and bicommunal solution to the Cyprus problem. This was part of demonstrations across all major cities in the Republic of Cyprus by thousands of students organized by PSEM and POFEN. At the same time, the north was celebrating the anniversary with the annual military parade and other celebrations. The UDI was condemned by UN Security Council resolutions 541 (1983) and 550 (1984), which called it legally invalid and called for its immediate withdrawal. The TRNC is recognized as a state only by Turkey.

On 15 November 2022, students marched in Larnaca condemning the north's unilateral declaration of independence (UDI) in 1983, 9 years after the Turkish invasion, and protesting for a bizonal and bicommunal solution to the Cyprus problem. This was part of demonstrations across all major cities in the Republic of Cyprus by thousands of students organized by PSEM and POFEN. Displaced Greek Cypriots organized by the union of Turkish-occupied municipalities also held an event. At the same time, the north was celebrating the anniversary with the annual military parade and other celebrations. The UDI was condemned by UN Security Council resolutions 541 (1983) and 550 (1984), which called it legally invalid and called for its immediate withdrawal. The TRNC is recognized as a state only by Turkey.

This was part of demonstrations across all major cities in the Republic of Cyprus by thousands of students organized by PSEM and POFEN. The Youth Councils of the Turkish-occupied municipalities of Kyrenia, Lapithos and Karavas along with municipal authorities organised an anti-occupation rally, with the displaced mayors wanting to pass on their sentiments for their homeland to the next generation. DISY and AKEL MPs for Kyrenia and the Bishop for Tamasos and Orini were present. At the same time, the north was celebrating the anniversary with the annual military parade and other celebrations. The UDI was condemned by UN Security Council resolutions 541 (1983) and 550 (1984), which called it legally invalid and called for its immediate withdrawal. The TRNC is recognized as a state only by Turkey.

On 13 November 2022, Turkish Cypriots, including opposition political parties, labour unions and NGOs, rallied at the Ayios Dhometios checkpoint against the construction of an Islamic government complex, known as the Kulliye project, in Northern Nicosia and funded by Turkey. They shouted slogans against fascism and the Turkish invasion of Northern Cyprus and called for the democratic forces to work together. The leader of Sol Hareket held a speech.

Movement of forces: On 11 November 2022, following a series of incidents of harassment of Greek Cypriot farmers working in their fields in the buffer zone, the Foreign Minister of the Republic of Cyprus said that the government had information that, aside from new sentry posts the Turkish army was setting up along the Green Line, there were also Turkish commando forces lying in wait to intervene along the UN buffer zone (coded to Nicosia). The incident took place at a time when the Turkish Cypriot leadership was promoting a solution to the Cyprus problem based on splitting Cyprus in two separate states and was putting pressure to UNFICYP to sign an agreement with the TRNC in order to continue their peacekeeping mission.

On 11 November 2022, the teenage daughter of former professional footballer Mohamed Kamara and fellow students and members of youth volleyball teams, of which she was a member, rallied at the Vergina School of Larnaca to protest against a deportation notice for Kamara and his family, whose 3 children were born and were attending school in Cyprus. The Ministry of Interior intervened and Kamara was given a special permit to remain in the country.

assoc_actor_1: PEO: Pancyprian Federation of Labour; SEK: Cyprus Workers Confederation; Labor Group (Cyprus)
notes: On 10 November 2022, on the third day of a dockers strike, Larnaca port workers supported by PEO and SEK, rallied demanding the Larnaca port management company stick to an interim agreement they signed with the ministry in October regarding a 50-50 share of port operations between the dock workers and the port's operators. The demonstrators suspended their strike following a meeting with ministry officials.

assoc_actor_1: YKP: New Cyprus Party; Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus)
notes: On 9 November 2022, Turkish Cypriots rallied against the 'Kulliye project', the construction of an Islamic government complex in Northern Nicosia, fully funded by Turkey, protesting that it was disrespectful and a waste in the middle of one of the worst financial crises they were facing. The leader of YKP made a statement that this was 'a political project'.

On 8 November 2022, residents of 4 Limassol communities, Moni, Monagroulli, Pyrgos and Asgata, including students and their parents, rallied outside the Agioi Anargyroi primary school in Monagroulli carrying banners to protest for clean environment and the removal of 2 asphalt plants from their area. Community leaders held speeches. Limassol lawmakers were present. The demonstrators marched on a main road and blocked traffic briefly.

On 7 November 2022, tens of residents of Limassol and environmental activists rallied carrying placards and banners to protest over the lack of transparency in the redevelopment of the Limassol municipal Garden.

Other: On 6 November 2022, 2 men in civilian clothes came from the Turkish Cypriot side and hurled rocks at a Greek Cypriot farmer in his tractor, who was cultivating his fields in the Ovgou area near Gerolakkos (Alaykoy) having all the necessary licenses to work in the UN buffer zone. The men shouted insults and threatened him to leave. When he demanded an explanation one of the attackers drew a knife. The Greek Cypriot farmer notified authorities. UNFICYP announced that it would be stepping up its patrols in the buffer zone. One of the 2 attackers returned escorted by a Turkish soldier claiming it was all a misunderstanding.

assoc_actor_2: Civilians (Cyprus); Police Forces of Cyprus (2013-2023); Refugees/IDPs (International)
notes: On 5 November 2022, groups of young people in the Pournara migrant reception center in Kokkinotrimithia clashed with each other, using crowbars, stones and wood. Police reinforcements from Nicosia were brought to restore order. There were 8 arrests, all minors. A small number of employees at the reception center and 10 migrants were injured and received first aid in hospital.

On 3 November 2022, about 50 employees and the Lady's Mile beach restaurant owners protested holding placards outside the British bases police station in Kolossi after they were ordered to close down their businesses for winter. The demonstrators accused the British officers of ordering them in a manner reminiscent of colonial times and called on the bases to reconsider and have a discussion.

actor1: Police Forces of Cyprus (2013-2023) Port and Marine Police

Movement of forces: On 1 November 2022, Turkish soldiers mobilized in the buffer zone and harassed a Greek Cypriot farmer working in his fields in Astromeritis. The soldiers withdrew with the arrival of a UNFICYP patrol vehicle. This follows another similar incident on 25 October and accusations of unauthorized Turkish military activity. The community leader of Astromeritis expressed concern noting that outposts of the UN peacekeeping force had long been removed from the area. The incident took place at a time when the Turkish Cypriot leadership was promoting a solution to the Cyprus problem based on splitting Cyprus in two separate states and was putting pressure to UNFICYP to sign an agreement with the TRNC in order to continue their peacekeeping mission.

Pafos police arrested the British soldier and started an investigation.

On 28 October 2022, about 60 migrants from the Pournara reception center rallied peacefully outside the Kokkinotrimithia police station - many of them carrying their belongings - protesting that they are scared to return to the camp following clashes between migrants from Nigeria and the Democratic Republic of Congo.

notes: On 28 October 2022, migrants from Nigeria and from the Democratic Republic of Congo clashed in the overcrowded Pournara reception center in Kokkinotrimithia. The rioters armed themselves with sticks and metal rods, set fires to 24 tents and hurled rocks. 20 people were injured. Many people sought refuge in nearby villages. Police used batons and tear gas. Pournara holds 2,150 migrants, but was built for 800 and has a maximum capacity of 1,000. According to EU statistics, in relation to the size of its population, Cyprus receives the most asylum applications in the EU and has repeatedly asked other EU member states to take in migrants. Police issued arrest warrants for 75 migrants, one of which was arrested. The Interior Minister stated that the 75 people responsible for the clashes would be deported.

The protesters held speeches and made a statement calling for the Education minister to resign.

On 27 October 2022, a citizens' initiative from all over Cyprus rallied holding placards outside Pafos city hall to protest the decision of the city council to offer the Golden Key to the city to President Nicos Anastasiades.

Police was investigating premeditated murder. On 9 November, the total number of suspects arrested was 11 including 3 prison guards. A Kurdish inmate was considered to be the main suspect. On 13 November, a 12th person was arrested.

On 27 October 2022, 6 Syrians, 3 men and 3 women, who went to the migration office in Pafos to submit a written application regarding their stay in Cyprus rioted after they were asked to make an appointment. They started smashing the offices and then attacked the police officers who intervened. The latter had to go to the hospital for first aid.

They were holding placards reading 'housing, health, work, driving licenses for all', 'No to racial discrimination'. They shouted slogans outside Parliament and submitted their demands in writing. The march was observed by police forces.

On 25 October 2022, 2 riders on a dark-colored motorcycle approached the company vehicle of a traffic camera operator, while he was inside the vehicle on the Larnaca - Agia Napa highway, and shot at him twice with a shotgun before speeding away. The rear of the vehicle was damaged.

Similar incidents in the past involved only 5-6 soldiers. Greek Cypriots accused the Turkish military of expanding in the buffer zone and setting up a new sentry post near Deneia in addition to other unauthorized construction activity inside the buffer zone at the Cetinkaya stadium near Ledra Palace. The incident took place at a time when the Turkish Cypriot leadership was promoting a solution to the Cyprus problem based on splitting Cyprus in two separate states and was putting pressure to UNFICYP to sign an agreement with the TRNC in order to continue their peacekeeping mission.

On 24 October 2022, Turkish Cypriot school janitors supported by their union continued their tent protest outside parliament in Northern Nicosia during an indefinite strike-protest demanding their unpaid wages for 50 days and to sign a collective bargaining agreement.

Other: On 24 October 2022, the Turkish Cypriot leadership voted for an amnesty to all irregular migrants, also giving a monetary allowance for 90 days to foreign nationals residing illegally in the north of Cyprus (coded to Nicosia). This voting affects about 5,000 people. A similar amnesty was given to 4,167 people between 4 November 2021 and 31 January 2022. The majority of irregular migrants enter the Republic of Cyprus and therefore the EU from the north of the island.

On 20 October 2022, Turkish Cypriot school janitors supported by their union set-up tents outside parliament in Northern Nicosia during an indefinite strike-protest demanding their unpaid wages for 50 days and to sign a collective bargaining agreement.

On 20 October 2022, athletes, parents and members of the Pafos sailing club, rallied outside the city council for a second time holding placards to protest against the closure of the municipal swimming pool.

On 19 October 2022, Turkish Cypriot school janitors supported by their union rallied outside the Ministry of Education in Northern Nicosia during an indefinite strike-protest demanding their unpaid wages for 50 days and to sign a collective bargaining agreement.

Around 18 October 2022 (week of), residents of Liopetri protested at the construction site of a sewerage pumping station demanding its relocation 500 meters further away from their homes and they physically prevented scheduled drilling works from beginning.

On 18 October 2022, parents of children with kidney problems rallied outside the Health Ministry in Nicosia demanding the reinstatement of the doctors who had been treating their children. The doctors were suspended over a case of alleged negligence.

assoc_actor_1: KTOEOS: Cyprus Turkish Secondary School Teachers Union; Teachers (Cyprus); Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus)

On 10 October 2022, members of cancer association Europa Donna, participating in the 18th Europa Donna march in Nicosia, protested for the right to live without discrimination and for the right to have their medical history forgotten, so that they have 'the same and equal access to insurance policies like our other fellow human beings'.

On 9 October 2022, Greek Cypriot refugees demanding the reunification of the island participated in an anti-occupation march in Astromeritis at the end of the 42nd Morphou Memory Days events. Before the march, during the memorial service for the fallen and prayers for finding the missing that was also attended by ambassadors and foreign dignitaries, President Anastasiades blamed the EU and the United Nations for the Turkish arrogance claiming that 'as long as the international community tolerates or accepts the Turkish behavior, it is like rewarding the perpetrator who wants to pose as the victim'.

On 9 October 2022, female non-commissioned officers and their families rallied outside the presidential palace in Nicosia and submitted a letter to the director of the president's office to protest against gender-based discrimination in the national guard.

On 8 October 2022, cancer patients, who were residents of Latsia, protested outside the Astrasol shoe-sole factory following a court ruling that found no causal link between the company's operation and the cancer cases detected nearby. The demonstrators called on the guilty parties to be punished holding a placard with the Green Party's logo reading 'we demand justice'.

On 8 October 2022, supporters of Andriana, the mother of Thanasis Nicolaou, a conscript whose death 17 years ago was this year linked to murder, arrived from all regions of the Republic of Cyprus and rallied outside the legal service in Nicosia demanding the return of an investigator into the case, who had revealed details of the investigation and alluded to a cover-up saying original evidence was ignored after the national guardsman was found dead. It was then deemed to be a suicide. Placards demanding justice and denouncing bureaucracy and corruption were placed on the fence of the legal service public offices. Andriana Nicolaou held a speech.

On 8 October 2022, Limassol residents protested, demanding that citizens be consulted about any changes made to the Limassol municipal Garden, against redevelopment work that started following a large donation to Limassol municipality by a private Belarusian company.

On 6 October 2022, members of the Pensioners of Cyprus Union (EKYSY) marched in Nicosia accusing the government of being indifferent to their plight and demanding a radical reform of the state pension system.
On 6 October 2022, members of the Pensioners of Cyprus Union (EKYSY) marched in Larnaca demanding the government find solutions to various problems affecting the quality of life of the elderly.
On 6 October 2022, members of the Pensioners of Cyprus Union (EKYSY) marched in Pafos protesting over low pensions and the high cost of living.

On 2 October 2022, Turkish Cypriot demonstrators continued to protest in Northern Nicosia against the construction of an Islamic government complex, the Kulliye project, fully financed by Turkey. Spending this amount of money for an Islamic complex to include a 'presidential palace' for the Turkish Cypriot leader, a 'parliament building' for the Turkish Cypriot assembly, a mosque and a recreational park, costing around 2.5 billion Turkish lira (140 million euros), in the middle of one of the worst financial crises facing Turkish Cypriots was seen as disrespectful and a waste.

Following public pressure, 4 members of the board of directors of KIB-TEK resigned and the Prime Minister handed over the contract documents.

On 7 July 2022, residents of the Kokkinotrimithia area rallied outside parliament in Nicosia shouting slogans to protest over the overcrowded Pournara migrant reception center and the perceived indifference of their MPs. They protested against crime and drug use among migrants loitering outside the center, but also expressed fears over their health following an outbreak of transmissible diseases in the camp.

On 7 July 2022, unionists affiliated with Hur-Is rallied outside the Prime Minister's office in Northern Nicosia laying a black wreath and shouting slogans against the subcontractor system, which they described as 'slavery'. The protesters accused the PM of failing to address this issue and of not keeping promises regarding a minimum wage.

assoc_actor_1: CTP: Republican Turkish Party; Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus)
notes: On 6 July 2022, members of CTP rallied outside the Prime Minister's office in Northern Nicosia accusing the government, which they consider to be illegitimate, of corruption amid problems in the fuel supply and continuous power cuts. The protesters accused KIB-TEK, the Turkish Cypriot Electricity Authority, of purchasing fuel without tender and demanded to see the contracts. Before the rally, CTP had applied to the Constitutional Court for the annulment of the decision.

On 6 July 2022, potato farmers lined up their tractors and held banners to protest over the high cost of fertilizer and fuel ahead of a presidential visit in Xylofagou. The President met with the farmers and promised support.

assoc_actor_1: KTAMS: Cyprus Turkish Civil Servants Trade Union; Labor Group (Cyprus); Government of Northern Cyprus (2020-); Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus)

Around 3 July 2022, residents of Akaki rallied against the government's policy of putting barbed wire barriers, stretching many kilometers along the Green Line, and metal gates in their communities to prevent the arrival of irregular migrants into the Republic of Cyprus. The government was erecting an 11km razor wire barrier along the buffer zone from Astromeritis to the old Nicoosia airport.

On 30 June 2022, about 50 asylum seekers from the Republic of Congo held an anti-racism protest in Nicosia over their living conditions in the Pournara migrant reception center and delays in the examination of their applications. They marched to the civil registry and migration department holding 'Black Lives Matter' signs demanding equality and the right to employment. Strong police forces observed the demonstration.

On 30 June 2022, members of the Theofilos Kurdistan cultural center marched to parliament in Nicosia to protest after the Kurdish Workers' Party PKK was referred to as a 'terrorist' organization during the NATO summit in Madrid. The protesters asked the international forces to demand Turkey implement international law and stops the massacre of the Kurdish people. They were received by the Director General of the House of Representatives on behalf of the house president.

On 29 June 2022, on the 8th day that Turkish Cypriot unionists rallied outside the Prime Minister's office in Northern Nicosia to protest against hiring contractors rather than employees for cleaning in government offices, ministries and especially state schools, the head of Kamu-Is held a speech. On 25 June 2022, environmental groups and members of the Cyprus Green Party marched to Pafos town hall against development plans for the national park of Akamas, the last pristine coastal area in the Republic of Cyprus. On 24 June 2022, teachers at the English School in Nicosia organized by the English School Staff Union (ESSA) rallied for a second time to protest the management of the school.

On 20 June 2022, residents of 9 communities in the Vassilikos area (coded to Mari), holding signs, blocked entry to the facility and to the industrial facilities from Kalavassos to Pentakomo to protest the environmental degradation of the area, following a fire at a processing center in Vassilikos in an open area filled with old tires. The demonstrators protested against the proposed amendments for restricting fundamental rights and freedoms of Turkish Cypriots and aiming at preventing individuals and institutions, including social media, from expressing their free thought.

On 5 June 2022, on World Environment Day, members of the Cyprus Greens rallied outside the Russian embassy in Nicosia to protest against the construction of a nuclear power plant in Akkuyu, Turkey, by a Russian company.

Around 4 June 2022, Turkey designated the Turkish Cypriots' unrecognized, main airport in Tymbou as a domestic flight route (coded to Nicosia). Many liberal Turkish Cypriots and the government of the Republic of Cyprus protested in writing to the United Nations that this move would effectively turn it into a Turkish airport and expressed concerns that - in combination with the recently signed economic protocol with Turkey - this was a signal of Turkish President Erdogan's intention to annex breakaway northern Cyprus.

On 3 June 2022, members of 2 NGOs, the Cyprus Natural Coastline initiative and Save Akamas/Save Cyprus, picketed the environment service in Nicosia to protest against proposed planning zones in the natural habitat of Akamas in their efforts to protect local species endangered from tourist development.

On 3 June 2022, on the platinum jubilee of Queen Elizabeth II, motorcyclists from all major cities of the Republic of Cyprus, all members of the 'Initiative in Memory of Isaak-Solomou', rallied at the ancient theater of Kourion to commemorate the 9 EOKA fighters against British colonialism, who were hanged with the approval of Queen Elizabeth in the late 1950s, to protest against the jubilee celebrations in the British Base Area, and to express their solidarity with the people of British colonies.

On 2 June 2022, a group called Russians in Cyprus Against war (RAW) organized a demonstration in Limassol demanding that hundreds of political prisoners and prisoners of conscience in Russia be released and said that because Russia had withdrawn from the Council of Europe, its citizens had lost access to the European Court of Human Rights.
On 1 June 2022, Turkish Cypriot students carrying banners protested in the Middle East Technical University Northern Cyprus Campus in Kapouti over price hikes and the cost of living.
On 1 June 2022, public transport bus drivers in Pafos walked out of the job and protested over unpaid salaries.

On 30 May 2022, members of women's movement POGO rallied carrying banners during a trial outside the courthouse in Larnaca to express their solidarity with a woman who accused the former Bishop of Kition of indecent assault and to protest over his acquittal in a similar case in the past.

On 29 May 2022, about 300 members of 3 different hunters' movements rallied outside the Presidential Palace in Nicosia to protest against poaching and other issues in the natural habitat of Akamas, as well as over the cost of living and low wages and pensions.
On 28 May 2022, the Ukrainian community of Cyprus rallied against Russia's invasion of Ukraine carrying placards and banners outside the European Union House in Nicosia.

assoc_actor_1: Women (Cyprus); Labor Group (Cyprus); Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus)
notes: On 23 May 2022, female employees of Girne (Kyrenia) municipality rallied to protest over the death of a female municipal employee in a citrus factory, who was killed in a work-related accident, and they demanded increased health and safety measures.

On 23 May 2022, a group of 5 people attacked a young man who entered a church in the village of Ayios Amvrosios with the intention to steal. The attackers beat him and hit him in the front and back of the head, causing bruises in his eyes and injuries in various parts of his body. One of the attackers was using a piece of wood and another hit him with the back end of his gun. The assailants also immobilized the young man and tied a belt in his neck as they continued to beat him. His parents reported that the police officers who arrested him instead of taking him to the hospital immediately, first took his statement as he was fainting.

notes: On 21 May 2022, a UN patrol vehicle of the Peacekeeping Force in Cyprus (UNFICYP) encountered a vehicle in the buffer zone and when they approached it for an inspection the driver fled towards Geri/Yeri in the Republic of Cyprus. During the car chase that followed, the perpetrators shot at the peacekeepers with a hunting rifle. The UN vehicle was damaged. There were no injuries. The Republic of Cyprus opened an investigation.

The Defense minister, religious leaders, a city councilor and the mayor of Pafos, and a former Greek military officer participated in the event and held speeches.

Activists and CTP supporters rallied outside parliament. They were joined by members of TDP, TKP, YKP and BKP political parties, who also rallied outside the Turkish embassy. CTP laid a black wreath on the Presidential door before voting 'No'. The protesters also shouted slogans against President Tatar and in favor of a United Federal Cyprus. A young Turkish Cypriot woman, who was a YKP supporter, was carrying a placard reading 'Invader Turkey, get out of Cyprus'; the following day the new PM announced that there would be a police investigation regarding the placard, which the government claimed fueled hatred.

The farmers blocked roads outside the Presidential Palace, later cutting access to key traffic arteries on their way to the agriculture ministry, poured tons of milk outside the Presidential Palace in Nicosia and set fire to bales of hay. Police observed the demonstration, but did not intervene. The following day, police identified at least 3 people from footage of the demonstration and arrested 1 for reckless behavior and conspiracy to commit a crime.

The ambassador of Ukraine in Cyprus participated in the protest.

notes: On 20 April 2022, members of the Initiative Group of Residents of Empa protested that more than 1,500 refugees were transferred from Chloraka to Empa, which they say is a large number for a community of 3,000 people. The protesters briefly disrupted traffic in the main road holding placards reading 'respect and quality of life'. Community leaders of Chloraka and Empa and local MPs of DIKO and DISY held speeches.

On 19 April 2022, municipality employees (staff), organized by Dev-Is, participated in a job walk-out during a 1-hour strike-protest outside Buyukkonuk (Komi Kebir) municipality in Northern Cyprus. The protesters made a statement demanding the central government's attention over financial and economic problems of the past 3 years that have reached unsustainable levels.

Other: On 19 April 2022, the recently elected government, which had received a vote of confidence on 3 March, resigned [coded to Nicosia], following disagreements between the Prime Minister and the Finance Minister amid a financial crisis in Northern Cyprus, the renewal of the financial protocol with Turkey, and ongoing strikes over energy price hikes and long-term management problems regarding the Cyprus Turkish Electricity Corporation. Turkish Cypriot president Ersin Tatar (backed by Turkey) accepted the government's resignation with some delay. On 23 April, the same UBP-DP-YDP coalition government was formed and the Finance Minister was replaced, but the re-established government only lasted until 29 April as they failed to agree on a 100-day action plan. On 12 May, a new UBP-DP-YDP coalition government was formed amidst accusations of following undemocratic procedures after president Tatar assigned the task to MP Unal Ustel. As infighting within UBP, the majority party, continued, the finance minister Olgun Amcaoglu resigned on 13 May, but the following day returned to his duties. On 18 May, the government received a vote of confidence in parliament with 29 affirmative and 20 negative votes (1 MP was absent) and under strong objections by the opposition parties. The following day the leader of HP submitted his resignation from parliament invoking 'Sine-i-millet' to protest that the government has lost it legitimacy. The withdrawal of HP from parliament was approved on 6 June.
On 17 April 2022, migrants of different nationalities clashed in the overcrowded Pournara refugee reception center in Kokkinotrimithia. There were no injuries.

On 17 April 2022, prominent Cypriots and Russian-speaking Cypriot activists rallied outside the Russian embassy in Nicosia in support of Russia and against the Russian sanctions in Cyprus. They also protested against NATO's support for Ukraine and providing Ukraine with weapons.

On 17 April 2022, residents of Episkopi rallied to protest against plans for the administrative merging of their municipality with Limassol. The community leader of Episkopi and leaders of other communities held speeches.

On 15 April 2022, residents of Empa in Pafos clashed with migrants in the village cafe causing damages. Damages were also caused at vehicles parked outside. Strong police forces were called at the scene. The incident started with an altercation over a parking space between a Syrian migrant and a Cypriot, which was followed by an attack at Cypriots by Syrians wielding clubs and carrying knives and local residents of Empa responding. Cypriot youths started looking for migrants to get revenge on. There is tension in the area following the transfer of a large number of Arab and African refugees from a nearby community. Police was patrolling overnight to prevent clashes. In the following days, the Syrian and the Cypriot, who started the incident were identified and arrested.

On 14 April 2022, the Government of Northern Cyprus (coded to Nicosia) signed a new economic cooperation protocol with Turkey for the provision of financial support to the economically dependent Northern Cyprus. The financial agreement of about 240 million euros worth of grants and loans caused strong reactions when it was published in the official gazette for further restricting the freedoms of Turkish Cypriots. Under the protocol, there were reforms and 'laws' concerning the economy, but also provisions not related to finances, such as changes to the right to assemble and demonstrate, and the monitoring of all communication platforms to tackle misinformation, including a provision about media that provided for fines up to five years in jail for insulting Turkish Cypriot leader Ersin Tatar or Turkey.

On 6 March 2022, the king and queen of the Limassol carnival and other members of the carnival procession marched against the war in Ukraine holding placards and wearing their costumes, although the regular carnival parade had been cancelled due to coronavirus-related restrictions.
On 5 March 2022, a large crowd of Ukrainians, Cypriots and Russians rallied in Larnaca demanding the war in Ukraine ends and they shouted slogans against Putin.

On 5 March 2022, Ukrainians, Cypriots and Russians rallied in Nicosia demanding the war in Ukraine ends and they shouted slogans against Putin.
On 5 March 2022, Ukrainians, Cypriots and Russians rallied in Pafos demanding the war in Ukraine ends and they shouted slogans against Putin.
On 2 March 2022, residents of Kiti rallied at the roundabout junction of Kiti holding placards and banners to protest against the administrative merging of their municipality with Dromolaxia.

notes: On 26 February 2022, AKEL organized demonstrations in Nicosia, Larnaca, Limassol, Pafos to protest a steep rise in the cost of living and demanded the government takes appropriate measures.

On 26 February 2022, residents of 9 communities in the Vasiliko area rallied holding banners and placards and severely disrupted traffic in all four lanes of the Nicosia - Limassol motorway at Zygi to protest against the relocation of three asphalt plants to their area.

On 26 February 2022, dozens of Ukrainians rallied holding Ukrainian flags outside the Presidential Palace in Nicosia to protest for EU sanctions, including blocking Russia from the Swift global payments system. Some held signs reading 'Stop Russia before it's too late!' and others suggested a correlation between the war in Ukraine with the 1974 Turkish invasion of Cyprus. They addressed a letter to President Nicos Anastasiades, which was received by the director of the president's press office.

On 26 February 2022, residents of 9 communities in the Vasiliko area rallied holding banners and placards and shouted slogans against the relocation of three asphalt plants to their area. The protesters blocked traffic for 20 minutes on the Nicosia - Limassol motorway at Kalavasos and for another 20 minutes at the Kalavasos roundabout junction. The municipality leader of Kalavasos, who is also the president of the coordinating committee of the 9 communities made statements.

On 25 February 2022, about 100 Ukrainians living in Cyprus rallied at the Old Port of Limassol holding flags and banners and shouting slogans to protest against Vladimir Putin's invasion of Ukraine. The protesters asked the Cypriot government to exclude Russia from the SWIFT international banking system and compared the situation faced by Ukraine to the 1974 invasion of Cyprus.

On 25 February 2022, Ukrainians living in Pafos rallied at the promenade to protest against Vladimir Putin's invasion of Ukraine holding placards reading 'Cyprus remember 74', 'stop swift for Russia' and 'stop Putin'.

On 24 February 2022, 100-200 Ukrainians, holding flags and banners and shouting slogans, rallied outside the Russian consulate in Limassol to protest against Vladimir Putin's invasion of Ukraine. The protesters also sang the national anthem of Ukraine and folk Ukrainian songs. They then marched to the United States embassy. Honking cars flying the Ukraine flag passed by, with some drivers displaying the victory sign with their fingers. Police kept a discreet watch over the protest.

On 24 February 2022, about 200 Ukrainians, holding flags and banners and shouting slogans, rallied outside the Russian embassy in Nicosia to protest against Vladimir Putin's invasion of Ukraine. The protesters also sang the national anthem of Ukraine. They then marched to the United States embassy.

On 21 February 2022, women activists and the parents of women military non-commanding officers rallied outside the Presidential Palace in Nicosia to protest over the discrimination of women officers with regard to their promotion compared to their male colleagues and demanded that women officers be promoted and that they receive the additional income retroactively.

On 20 February 2022, residents of Kokkinotrimithia protested over the living conditions of migrants at the Pournara reception center and demanded health and safety. The protesters briefly blocked the motorway.

On 20 February 2022, demonstrators organized by the Pancyprian Peace Council rallied at the entrance of Akrotiri base to protest over the arrival of 4 Eurofighter Typhoon fighter jets and opposed the involvement of the British Bases in the crisis in Ukraine.

On 19 February 2022, protesters against the construction of a roundabout junction that would affect a green area and a playground rallied in Limassol with the support of the Cyprus Green Party and the President of Limassol Schools.

On 17 February 2022, lawyers of Nicosia, Kyrenia, Limassol, Larnaca and Famagusta supported by their associations rallied outside the Supreme Court in Nicosia to protest over their working conditions.

On 16 February 2022, protesters rallied outside Larnaca hospital demanding justice and a full investigation following the death of a young woman and a malpractice report to the police by her husband. The protesters left carnations at the hospital entrance, while there was strong police presence.

On 16 February 2022, residents and members of the local government protested in the Limassol suburb of Agios Athanasios against the closure of the last remaining bank branch in their community. The Mayor held a speech.
On 15 February 2022, a picket was held outside the Russian embassy in Nicosia in support of Alexei Navalny, against terror and war.

On 13 February 2022, a group of teenagers and their family members attacked a migrant working as a food delivery driver in the area of Palouriotissa in Nicosia. There were five injuries in total and the worker was transferred to hospital. The father of one of the teenagers was arrested, charged and released. This was the second such incident on the same day.
On 12 February 2022, unidentified assailants targeted migrants, who were working as food delivery drivers in Nicosia, in a racially motivated attack.

On 12 February 2022, scores of protesters staged a 'freedom convoy' against coronavirus restrictions and health mandates following the example of Canada. The convoy set off from Pafos with protesters from other districts joining along the pre-designated route and ended in Nicosia, where traffic was disrupted. The convoy was escorted by police cars and was monitored aerially by a police helicopter. The protesters held Cyprus flags and honked their horns.

Community leaders and MPs of AKEL, DIKO and ELAM also participated in the protest. There was strong police presence.

On 9 February 2022, Congolese and Nigerian youths clashed during a basketball game in the overcrowded Pournara reception center in Kokkinotrimithia in hand-to-hand clashes and hurling rocks at each other. There were 48 injuries. Police arrived to restore order. Ambulances transferred the injured to hospital.

On 8 February 2022, Congolese and Nigerian youths clashed in the overcrowded Pournara reception center in Kokkinotrimithia hurling stones and other objects at each other. The fight erupted following the theft of money, mobile phones and other objects by the Nigerians. There were 35 injuries, 3 of which needed hospitalization. A minor injured another person in the eye with a knife and threatened a police officer. No member of staff was injured.

On 8 February 2022, students at the Greek School of the American Academy in Limassol followed the example of students at the Experimental School of Thessaloniki and rallied in their school yard forming a message with their school bags to protest against violence and the murder of a teenage soccer fan in Thessaloniki on 1 February.
On 7 February 2022, doctors, lawyers and educators of the network Alarm Call protested in Nicosia over the 'state's inefficiency in handling the coronavirus pandemic'.

assoc_actor_1: PASYNO: Pancyprian Nurses Union Federation; Health Workers (Cyprus)
notes: On 4 February 2022, health workers supported by their unions PASYNO and PASYDY participated in a spontaneous protest at the General Hospital of Nicosia over understaffing and the hospital's intensive care unit being full over capacity.
On 3 February 2022, hospital cleaning staff in Girne (Kyrenia) participated in a protest-strike over unpaid salaries. A delegation of Independence Road members joined the protest.

On 3 February 2022, about 100 protesters opposing the government's coronavirus measures rallied outside a conference center in Nicosia that was hosting parliamentary sessions and demanded a referendum.

assoc_actor_1: PEO: Pancyprian Federation of Labour; Labor Group (Cyprus)
notes: On 2 February 2022, hotel employees, unemployed due to the coronavirus pandemic particularly during the winter season, rallied outside the Labour Ministry in Nicosia demanding unemployment benefits. The protesters were supported by PEO.

On 31 January 2022, around 40 activists rallied outside the Supreme Court in Nicosia to express their solidarity with a British woman who was accused of falsely claiming she was gang-raped by up to 12 Israeli tourists in a Cyprus holiday resort in 2019. The protesters were holding banners reading 'I believe her' and 'end rape culture', and clapped when they heard the court's ruling that overturned her conviction by a lower court.

On 30 January 2022, Ukrainian permanent residents of Limassol rallied shouting slogans and holding banners - one of them reading 'Putin, hands off Ukraine' - to protest against any Russian military intervention in their country.

On 28 January 2022, residents of Agioi Konstantinos kai Eleni in Dali rallied outside the Presidential Palace in Nicosia against pollution caused by the asphalt plants near their community and bureaucratic delays in their re-location. The demonstration took place during a cabinet meeting on this issue.

On 23 January 2022, Pakistani students in Northern Cyprus rallied for hours at the scene of a traffic accident in Cengizkoy (Peristeronas), where a friend of theirs had just lost his life, and protested over the bad condition of the road and the late arrival of the funeral vehicle. The protesters attempted to block the road twice, but were not allowed, and after the body of their friend was driven away from the scene, they marched to Gemikonagi (Karavostasi) in protest.

Elections/referendum: On 23 January 2022, Turkish Cypriots voted in parliamentary elections [coded to Nicosia] amid a record low voter turnout of just under 58% due to a boycott by voters of leftist parties, who wanted to register their disenchantment with the Ankara-aligned policies of Northern Cyprus, as well as a faltering economy. Hardline National Unity Party (UBP) took nearly 40% of the vote. Ersin Tatar, the leader of UBP, who is backed by the Turkish government, considered the party's victory as an endorsement for a two-state settlement with the Greek Cypriots - instead of the internationally backed federation-based deal to end the island's 48-year division. On 26 January, UBP, DP and HP reached a preliminary agreement to form a coalition government, which did not materialize. On 19 February, UBP, DP and YDP reached an agreement and, on 3 March, the new government received a vote of confidence in the Assembly.

On 20 January 2022, anti-vaccine demonstrators, including children, rallied outside parliament in Nicosia during a session of the House Health Committee to protest against coronavirus measures and health regulations.

assoc_actor_1: Farmers (Cyprus); PEO: Pancyprian Federation of Labour; Labor Group (Cyprus)
notes: On 19 January 2022, land workers at Fasouri farm rallied outside the Presidential Palace in Nicosia during a strike-protest against the decision of the Labour Ministry to give work permits to foreign nationals allowing them to work at the farm in jobs carried out by Cypriots. The protesters were supported by SEGDAMELIN-PEO.
On 18 January 2022, about 70 foreign refugees clashed hurling rocks and other objects at each other in the Menogeia reception center in Larnaca district. Six people were injured.

A delegation of KISA and protesters delivered a memorandum to the director of the Water Development Department and the district engineer of Pafos.
On 16 January 2022, 40 British nationals, residents of Pafos, protested against coronavirus measures and submitted a memorandum to the police headquarters in Pafos.

On 14 January 2022, sea sport professionals, organized by the Association of Sea Sport - Recreation Means, rallied outside Paralimni Municipality against its tender procedure for offering services on beaches, and protested against the mayor, who they claimed was breaking the law. The protesters demanded the intervention of the Interior Ministry.

On 13 January 2022, owners of driving schools gathered in front of the Driving License Inspectorate in Northern Nicosia and drove to the Ministry of Public Works and Transport, demanding the transition to the online system for driving license exam appointments.

The Presidents of KTOEOS and EL-SEN held speeches.
On 10 January 2022, a bomb exploded in the car of an activist member of CABS, the Committee Against Bird Slaughter, in Pyla. The vehicle was damaged, but there were no injuries.

On 9 January 2022, dozens of people gathered outside the Archbishopric in Nicosia to protest against the ultimatum given by the Archbishop to unvaccinated priests to receive the shot against the coronavirus by 15 January or be punished.

On 3 January 2022, members of the Turkish Cypriot Workers' Union participated in a 2-hour protest-strike in Northern Nicosia in support of cooperatives and the right to collective bargaining. Union officials rallied outside the Prime Minister's office holding a banner and held a speech.

On 31 December 2021, residents of Agioi Konstantinos kai Eleni in Dali demonstrated against pollution caused by the nearby asphalt plants and bureaucratic delays in finding a solution despite government promises. The mayor of Dali joined the protesters in a motorcade to the asphalt plants.

On 23 December 2021, foreign nationals protested [likely over delayed payment of benefits] at the welfare office of Lakatamia, a suburb of Nicosia, prompting the intervention of Team Z police officers.

On 21 December 2021, hundreds of students organized by their union PSEM marched to the Presidential Palace in Nicosia to protest against exams citing heavy workload. They were holding banners and shouting slogans. Their representatives submitted a petition to the President. Strong police forces observed the demonstration. Teachers and parents also participated in the demonstration.

On 18 December 2021, a group of citizens - not affiliated to any group - rallied with their children in the Northern Nicosia suburb of Hamitkoy to protest over the failing economy in Northern Cyprus, following the depreciation of the Turkish Lira.

On 18 December 2021, parents of students interrupted the inauguration ceremony of the new Philharmonic building of Pafos by the Minister of Education to protest against the coronavirus measures at schools. Police observed the protest, but did not intervene.
On 18 December 2021, about 200-300 members of the movement Os Dame (Enough!) marched in Nicosia against 'authoritarianism' and corruption.
On 17 December 2021, residents and the deputy mayor of Geroskipou protested against the administrative merging of their municipality with Pafos.
On 14 December 2021, unidentified assailants hurled a petrol bomb at the police station in Aradippou and then fled. No injuries were reported.

On 14 December 2021, several African asylum seekers entitled to benefits rallied outside a social welfare office in Pafos to demonstrate over delayed payments and some of them caused a fracas. They entered the building and pushed 3 female social workers. They also assaulted police officers who arrived at the scene. 1 police officer sustained a fractured arm. 1 man and 2 women were arrested. The welfare office employees participated in a spontaneous work stoppage.

On 13 December 2021, Lapta (Lapithos) municipality employees in Northern Cyprus affiliated with BES, the council workers' union, started an indefinite strike to protest over unpaid wages for 4 months. The head of the union made a speech.

On 11 December 2021, dozens of residents of Kokkinotrimithia and other villages near the Pournara migrant reception center protested holding signs reading 'safety and health' demanding the government limit the number of migrants in the overcrowded center and improve their living conditions. They also demanded the laws that apply to locals should be applied to migrants, calling for a crack down on prostitution and drug trafficking. The protesters briefly disrupted traffic, while being observed by police.

On 11 December 2021, demonstrators against the government's coronavirus measures, particularly the mandatory use of facemasks by school children, rallied at the Rizoelia Junction in Aradippou, Larnaca district, physically blocking traffic, while drivers waited for hours to drive through.

assoc_actor_1: KTAMS: Cyprus Turkish Civil Servants Trade Union; Labor Group (Cyprus); Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus)

The protesters, who marched on the motorway chanting slogans and using whistles, reached the parliament building, where they tied ribbons and banners at the entrance.

On 10 December 2021, Forestry Department employees staged a 3-hour work stoppage to protest understaffing. The protesters rallied outside the finance ministry in Nicosia before marching to the Presidential Palace to hand in a resolution to the presidency.

assoc_actor_1: KTOEOS: Cyprus Turkish Secondary School Teachers Union; Teachers (Cyprus); Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus)
notes: On 9 December 2021, the 2 teachers' unions KTOS and KTOEOS rallied outside parliament in Northern Nicosia holding banners to protest over the depreciation of the Turkish Lira against foreign currency.

On 7 December 2021, state school biology teachers supported by their union OELMEK staged a Pancyprian 2-hour work stoppage to demand the introduction of laboratory teaching in biology classes. They rallied and unfurled banners outside Acropolis school in Nicosia.

On 7 December 2021, state school biology teachers supported by their union OELMEK staged a Pancyprian 2-hour work stoppage to demand the introduction of laboratory teaching in biology classes. They rallied and unfurled banners outside Drousia school in Larnaca.
