On 7 December 2021, state school biology teachers supported by their union OELMEK staged a Pancyprian 2-hour work stoppage to demand the introduction of laboratory teaching in biology classes. They rallied and unfurled banners outside Paralimni high school in Famagusta.

On 6 December 2021, students organized by teachers' union POED and the Confederation of Parents participated in a 15-minute Pancyprian protest outside their schools in Limassol singing songs and shouting slogans against recent incidents of violence in schools over the latest coronavirus measures. The leadership of POED and of the Confederation of Parents joined the protest at the Limassol school, which was the site of a bomb explosion.

On 6 December 2021, students organized by teachers' union POED and the Confederation of Parents participated in a 15-minute Pancyprian protest outside their schools in Larnaca singing songs and shouting slogans against recent incidents of violence in schools over the latest coronavirus measures.

On 6 December 2021, students organized by teachers' union POED and the Confederation of Parents participated in a 15-minute Pancyprian protest outside their schools in Nicosia singing songs and shouting slogans against recent incidents of violence in schools over the latest coronavirus measures.

On 6 December 2021, students organized by teachers' union POED and the Confederation of Parents participated in a 15-minute Pancyprian protest outside their schools in Pafos singing songs and shouting slogans against recent incidents of violence in schools over the latest coronavirus measures.

On 6 December 2021, students organized by teachers' union POED and the Confederation of Parents participated in a 15-minute Pancyprian action outside their schools in Famagusta singing songs and shouting slogans against recent incidents of violence in schools over the latest coronavirus measures.

On 4 December 2021, hundreds of demonstrators - mostly parents - rallied in Limassol to protest against the government's coronavirus measures and particularly a mask mandate and SafePass requirement for children as young as six. The protesters were holding placards and banners. There was heavy police presence observing the rally and monitoring traffic.

On 4 December 2021, members of Turkish Cypriot non-governmental organizations under the leadership of the Famagusta Women's Center Association rallied at the city's landfill to protest against the burning of garbage that was causing air pollution.

On 4 December 2021, hundreds of citizens in Polis Chrysochous, including members of civil society organizations, local government and Pafos lawmakers, rallied to protest the understaffing of the local police station and hospital following the death of a man earlier in the week.

On 3 December 2021, on the International Day of Persons with Disabilities, Turkish Cypriot persons with disabilities, organized by their association KTOOD and the Equal Rights and Justice Union (HAKSEN) marched to parliament in Northern Nicosia to highlight their problems regarding employment, health services and public infrastructure.

On 3 December 2021, Orthodox Christians holding Greek flags and banners reading 'PAPA EST PERSONA NON GRATA' and shouting slogans such as 'Cyprus is Orthodox' rallied in Nicosia to protest the visit of Pope Francis in Cyprus. The protesters were observed by strong police forces.

On 2 December 2021, early in the morning, a makeshift metal cylindrical device placed at the entrance of a primary school in the Zakaki quarter of Limassol exploded causing extensive damages in a classroom, shattering window panes at the school and at an adjacent church. A second larger explosive device found at the school's main entrance failed to go off. The bomb attack is suspected to be the work of people opposing the government's new coronavirus measures making mask-wearing at school compulsory.

On 2 December 2021, members of the Independent Driving Schools Association rallied in front of the Nicosia Driving License Inspectorate in Northern Nicosia demanding the manual appointment system used for driving school exams is replaced with an online system.

Property destruction: On 2 December 2021, early in the morning, unidentified parents opposing the government's new coronavirus measures making rapid tests and mask-wearing at school compulsory, torched a classroom and a multi-purpose room in the primary school of Deutera in Nicosia. The arsonists used red spray to write 'Hands off our children, traitors' on the entrance staircase.

On 2 December 2021, parents demonstrating against the government's new coronavirus measures making mask-wearing at school compulsory marched in central Pafos holding placards reading 'Hands off our children'. The demonstration severely disrupted traffic.

On 1 December 2021, during the night, around 300 underage Arab and African refugees clashed in the Pournara migrant reception center in Kokkinotrimithia. The rioters hurled rocks at each other. 7 minors were injured.

On 1 December 2021, around 300 parents demonstrating against rapid tests, vaccination of children and the government's new coronavirus measures making mask-wearing at school compulsory for children aged 6 and over rallied outside the Philoxenia conference center in Aglandja, where parliament committees meet, during a session of the House education committee that was discussing coronavirus measures in schools and recent incidents of individual violence by parents attacking teachers and staff in many schools. The protesters held banners and shouted slogans demanding the President's resignation and the abolition of the measures, while they were observed by strong police forces. They insisted for their representatives to enter parliament, but they were denied.

On 1 December 2021, parents demonstrating against the government's new coronavirus measures making mask-wearing at school compulsory rallied outside the district offices of the Ministry of Education in Pafos, while they were observed by strong police forces.

On 30 November 2021, hundreds of parents and students demonstrating against the government's new coronavirus measures making mask-wearing at school compulsory rallied for a third day outside the district offices of the Ministry of Education in Limassol disrupting traffic for about 3 hours. Police arrested 1 parent who not only refused to allow a vehicle through following police instructions, but also attacked a police officer. The rally was not affected by this incident.
On 30 November 2021, parents demonstrating against the government's new coronavirus measures making mask-wearing at school compulsory rallied in central Pafos and then marched shouting slogans.

On 29 November 2021, tens of anti-vaccine demonstrators and mask deniers, mostly parents of primary school children, rallied outside the district offices of the Ministry of Education in Pafos to protest against the government's new coronavirus measures making mask-wearing at school compulsory. Many children skipped school and joined their parents in protest. British citizens, who are permanent Pafos residents, were also involved in organizing the demonstration and one of them appeared dressed as Batman.

On 29 November 2021, parents and students demonstrating against the government's new coronavirus measures making mask-wearing at school compulsory rallied for a second day outside the district offices of the Ministry of Education in Limassol before marching to Limassol port, where they blocked the entrance for about 1 hour. notes: On 16 September 2021, members of POGO and the women's section of the Cyprus Green Party rallied outside parliament in Nicosia to protest over an incident of verbal abuse during a session of the House Education Committee the previous week by an ELAM lawmaker against a female Green Party parliamentary assistant.

On 16 September 2021, members of the Famagusta branch of the Union of Cyprus Pensioners (EKYSY) rallied in Deryneia to protest for their rights ahead of 1 October, the International Day of Older Persons established by the United Nations.

assoc_actor_1: Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus); KTOEOS: Cyprus Turkish Secondary School Teachers Union; Teachers (Cyprus)
notes: On 15 September 2021, Turkish Cypriot teachers supported by KTOS and KTOEOS rallied at a newly built primary school in Lapta (Lapithos) to protest over infrastructure problems, but mostly against the return to classes in person with a high number of students per class and demanded increased coronavirus safety measures.

On 15 September 2021, about 50 foreign nationals pushed away the security guard at a welfare office in Nicosia and entered the building by force. The employees locked themselves in their offices and called the police. Team Z police officers evacuated the intruders. No injuries or damages were reported. The reason for the forced entry is unclear from the reports.

On 14 September 2021, a member of the Committee Against Bird Slaughter (CABS) was attacked by a group of bird trappers in Sotira. The activist was monitoring the garden of a known poacher when the illegal trapper first threatened him and then pointed a loaded gun to his chest before he was joined by other bird trappers, who were grabbing and pushing the CABS member around and threatening him with physical harm. The incident was over following the arrival of police patrol cars and officers of the Game Service.

On 13 September 2021, primary school students, teachers and parents rallied outside their school in Dali holding banners and shouting slogans demanding clean air and protesting over delays in the relocation of asphalt plants away from their community.

On 13 September 2021, pupils and their parents protested outside the primary school of Agioi Anargyroi in Monagroulli in the district of Limassol against a Ministry of Education decision to merge the first and second year classes of the school as the number of students for both years does not exceed 20.

On 11 September 2021, the parents and family of a baby that sustained brain damage during birth and who blamed the doctor responsible for the birth rallied in the Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus in Northern Nicosia holding banners to demand justice.

On 10 September 2021, demonstrators demanding the ministry of health covers the cost of treatment for a baby with SMA type 1 disease rallied outside the health ministry in Northern Nicosia preventing vehicles from exiting the building. A demonstrator hit the driver of a car attempting to drive through. 2 demonstrators were injured in clashes with the police and were hospitalized. There was 1 arrest.

On 10 September 2021, on the first day back to school, parents of pupils at the Astromeritis primary school protested against the transfer of the school's principal. The protesters locked the school gates using chains preventing teachers from entering.

On 9 September 2021, the 'United Parents of Cyprus' protested outside the Ministry of Education in Nicosia against coronavirus health protocols and rapid tests in schools. The protesters said they would not allow schools to become health centers.

On 8 September 2021, a number of students and their parents rallied outside Cyprus University of Technology (Tepak) in Nicosia to protest the ban on the physical presence of students who are not vaccinated against coronavirus on campus for the new semester. The protest was organized by the autonomous student movement Niki and took place outside the building where the senate was meeting.

On 30 August 2021, parents from 5 organizations for people with disabilities rallied outside the ministry of education and outside the Presidential palace in Nicosia demanding school escorts for their children.

On 29 August 2021, students of the Cyprus University of Technology (Tepak) rallied in Nicosia over the exclusion of students not vaccinated against the coronavirus from attending classes in person. They also protested against SafePass and the cost of coronavirus tests.

assoc_actor_1: Government of Cyprus (2013-2023); Greek Ethnic Group (Cyprus); Refugees/IDPs (Cyprus)
notes: On 29 August 2021, Greek Cypriots originally from the abandoned village of Achna under the control of Turkish forces in Northern Cyprus participated in a protest event on the 47th anniversary of the Turkish occupation of Achna on 28 August 1974 condemning the occupation and reiterating a request, which had been denied for the 4th year in a row, to reopen the church of Ayia Marina for services. The mayor and representatives of all organized groups of Achna participated holding speeches and prayers.

On 25 August 2021, students of the Cyprus University of Technology (Tepak) protested outside the health ministry in Nicosia against the exclusion of students not vaccinated against the coronavirus from attending classes in person.

On 17 August 2021, members of the Turkish Chamber of Craftsmen (KTEZO), Cyprus Turkish Subcontractors Association and Furniture Manufacturers Association rallied in Northern Nicosia protesting that the government is insensitive to the problems experienced by tradesmen and is trying to abolish the insurance premium support. The demonstrators were holding black flags and a banner; they also left an empty cauldron outside the Prime Minister's office and their leaders held speeches.

On 12 August 2021, employees of DP World Limassol, on an indefinite strike that started on 11 August, protested for the second day at the entrance of the Limassol port terminal over the dismissal of 4 employees, who were made redundant following the signing of collective contracts after a spontaneous strike the week before. Union leaders called the move 'an act of revenge' by the company.

On 11 August 2021, employees of DP World Limassol went on a new indefinite strike and protested at the entrance of the Limassol port terminal over the dismissal of 4 employees, who were made redundant following the signing of collective contracts after a spontaneous strike the week before. Union leaders called the move 'an act of revenge' by the company.

assoc_actor_1: Greek Ethnic Group (Cyprus); Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus)
notes: On 11 August 2021, Greek Cypriots and Turkish Cypriots rallied in Famagusta demanding a stop to actions that would lead to a permanent partition of the island. The protesters announced they had founded a common platform with the title 'Eimaste mazi' (We are together).

On 10 August 2021, scores of residents of Kili village gathered outside government buildings in Pafos to protest against their exclusion from compensation to be given to people whose properties were damaged by June's fires in their area. The residents demanded equal treatment as others affected by the recent fires.

On 8 August 2021, unidentified protesters left a fake bomb, consisting of a suitcase with cut cables, outside the Presidential Palace in Nicosia and shouted slogans of unknown content from afar. Police performed a controlled explosion and announced the bomb was fake.

On 7 August 2021, scores of protesters from all districts of the Republic of Cyprus, organized in social media by the group Foni Laou (Voice of the People), rallied outside the Presidential Palace in Nicosia holding banners and shouting slogans for freedom. They were protesting against obligatory vaccination against the coronavirus, which they consider unconstitutional, and particularly against the vaccination of children.

assoc_actor_1: KTAMS: Cyprus Turkish Civil Servants Trade Union; Labor Group (Cyprus); Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus)
notes: On 3 August 2021, members of KTAMS rallied outside the Development Bank in Northern Nicosia making a statement and laying a black wreath to protest against the Development Bank chairman, claiming his decisions are arbitrary and unjust and that his attitude towards KTAMS is aggressive.

On 2 August 2021, unidentified perpetrators beat the Editor-in-Chief of the Cyprus Real News Site in Northern Nicosia, who sustained very serious injuries. The attack took place outside his home. On the same night, unidentified perpetrators attacked the cameraman of the same news site, who was insulted and beaten, while he was on duty outside a police station.
On 2 August 2021, employees of DP World Limassol went on strike and protested spontaneously at the entrance of the Limassol port terminal, demanding the renewal of their collective contracts.

assoc_actor_2: UNFICYP: United Nations Peacekeeping Force in Cyprus (1964-)
notes: On 1 August 2021, unidentified perpetrators attacked a young UNFICYP peacekeeper in Pafos, who was on short leave from his unit, and beat him on his head and other parts of his body. He was found severely beaten and he was transferred to hospital. There was likely a fight, but the peacekeeper was not able to describe the circumstances of his attack because he had sustained a broken jaw.
On 30 July 2021, about 30 protesters rallied outside the Presidential Palace in Nicosia against the government's restriction measures to combat the coronavirus pandemic.

On 25 July 2021, about 500 anti-vaccine protesters rallied peacefully outside the Ministry of Justice in Nicosia against the government's coronavirus measures, including rapid tests and the SafePass requirements for businesses, which they consider to be 'repressive measures'. They also demanded the release of those arrested in connection to the attack at DIAS media group. They were organized online by the platform 'Voice of God'. Riot police in full gear observed the demonstrators.

On 24 July 2021, protesters against coronavirus restriction measures rallied peacefully outside the Presidential Palace in Nicosia. The demonstrators were organized online as part of 'The World Wide Demonstration (AKA World Wide Rally For Freedom)' protesting for 5 freedoms, namely speech, movement, choice, gatherings, health.

assoc_actor_1: Former Military Forces of Cyprus (2013-2023); Students (Cyprus)
notes: On 20 July 2021, on the 47th anniversary of the 20 July 1974 Turkish invasion of Northern Cyprus, members of 5 student associations marched to Ledras crossing point in Nicosia in protest. A veteran soldier held a speech.

On 19 July 2021, ahead of the 47th anniversary of the Turkish invasion of Northern Cyprus, the House Speaker and staff in the House of Representatives, protested with the slogan 'We are all Famagusta' outside parliament in Nicosia against the continuing occupation of Northern Cyprus and against Turkish President Erdogan's visit to Famagusta and plans to reopen fenced-off Varosha contrary to UN resolutions.

assoc_actor_1: BMBP: This Country is Ours Platform; Government of Cyprus (2013-2023); Greek Ethnic Group (Cyprus); Labor Group (Cyprus); Lawyers (Cyprus); Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus)
notes: On 19 July 2021, thousands of Greek Cypriots rallied in Deryneia with the slogan 'We are all Famagusta' to protest against Turkish President Erdogan during his visit in Famagusta on the 47th anniversary of the Turkish invasion of Northern Cyprus and his announcement that the military status of part of Varosha will be lifted and the area will be granted civilian status. The mayor of Famagusta, the president of the Bar Association of Famagusta, representatives of Famagustan football associations, the House Speaker, the Minister of Health, MPs and representatives of political parties also participated in the rally. The protesters, who held speeches, were joined by Turkish Cypriots protesting for peace, freedom and the reunification of the island, including members of the trade union DEVIS and the platform This Country is Ours. The protesters marched to the checking point of Deryneia, where they submitted a petition to representatives of the United Nations.

On 18 July 2021, at least 5,000 according to police estimates, and somewhere between 10,000-20,000 according to demonstrators, rallied outside the Presidential Palace in Nicosia against the government's latest coronavirus measures, and particularly the expanded SafePass requirements. They eventually split into 3 groups and marched in different directions. They hurled bottles and rocks against riot police outside the Presidential Palace and 10 demonstrators assaulted an Associated Press photographer, wounded him, and damaged his equipment. Thousands marched to DIAS media group housing Sigma TV station and stormed the grounds attacking the guard at the gate. Many of the demonstrators hurled bricks, flares and home-made petrol bombs. They broke into the premises torching 5 vehicles and trashing the interior of the building and attacking the staff before they clashed with police. In total, 12 police officers were injured, 7 of which were taken to hospital, 2 of them with serious injuries. As of 29 July, 26 people were identified and arrested, including a popular epidemiologist, who was arrested for inciting violence.

On 17 July 2021, Turkish Cypriot members of a non-governmental organization in Lefke continued their protests over chronic delays in the construction of a road that would connect Lefke to Guzelyurt (Morphou) and claimed that the region of Lefke was ignored by consecutive governments.

On 16 July 2021, tens of members of the association of owners of recreation centers protested in their cars outside the Presidential Palace in Nicosia against a government decree that sees business owners checking that customers and staff have a coronavirus SafePass. The protesters placed placards on their vehicles.

On 16 July 2021, more than 50 young Cypriots and foreign nationals, who had been waiting in the heat for a long time to be vaccinated against the coronavirus, protested spontaneously outside a Walk-In center in Limassol when it was announced that the center had run out of vaccines. The protesters started shouting against the handling of the vaccination process by the Ministry of Health, and there was some verbal confrontation with the staff and nurses of the center.

assoc_actor_1: Greek Ethnic Group (Cyprus); Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus); UCN: Unite Cyprus Now
notes: On 16 July 2021, about 50 Greek Cypriots and Turkish Cypriots, members of Unite Cyprus Now, rallied close to Varosha/Maras in Famagusta, in the area adjacent to the UN-patrolled Green Line, ahead of the visit of Turkish President Erdogan on the 47th anniversary of the Turkish invasion of Cyprus, and held hands to form a human chain symbolizing solidarity and their desire for reconciliation.

actor1: Police Forces of Turkey (2016-) Coast Guard
actor2: Police Forces of Cyprus (2013-2023) Port and Marine Police
notes: On 16 July 2021, early in the morning, a Turkish coast guard vessel chased away a small Cyprus marine police vessel on a routine patrol at 11 nautical miles off the coast of Kato Pyrgos in Tylliria [coded to Coast of Nicosia]. The Cypriot vessel turned towards Kato Pyrgos to avoid an incident, but, at 4 nautical miles from the coast, the Turkish coast guard vessel fired shots at the Cyprus police vessel. Turkish coast guard denied firing shots at the Cyprus coast guard. Cyprus police increased both land and sea patrols since the government declared a 'state of emergency' in May following an influx of Syrian refugees. This incident, which the government of Cyprus described as the first of its kind, took place ahead of Turkish President Erdogan's planned visit to Varosha the following week on the anniversary of the Turkish invasion of Cyprus.

On 13 July 2021, members of the Cyprus Turkish Teachers Union (KTOS) protested outside the President's office in Northern Nicosia over the Republic of Cyprus citizenship issue, which affects citizens born from mixed marriages, and their inability to benefit from the advantages provided by European citizenship. The protesters accused Turkish Cypriot President Tatar (backed by Turkish President Erdogan) of holding a Republic of Cyprus passport and identity card and concealing the fact. They also accused Tatar for not speaking out when prominent Turkish Cypriot citizens were denied entry to Turkey due to 'security reasons'.

On 9 July 2021, nursing staff supported by their union participated in a spontaneous 1 hour strike-protest outside Nicosia General Hospital. The protesters accused the management of the hospital of authoritarian behavior and of taking unilateral decisions that affect negatively the operation of the hospital.

On 8 July 2021, Turkish Cypriot members of a non-governmental organization in Lefke protested over chronic delays in the construction of a road that would connect Lefke to Guzelyurt (Morphou). Police prevented them from blocking the road. There was verbal confrontation with the protesters.
On 7 July 2021, employees of the Famagusta Turkish Municipality (GMB) protested over unpaid salaries.

assoc_actor_1: BMBP: This Country is Ours Platform; TDP: Communal Democracy Party; Journalists (Cyprus); Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus)
notes: On 6 July 2021, members of the platform This Country is Ours marched in Northern Nicosia to protest for the re-opening of the 1996 murder investigation of journalist Kutlu Adali. The protesters passed by the location of the murder and left a black wreath outside police headquarters reading 'We will not be silent'. The chairman of TDP, the president of the Press Workers' Union and the editor-in-chief of Yeniduzen newspaper made statements.
On 5 July 2021, residents of Kellaki village protested for the relocation of a warehouse storing fireworks away from their residential area.

On 1 July 2021, members of the 'Isaak-Solomou Memorial Initiative', including relatives of the Greek Cypriot demonstrators killed by Turkish forces in 1996, gathered at Nicosia International airport holding Greek and Cypriot flags and banners reading 'I don't forget' before flying to Thessaloniki in Greece. This was the beginning of the 25th annual motorcycle procession, usually taking place in Cyprus, titled 'Memory runs again' to emphasize the importance of a shared struggle between Greece and Cyprus and to protest for dignity and freedom on the 47th year of the Turkish occupation of Northern Cyprus and on the 200th year since the beginning of the Greek War of Independence.

On 30 June 2021, state hospital doctors protested outside the psychiatric hospital in Nicosia during a 3 hour strike over their working conditions, and demanded an improvement in the services offered to patients with a mental health condition. The protesters, who were holding a banner reading 'end to anachronistic treatment conditions', said the national health scheme (GESY) reforms did not include the psychiatric hospital.

On 30 June 2021, members of 11 organizations, including POGO, rallied outside the Presidential Palace in Nicosia to protest against a decision by the attorney-general not to prosecute 15 police officers over their failure to properly investigate missing persons reports, allowing a serial killer to go undetected for about three years. This was a reversal of the decision of his predecessor.

On 25 June 2021, protesters over delays in a regeneration project rallied in Limassol during the opening ceremony of nearby projects, attended by the mayor of Limassol. The protesters were holding banners reading 'Nicolaides - The Mayor of Destruction'.

assoc_actor_1: CTP: Republican Turkish Party; Government of Northern Cyprus (2020-); Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus)
notes: On 24 June 2021, CTP protesters, including the Secretary General, the members of the Central Executive Board, deputies, mayors and party members, rallied in Lefke demanding the resignation of the Ersin Tatar government, accusing the current administration of coming to power with the intervention of Turkey. The protesters demanded the investigation of murders of Turkish Cypriots, including journalist Kutlu Adali, and protested for a 'United Federal Cyprus' against Ersin Tatar's plans for splitting Cyprus in two states.

assoc_actor_1: BMBP: This Country is Ours Platform; KTAMS: Cyprus Turkish Civil Servants Trade Union; Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus); Labor Group (Cyprus)
notes: On 24 June 2021, members of the platform This Country is Ours protested outside the Ministry of the Interior in Northern Nicosia over the government's citizenship policy. The president of KTAMS made a statement claiming Turkish Cypriots are becoming a minority in their own country and that the current administration has been granting citizenship in unprecedented numbers in an attempt to change the demography of Northern Cyprus even further ahead of the next elections.

On 23 June 2021, Turkish Cypriot members of 24 labor groups rallied outside the prime minister's office in Northern Nicosia against proposed labor legislation that also affects collective contract agreements, claiming that it undermines unionism. The protesters read a common statement and submitted a memorandum to the government.

On 23 June 2021, after the General Assembly of the United Nations voted for the 29th consecutive year in favor of a resolution to demand the end of the US economic blockade on Cuba, supporters of Cuba rallied outside the United States embassy in Nicosia to protest for lifting the US embargo.

actor1: Police Forces of Turkey (2016-) Coast Guard
notes: Property destruction: On 23 June 2021, 8 armed Turkish police officers on 2 Turkish coast guard vessels surrounded a Cypriot fishing boat in international waters north east of Cyprus, 20 nautical miles off Cape Apostolos Andreas, in the Eastern Mediterranean Sea, and boarded the vessel using an inflatable boat. 4 of the Turkish armed men questioned the crew claiming that the EEZ off the coast of Cyprus north of Deryneia belongs to Turkey, while the other 4 caused damages to the ship's electrical system to the cost of 50,000 euros.

assoc_actor_1: Teachers (Cyprus); SEK: Cyprus Workers Confederation; Labor Group (Cyprus)
notes: On 16 June 2021, teachers at the government's Afternoon and Night educational programs, on an indefinite strike since May, rallied outside the Education Ministry in Nicosia demanding proper contracts that would give them access to unemployment benefits and holidays. The protesters were organized by SEK.

assoc_actor_1: AKEL: Progressive Party of Working People; Government of Cyprus (2013-2023); POGO: Womens Movement; Women (Cyprus)
notes: On 16 June 2021, a group of demonstrators organized by women's group POGO protested outside the offices of the Legal Service of Cyprus in Nicosia against a decision by the attorney-general not to prosecute 15 police officers over their failure to properly investigate missing persons reports, allowing a serial killer to go undetected for about three years. This was a reversal of the decision of his predecessor. AKEL lawmakers also participated in the protest.

On 14 June 2021, residents of Episkopi briefly blocked the Limassol-Pafos road to protest over long-term problems of their municipality and the indifference of the authorities. The protesters demanded the construction of roads and the reconstruction of a bridge among other issues.

On 13 June 2021, tens of tenants in an apartment complex in Pafos protested against the owner of the building after he blocked all entrances and locked them out of their homes because some of the tenants did not contribute to the building's shared utility bills.

On 12 June 2021, leftist Turkish Cypriots of the Left Movement (Sol Hareket) participated in a march in Gonyeli in Northern Nicosia to commemorate the killing of 8 Greek Cypriots by far right Turkish Cypriots on 12 June 1958 and to protest for lasting peace on the island. They were holding placards reading 'confront the past, liberate yourself'.

On 11 June 2021, members of the Pancyprian Association of Professional Lifeguards rallied in Pafos over their working conditions. The protesters demanded the hiring of more lifeguards, new equipment, and the extension of the hours that beaches are watched over by lifeguards among other issues.

On 10 June 2021, members of the Association of Parents of Vergina school in Larnaca protested spontaneously after an armed gang of teenagers from another school entered the school premises the previous day holding irons, crowbars, knives and other sharp objects, disrupting the operation of the school.
On 10 June 2021, members of the Nicosia Bar Association protested outside the Supreme Court building over their working conditions and demanded reforms and increased coronavirus safety measures.

assoc_actor_1: Teachers (Cyprus); PASYNO: Pancyprian Nurses Union Federation; Health Workers (Cyprus)
notes: On 10 June 2021, teachers at the government's Afternoon and Night educational programs, who were on the 5th week of an indefinite strike, rallied holding banners outside the Conference Center in Nicosia, which is housing parliament sessions, while the new House Speaker was being voted. The protesters demanded proper contracts that would give them access to unemployment benefits and holidays. They were joined by representatives of POED and PASYNO.

On 9 June 2021, employees at the Kato Polemidia city hall in Limassol occupied a municipal building in protest over their working conditions and over the government's decision to transfer the ownership of that building to the Famagusta municipality. In the following days, the protesters started relocating of their own accord to the new building, where they installed a sign reading 'Kato Polemidia City Hall'.
On 8 June 2021, employees at the Kato Polemidia city hall in Limassol protested over their working conditions and the dilapidated state of the city hall building.

On 7 June 2021, civil servants launched an indefinite strike at Turkish Alcoholic Drinks and Wine Industry Limited to reinstate the personnel who were dismissed approximately 1.5 years ago. The protesters read a statement outside the factory building in Famagusta.

assoc_actor_1: PASYNO: Pancyprian Nurses Union Federation; Health Workers (Cyprus)
notes: On 7 June 2021, members of PASYNO rallied outside the Ministry of Health in Nicosia to express their support with 3 nurses under investigation for refusing treatment to a coronavirus patient on the grounds that health protocols were not being followed.

On 4 June 2021, on the fifth day of a 5-day demonstration, police towed the tractors and vehicles of livestock producers and breeders, who were blocking traffic outside parliament in Northern Nicosia, after the demonstrators had accepted 6 of the 7 items of a government proposal package. The demonstration was over price hikes in their sector and the lack of government support. Police prevented members of the Farmers Union, arriving to support the demonstrators, from entering Nicosia.
On 4 June 2021, about 70 Muslims and Arabs protested in Limassol demanding they are granted a place of worship in Polemidia.

assoc_actor_1: Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus); Greek Ethnic Group (Cyprus)
notes: On 4 June 2021, tens of Greek Cypriots and Turkish Cypriots, organized by the bi-communal initiative United Cyprus, marched with live music from Freedom Square in Nicosia to Buyuk Han in Northern Nicosia to celebrate the reopening of Ledras crossing point, which was closed due to the coronavirus pandemic, and the opportunity to meet each other, and likely to promote the message of a united Cyprus.

On 4 June 2021, nine crossing points along the United Nations-controlled buffer zone in ethnically split Cyprus [coded to Nicosia] were reopened, allowing free movement across the divide with the display of a negative coronavirus test. The openings became possible after a significant drop in coronavirus infections on both sides. The United Nations helped broker the agreement between the two sides. The closings had caused much controversy as peace activists denounced the move as politically motivated.

On 3 June 2021, on the fourth day of a 5-day demonstration, livestock producers and breeders, demonstrating over price hikes in their sector and the lack of government support, continued to block traffic in Northern Nicosia by rallying with their tractors and other vehicles outside parliament. The government presented to the president of the association a 7-item proposal package.

On 3 June 2021, members of the Cyprus Turkish Student Dormitories Union, the Cyprus Turkish Chamber of Tradesmen and Craftsmen, the Cyprus Turkish Public Vehicles Operators Association, the Cyprus Turkish Travel Agencies Association, and members of Ercan Airport, Famagusta and International Taxi Drivers Association, blocked the road outside the Prime Minister's office in Nicosia to protest over their financial problems due to the coronavirus pandemic. The protesters submitted their recommendations, including in relation to the education sector, to the Prime Minister.

On 3 June 2021, following a fracas in a welfare office in Polemidia, Limassol, by 10 Africans saying they were owed money, its 35 employees - including the security guard, admin and archives staff - walked off their job, and protested outside the welfare office that their employer, which is the state, is not capable of protecting them. Other welfare offices in the city also participated in a strike to express their solidarity.

On 3 June 2021, protesters rallied outside Pafos court against parental alienation and to express their solidarity to a mother of 3 children not allowed to see them. The protesters were holding placards reading 'a mother wants her children', 'no to judicial delays', and 'no to violence against women'. When the protest was over, the protesters dispersed peacefully.

On 3 June 2021, 10 African refugees, claiming they were owed money, caused a fracas in a welfare office in Polemidia, Limassol. Employees were trapped in the building when one of the men broke the glass entrance door, entered the building and kicked office doors. He also attacked the police officers who arrested him. He was transferred to hospital because he injured his leg. There were another 2 arrests, one of whom continued to demonstrate lying on the road intending to be run over by passing vehicles.

On 2 June 2021, the Armenian National Committee of Cyprus held a protest outside the Russian embassy in Nicosia calling on Moscow to exert pressure on Azerbaijan to release Armenian war prisoners held by the Azeri military. The group delivered a resolution to the Russian ambassador to Cyprus. The leader of Solidarity Movement participated in the protest.

On 2 June 2021, on the third day of a 5-day demonstration, livestock producers and breeders, demonstrating over price hikes in their sector and the lack of government support, continued to block traffic in Northern Nicosia by rallying with their tractors and other vehicles outside parliament. The demonstrators continued their action after the government rejected their demands.

assoc_actor_1: Farmers (Cyprus); KTAMS: Cyprus Turkish Civil Servants Trade Union; Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus); Labor Group (Cyprus)
notes: On 1 June 2021, on the second day of a 5-day demonstration, livestock producers and breeders, demonstrating over price hikes in their sector and the lack of government support, continued to block traffic in Northern Nicosia by rallying with their tractors and other vehicles outside parliament. The demonstrators continued their action following a failed meeting with the Prime Minister and the ministers of Finance and Agriculture the previous day. The president of KTAMS participated in the action.

assoc_actor_1: Farmers (Cyprus); TDP: Communal Democracy Party; Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus)
notes: On 31 May 2021, on the first day of a 5-day demonstration, livestock producers and breeders, demonstrating over price hikes in their sector and the lack of government support, clashed with police in Northern Nicosia when they attempted to enter parliament. The demonstrators, who had rallied with tractors and other vehicles outside parliament and the ministry of Agriculture, had 6 demands regarding support by the government that were rejected. The chairman and the deputy of TDP participated in the action.

assoc_actor_1: BMBP: This Country is Ours Platform; Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus)
notes: On 31 May 2021, members of the platform This Country is Ours protested, likely in Nicosia, for democratization and demilitarization. The protesters demanded the reopening of the case of the unsolved 1996 murder of the Turkish Cypriot journalist Kutlu Adali and other murders in Northern Cyprus, following the resurfacing of new information.

source: AFP; AP; Cyprus Mail; Ekathimerini; Philenews
notes: Elections/referendum: On 30 May 2021, Cypriots voted in parliamentary elections for the new House of Representatives [coded to Nicosia]. Traditional parties - including leading center-right DISY and AKEL, the communist party of Cyprus in the opposition - remained in the lead, but they both suffered substantial losses. ELAM, a far-right party that originated as an offshoot of Golden Dawn, doubled its seats in parliament and became the fourth biggest party. DIPA, a new centrist party, secured representation in parliament in its first appearance. The election did not affect the running of the government as executive power rests in the hands of the president, who is elected separately.

assoc_actor_1: CTP: Republican Turkish Party; Women (Cyprus); Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus)
notes: On 28 May 2021, members of the CTP Youth Organization and the CTP Women's Organization rallied outside police headquarters in Northern Nicosia to protest for press freedom and the reopening of the case of the unsolved 1996 murder of Turkish Cypriot journalist Kutlu Adali, following the resurfacing of new information and claims of Turkish involvement. The protesters were dressed in black and distributed black pens.

On 27 May 2021, members of the Pancyprian Association of Professional Lifeguards rallied in Limassol during a pancyprian protest over their working conditions. The protesters claimed ongoing problems of their sector were being ignored for decades.

On 26 May 2021, scores of nightclub owners participated in a motorcade to the Ministry of Finance and the Presidential Palace in Nicosia, where they delivered a petition. The protesters demanded state aid to mitigate 60 weeks of compulsory closure because of the coronavirus pandemic.

assoc_actor_1: Government of Northern Cyprus (2020-); Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus)
notes: On 26 May 2021, mayors who were members of the Executive Board of the Union of KT municipalities in Northern Cyprus marched together to the office of the Prime Minister in Nicosia, demanding coronavirus support among other issues. The protesters were received by the Prime Minister.

On 25 May 2021, members of the Turkish Cypriot teachers' union KTOS protested outside the Ministry of Finance in Nicosia against the dependence of Northern Cyprus on Turkey and particularly borrowing money when the Turkish Lira is losing its value. Also, the Secretary General of KTOS claimed that there was 'a 'gang-state' integration in the Republic of Turkey' and that 'the TRNC became a black money and drug center' and called for citizens to protest against illegal activities in Northern Cyprus.

On 25 May 2021, unidentified assailants placed an explosive device consisting of gas cannisters at the entrance of the Ministry of Health in Nicosia. The explosion caused damages and started a fire. On 14 June 2021, police made an arrest.

assoc_actor_1: Labor Group (Cyprus); Government of Northern Cyprus (2020-); CTP: Republican Turkish Party; Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus)
notes: On 24 May 2021, members of the Cyprus Turkish Chamber of Tradesmen and Craftsmen, including shopkeepers of Arasta, protested in Northern Nicosia demanding the reopening of the checkpoints and allowing free movement to both sides of divided Cyprus. The crossing points had been closed for more than a year due to the coronavirus pandemic. The protesters, who held banners reading 'Open the gates now', were joined by 2 CTP lawmakers.
Property destruction: On 22 May 2021, unidentified assailants torched an armory building in Nicosia district that belonged to a candidate MP and member of the United Cyprus Hunters Movement.
On 22 May 2021, business owners based on a main road in Limassol, and other protesters, rallied claiming that a new road dividing island caused a series of problems and demanding its removal.

assoc_actor_1: Teachers (Cyprus); PEO: Pancyprian Federation of Labour; SEK: Cyprus Workers Confederation; Labor Group (Cyprus)
notes: On 21 May 2021, teachers at the government's Afternoon and Night educational programs, who were also participating in an indefinite strike, marched to the Presidential palace in Nicosia, where they held speeches to protest against their working regime and the lack of labor rights, and particularly not being entitled to unemployment benefits. The protesters were supported by trade federations PEO and SEK and by teachers' unions.

On 19 May 2021, several dozen Orthodox Christians, including 3 priests, lined up in a human chain, holding up wooden crucifixes, religious icons, Greek flags and a banner reading 'Cyprus loves Jesus', and played on loudspeakers church hymns and the Greek national anthem outside Cyprus' state broadcaster in Nicosia protesting that the country's entry in the Eurovision song contest - titled 'El Diablo' - is 'blasphemous'. At same time, a group of female students living nearby counter-protested playing 'El Diablo' in high volume. Police charged a man with uttering threats and causing a disturbance when he barged onto the grounds of the public broadcaster in protest.

On 18 May 2021, unidentified assailants hurled a petrol bomb, consisting of a firecracker in a plastic bottle, at the Polemidia police station in Limassol before fleeing the scene. No injuries or damages were reported.

On 15 May 2021, protesters rallied against the government's coronavirus measures and against coronavirus vaccination in Pafos.

The protesters requested financial support by the government.

On 13 May 2021, Palestinian students studying at the Eastern Mediterranean University (EMU) in Famagusta protested against Israel's attack on Gaza. They were supported by the EMU Vice Rector for Social and Cultural Affairs and academic staff.

On 12 May 2021, members of the Cyprus Turkish Electricity Authority Employees Union (El-Sen) rallied outside the building of the Electricity Authority (KIBTEK) in Nicosia on the second day of an indefinite strike to protest against the privatization of the company. The demonstrators lit a fire before marching to the Ministry of Economy and Energy holding banners and chanting slogans demanding the resignation of the Minister. A police cordon prevented them from entering the ministry. Some of the demonstrators hurled water bottles at the ministry building.

actor1: Police Forces of Turkey (2016-) Coast Guard
notes: Security measures: On 11 May 2021, at least 10 small Turkish fishing boats launched stones and smoke bombs at 2 Italian fishing vessels north east of Cyprus opposite Syria in the Eastern Mediterranean Sea. The Turkish vessels carried out close maneuvers toward the Italian vessels, making contact with and slightly damaging one of them. A Turkish coast guard motorboat and an Italian Navy vessel that was patrolling nearby as part of NATO's Sea Guardian operation, which also dispatched a helicopter, deescalated the incident.
Security measures: On 10 May 2021, additional coronavirus measures took effect in Northern Cyprus [coded to Nicosia] limiting the number of people during religious gatherings and social events.

On 9 May 2021, residents and farmers from the villages of Akaki, Avlona, Deneia, Astromeritis, Peristerona, Katokopia and Mammari in Nicosia district participated in a motorcade next to the buffer zone with their vehicles and tractors. The protesters demanded the removal of barbed wire, which was being installed by the government to prevent irregular migrants from crossing, so that they have unimpeded access to their land and their homes.

On 9 May 2021, protesters against the government's coronavirus measures rallied in Limassol shouting slogans for personal liberties and against the government's handling of the pandemic. Police arrested the 11 organizers of the protest before the rally. Another 3 protesters, one of which was also found in possession of an air gun, were arrested after the rally for defying health safety measures.

On 7 May 2021, citizens queuing in Larnaca port to receive vaccination for the coronavirus started protesting over the delays. 2 police officers were called to calm the crowd and ensure they were keeping a safe distance according to coronavirus regulations.

On 7 May 2021, early in the morning, a family owning a beach bar in Larnaca, which the municipality claims is illegal, protested preventing municipal employees accompanied by police officers from removing the equipment and tables of the bar. There were tens of police officers present, but there was no police intervention.

The protesters, who have been unemployed for a year due to the coronavirus pandemic, requested financial support among other demands. The protest lasted 12 days until 13 March.
