notes: On 1 March 2021, hundreds of Turkish Cypriot journalists and workers in the media, supported by their unions, marched in Northern Nicosia for freedom of the press, claiming that incidents of violence against journalists, as well as threats and intimidation by the Turkish administration, have increased. The protesters were joined by politicians from CTP, TDP, HP, KSP, and members of the Left Movement and labor groups.

On 1 March 2021, civil servants participated in a protest-strike over the dismissal of 7 employees, whose collective contract agreements had expired in December, at the Famagusta Turkish Alcoholic Beverage and Wine Industry.

On 26 February 2021, members of the association of restaurant and entertainment establishment owners drove in a convoy to the Presidential Palace in Nicosia beeping their horns, where they protested, unfurling a banner at the gates, over the prolonged closure of their businesses due to the coronavirus pandemic, after the government announced that the sector would not be allowed to resume operation until after March 16.

assoc_actor_1: CTP: Republican Turkish Party; Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus)
notes: On 26 February 2021, 5 representatives of the Youth Organization of CTP due to the coronavirus restrictions, protested outside the Prime Minister's office in Nicosia, where they laid a black wreath, over the government's handling of the coronavirus pandemic. The protesters accused the UBP-DP-YDP minority coalition government of being consumed by political disputes, rather than handling the coronavirus crisis.

On 26 February 2021, taxi drivers protested in Larnaca against the decision of the Ministry of Transport to organize a voting for selecting the mode of taxi operation at Larnaca airport, which offered only 2 options. The protesters requested a third option that would allow them to select the coordinators of the taxi operation at the airport.

On 24 February 2021, parents' associations and the mayor of Livadia, a Larnaca suburb, protested against the installation of a 5G antenna on a supermarket rooftop near a kindergarten. The protesters placed a banner on the kindergarten wall reading 'protect our children' and 'say no to 5G' among other slogans.

On 22 February 2021, members of the Cyprus Green Party and residents of Agioi Konstantinos kai Eleni in Dali demonstrated outside the Regional Court of Nicosia against pollution caused by 2 asphalt plants near their communities. The protesters were holding a banner reading 'We want to breathe clean air'.
On 20 February 2021, about 200 protesters against coronavirus restrictions, 5G, and government corruption, marched in Limassol holding candles and carrying a coffin as if in a funeral procession.

On 20 February 2021, about 10,000 protesters, responding to the call of tens of organizations, marched in Nicosia against government corruption and against police violence, demanding the President's resignation. This is a follow-up to a demonstration the week before, also titled 'Os Dame' (loosely translated 'enough'), which was dispersed by police. The protesters, including families with children and Gate 9 football fans, protested holding flowers and banners, many of them in the Turkish language, demanding the island's reunification.

On 18 February 2021, protesters rallied outside police headquarters in Limassol over the way police handled a demonstration on 13 February against government corruption and against the coronavirus lockdown, and expressed their solidarity with an injured demonstrator, covering up one of their eyes.

Around 15 February 2021 (month of), unidentified assailants placed a camping gas canister at the Latsia health center in the outskirts of Nicosia, which was being used for coronavirus vaccinations, causing a blast that damaged the building.

On 13 February 2021, several hundred demonstrators - including members of trade unions, the antifascist sector, radical ecology, the non-parliament left, and families with children - marched in Nicosia against government corruption and the coronavirus lockdown, beating drums and shouting at police. Police used their batons, tear gas, pepper spray, stun grenades, and a water cannon to disperse the crowd, who defied the ban on gatherings. Police claimed demonstrators ignored warnings to disperse and started pelting officers with rocks and other objects from all directions. There were 10 arrests and 6 people were fined. Many demonstrators were injured.

On 12 February 2021, farmers of the municipality of Paralimni protested over insufficient support from the government during the coronavirus crisis, which affected their livelihoods, emptying crates of their unsold produce on the road.

On 10 February 2021, members of single-parent associations, relatives and friends of a Cypriot mother protested outside Pafos court against the decision to give custody of her child to the father, who is a United States citizen residing in New York, and who claimed the mother abducted the child and moved to Cyprus.

On 10 February 2021, refugees, who had been demonstrating over their living conditions in the Pournara reception center in Kokkinotrimithia and over delays in the processing of their applications, rioted following an announcement by the Asylum Service that refugees need to hold a valid tenancy agreement in order to be allowed to leave the camp. During the riot, the Red Cross office in the camp, as well as kitchens and lavatories, were destroyed. Police forces used tear gas and smoke flares to disperse the rioters, who responded by hurling stones at police. Many refugees were injured.

On 6 February 2021, members of 2 environmental groups protested against the leadership of the Church over a series of illegal actions in relation to the environment and cultural heritage. The protesters rallied in Nicosia, wearing masks with the faces of members of the Holy Synod, at a construction site, where listed buildings were illegally demolished to make way for a new cathedral. They were holding placards, each one citing an illegal activity of the church.

On 5 February 2021, Greek Cypriots, who were displaced from Northern Cyprus during the 1974 Turkish invasion and were temporarily given Turkish Cypriot (who in turn were displaced to the north) properties in Pafos to reside in, protested against the mayor's and the local authority's management of these properties, which they consider to be arbitrary, and the protesters claim it lacks respect to the tenants.
Property destruction: On 5 February 2021, unidentified assailants torched the car of a lawyer in Limassol, who is also the president of a 2nd division football team and a candidate lawmaker.

Around 4 February 2021 (week of), African refugees blocked the gates of the Pournara reception center in Kokkinotrimithia, preventing Syrian refugees from exiting the camp. African refugees protested that authorities are allegedly favoring Syrians, letting them out of the camp sooner and more frequently than Africans.

On 3 February 2021, about 200 refugees in the Pournara reception center in Kokkinotrimithia marched out of the center to protest over their living conditions and their protracted detention in the facility due to the coronavirus pandemic. Riot police arrived as a precaution. The refugees shouted slogans and returned to the center when their protest was over.

On 2 February 2021, Kurdish people of Limassol rallied at the Kurdistan Cultural Centre 'Theofilos' and started a hunger-strike, which lasted for 8 days, to express their solidarity with the 700 Kurds on hunger-strike in Turkish prisons, with Kurdish hunger-strikers in Lavrio, Greece, and with Kurdish protesters on hunger-strike outside the United Nations offices in Geneva. The protesters demanded information on Kurdish leader Abdullah Ocalan, who is jailed in Turkey, and decried the imprisonment of tens of thousands of political prisoners in Turkey.

On 1 February 2021, refugees in the Pournara reception center in Kokkinotrimithia protested within the center over their living conditions and their protracted detention in the facility due to the coronavirus pandemic. The protesters held banners in English and Arabic demanding permission to leave the premises.

On 25 January 2021, tens of Turkish Cypriot workers living in Northern Cyprus and working in the Republic of Cyprus continued their protest against the coronavirus quarantine restrictions preventing them from commuting to work. They rallied at the Ayios Dhometios border (Kermiya/Metehan) holding placards reading 'Be fair' and 'Respect for the workers' asking Turkish Cypriot authorities to apply the same rules to them as to their counterparts working in the British Bases or the buffer zone.

Security measures: On 25 January 2021, the Turkish Cypriot administration [coded to Nicosia] implemented longer curfew hours in Northern Cyprus, and on 26 January ordered a full-day lockdown in Nicosia and Kyrenia. The general lockdown was applied to the rest of the country on 29 January to be effective until 3 February and longer in areas with a heavier epidemiological burden.

assoc_actor_1: KTOEOS: Cyprus Turkish Secondary School Teachers Union; Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus); Teachers (Cyprus)
notes: On 25 January 2021, members of KTOEOS protested outside the Guzelyurt Vocational School in Morphou over the decisions taken by the Ministry of National Education and Culture and the Ministry of Health Contagious Diseases Supreme Committee, demanding increased coronavirus safety measures in schools.

On 25 January 2021, Turkish Cypriot workers living in Northern Cyprus and working in the Republic of Cyprus continued their protest against the coronavirus quarantine restrictions preventing them from commuting to work. They rallied at the Agios Nikolaos checkpoint in Strovilia asking Turkish Cypriot authorities to apply the same rules to them as to their counterparts working in the British Bases or the buffer zone.

On 21 January 2021, Turkish Cypriot workers living in Northern Cyprus and working in the Republic of Cyprus continued their protest against the coronavirus restrictions preventing them from commuting to work, and over the conditions of their quarantine. They rallied at the border in Strovilia (Akyar Border Gate) demanding solutions from the government.

On 21 January 2021, trade unionists protested outside parliament in Northern Nicosia to demand an increase in the budget allocated for the municipalities in Northern Cyprus, claiming that, during the coronavirus pandemic, responsibilities have increased, but contributions they receive by the state have decreased.

On 18 January 2021, mothers, who are residents of Agioi Konstantinos kai Eleni in Dali, demonstrated outside a health center in Latsia, in Greater Nicosia, demanding the relocation of the asphalt plants causing air pollution in residential areas. The protesters, who were holding a banner reading 'We breathe whatever they burn', timed their protest as President Anastasiadis was receiving the second dose of the Covid-19 vaccine and managed to meet him.

assoc_actor_1: KTAMS: Cyprus Turkish Civil Servants Trade Union; Labor Group (Cyprus); Health Workers (Cyprus); Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus)
notes: On 18 January 2021, Turkish Cypriot civil servants represented by KTAMS and Kamu-Sen rallied outside Famagusta hospital during a protest-strike over the increased workload of health workers due to understaffing. Public health workers also protested that they have not been paid for 6 months.

On 14 January 2021, members of the Turkish Cypriot Electricity Authority Employees' Union (EL-SEN) rallied outside the Turkish Cypriot Electricity Authority (KIB-TEK) in Northern Nicosia. Their president read a statement demanding that the Deputy Prime Minister and Finance and Energy Minister reveals the corruption allegations in KIB-TEK, and called for urgent and short-term investments in the institution.

On 13 January 2021, the Federation of Free Trade Unions (Hur-Is) protested in front of the Ministry of Labor and Social Security in Northern Nicosia over the fact that the minimum wage has not been determined yet.

assoc_actor_1: KTOEOS: Cyprus Turkish Secondary School Teachers Union; KTAMS: Cyprus Turkish Civil Servants Trade Union; Health Workers (Cyprus); Teachers (Cyprus); Labor Group (Cyprus); Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus)
notes: On 12 January 2021, members of the authorized public sector unions KTOEOS, KTOS, KTAMS, Medicine-Is and the Nurses and Midwives Union protested outside the Ministry of Finance in Northern Nicosia over the new government's failure to initiate protocol negotiations, and demanded the adjustment of the minimum wage according to current conditions.

On 11 January 2021, about 600 refugees from various African states and from Syria clashed at the Pournara refugee reception center in Kokkinotrimithia. The cause of the unrest is likely overcrowding due to the coronavirus lockdown in addition to an increase in their numbers. The rioters hurled rocks and attacked each other with brass knuckles. Windowpanes were shattered, beds and other equipment smashed and a section of the camp's fencing sustained extensive damage. Riot police arrested 4 Syrians and 4 Africans. 35 refugees were injured, of which 24 were transferred to hospital for first aid.

On 11 January 2021, about 150 Turkish Cypriot workers living in Northern Cyprus and working in the Republic of Cyprus continued their demonstrations against the coronavirus restrictions preventing them from commuting to work. They marched to parliament in Northern Nicosia, where there were scuffles (verbal confrontations and pushing) with police that had formed a cordon. The demonstrators, who became organized as an association with the name 'Turkish Cypriot Workers in the South', demanded the same treatment as the employees in the British Bases, and as the residents of the village of Pyla, which is located inside the United Nations buffer zone. The Prime Minister received 3 of their representatives.

On 9 January 2021, relatives of prisoners in Northern Nicosia Central Prison, who had started a hunger strike the day before, protested in solidarity in front of the prison. They demanded better conditions in prisons during the coronavirus pandemic.

On 9 January 2021, protesters against the renewed coronavirus lockdown, who were organized through social media, gathered in Nicosia driving 50 cars. They then marched to the Ledras crossing point shouting slogans. They were observed by police forces. The following day 1 of the organizers was identified and charged.

On 9 January 2021, mothers, who are residents of Agioi Konstantinos kai Eleni in Dali, demonstrated spontaneously against pollution caused by the nearby asphalt plant. They drove to the factory, which continued to operate throughout the day, honking their horns and creating a lot of noise.

On 8 January 2021, members of the Tourism Workers Platform rallied in Northern Nicosia laying a wreath outside the office of the Prime Minister to protest for support as their sector was hit hard by the coronavirus pandemic.

On 4 January 2021, 200-300 protesters - according to police estimates - participated in a motorcade of 200 vehicles around Nicosia against the coronavirus lockdown measures banning rallies and gatherings. The protesters drove to the Presidential palace, where strong police forces prevented them from reaching the gates. There were 2 arrests and 9 people were fined.
On 29 December 2020, members of labor groups participated in a protest-strike outside the prime minister's office in Northern Nicosia over unpaid salaries.

assoc_actor_1: AKEL: Progressive Party of Working People; Government of Cyprus (2013-2023); Labor Group (Cyprus)
notes: On 24 December 2020, members and lawmakers of AKEL joined owners of small and medium businesses in a protest rally in Limassol over the problems their sector is facing due to the coronavirus pandemic.

assoc_actor_1: KTAMS: Cyprus Turkish Civil Servants Trade Union; Labor Group (Cyprus); Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus)
notes: On 22 December 2020, members of KTAMS protested outside of parliament in Northern Nicosia against the government rejecting the resignation of a UBP deputy staying in Istanbul, but receiving a salary from Northern Cyprus.

On 21 December 2020, parents of students already flying from Great Britain to Cyprus protested at Larnaca airport against their children's 7-day coronavirus quarantine in hotels arranged by the state, and over the late warning for this additional measure.

On 21 December 2020, parents of students already flying from Great Britain to Cyprus protested at Pafos airport against their children's 7-day coronavirus quarantine in hotels arranged by the state, and over the late warning for this additional measure.
On 19 December 2020, the Iskele Environment and Coasts Protection Initiative protested at 'Long Beach' [coded to Trikomo] against plans for hotel construction.

On 17 December 2020, members of the Public Workers Union participated in a protest-strike at the Agricultural Products Corporation in Nicosia over unpaid insurance and reserve fund premiums of the employees. The protesters unfurled banners.
On 16 December 2020, trade unionists protested outside the Ministry of Labor in Northern Nicosia for an increase of the minimum wage. The protesters also held a press conference.

On 16 December 2020, on the second day of their protest, Turkish Cypriots living in Northern Cyprus and working in the Republic of Cyprus drove to the Pergamos (Kermiya) crossing point to protest against new coronavirus rules by the Turkish Cypriot administration closing the border. The demonstrators then briefly disrupted traffic in Nicosia protesting outside the Prime Minister's office, where he received their representatives.

On 15 December 2020, around 100 Turkish Cypriots living in Northern Cyprus and working in the Republic of Cyprus protested at the Ayios Dhometios (Metehan) crossing point against new coronavirus rules by the Turkish Cypriot administration closing the border. The demonstrators walked to northern Nicosia in protest and attempted to enter the Prime Minister's office. One demonstrator was detained briefly and was let go after the protesters agreed to leave the premises. They continued their protest at a nearby empty land.

Security measures: On 15 December 2020, the Turkish Cypriot administration [coded to Nicosia] introduced new coronavirus restrictions closing border crossing points to the Republic of Cyprus, and introducing quarantine measures for Turkish Cypriots commuting to the south that continued into the new year, and implementing a 5-day night-time curfew on New Year's Eve and again on 17 January.

On 13 December 2020, unidentified perpetrators used a makeshift explosive device to blast the entrance of a telecommunications provider in Limassol. Police suspect 5G opponents as there were slogans written on the building against 5G networks. 2 more makeshift explosive devices went off at a bank branch and 5 hooded assailants hurled petrol bombs, attempting to burn down a Christmas tree. Police are investigating a possible link between the 3 consecutive attacks. On 19 January 2021, police arrested a contract soldier in the National Guard. A second person was arrested on 6 February. A third person was arrested on 8 March.

Security measures: On 10 December 2020, the Government of Cyprus [coded to Nicosia] re-introduced stricter measures, including a night-time curfew and a ban on public and private gatherings. In addition, the government introduced daytime movement restrictions.

On 10 December 2020, on the day the government of Cyprus announced stricter coronavirus measures due to a resurgence in the pandemic, demonstrators marched against the new restrictions, but also against political corruption. They clashed with police, who prevented them from entering a TV station in Nicosia. The demonstrators then blocked the road disrupting traffic and shouted slogans against police and journalists. They hurled rocks and smoke canisters at the police, who used water cannons to disperse the crowd. Cars were damaged. There were 3 arrests. 2 police officers and 1 demonstrator were injured. On 14 December, there were 2 more arrests.

assoc_actor_1: Labor Group (Cyprus); Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus); Police Forces of Northern Cyprus (2020-)
notes: On 8 December 2020, members of the Customs Employees Union (GUC-SEN) rallied outside the Public Service Commission in Northern Nicosia, where they left a black wreath and held a press release to protest over understaffing.

assoc_actor_1: CTP: Republican Turkish Party; TDP: Communal Democracy Party; Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus)
notes: On 5 December 2020, Turkish Cypriot youth civil society organizations organized a large 'March for Peace' in Northern Nicosia. The protesters, who called themselves 'peace walkers', rejected all kinds of ethnic and religious discrimination and marched to the Ledras/Lokmaci crossing point. Members of TDP, CTP Youth, and of the Left Movement and the Revolutionary Communist Union also participated in the march.

assoc_actor_1: KTAMS: Cyprus Turkish Civil Servants Trade Union; Labor Group (Cyprus); Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus)
notes: On 4 December 2020, private sector employees and members of KTAMS protested outside the Ministry of Labor and Social Security in Northern Nicosia requesting an urgent meeting of the Minimum Wage Determination Commission for the re-determination of the minimum wage.

On 3 December 2020, despite a ban on gatherings, protesters against corruption (following the recent passports scandal) and against the government's coronavirus measures rallied outside a conference center in Nicosia that is temporarily hosting parliamentary sessions. The protesters shouted slogans against lawmakers. 10 people were fined for breaking the coronavirus ban. The protesters then participated in a motorcade in Nicosia.

On 2 December 2020, 45 kidney patients who receive dialysis at the Famagusta general hospital in the Republic of Cyprus staged a three-hour demonstration protesting against the lack of doctors in the unit in the afternoons, during weekends and holidays. This is an issue that existed before Covid-19.

assoc_actor_1: Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus); Greek Ethnic Group (Cyprus)
notes: On 2 December 2020, Turkish Cypriots organized by the Association 'Peace' protested for a federal solution for Cyprus during the arrival of the UN special envoy in Northern Nicosia. On the other side of the Green Line, Greek Cypriots from Famagusta also protested for the same issue outside the presidential palace in Nicosia and unfurled a banner against the two-state solution.

On 1 December 2020, teachers rallied, holding a banner in front of the Ministry of Education and Culture in Northern Nicosia, protesting that college exams are not utilizing a modern assessment system, arguing that they create inequality among students and should be abolished.

assoc_actor_1: KTAMS: Cyprus Turkish Civil Servants Trade Union; Labor Group (Cyprus); Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus)
notes: On 26 November 2020, members of KTAMS rallied outside the Presidential office in Northern Nicosia to protest over President Tatar recruiting 16 temporary workers at the Prime Minister's office using the Prime Minister's signature when he was already President. The protesters argued that the duties and responsibilities of the Prime Minister were suspended, therefore he was not authorized to appoint these workers to public institutions.

assoc_actor_1: KTOEOS: Cyprus Turkish Secondary School Teachers Union; Teachers (Cyprus); Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus)
notes: On 23 November 2020, ahead of Teachers' Day on 24 November, Cyprus Turkish Secondary Education Teachers Union (KTOEOS) and Cyprus Turkish Teachers' Union (KTOS) held a demonstration outside parliament in Northern Nicosia protesting for 'Non Dogmatic, Public Scientific Democratic and Contemporary Education'.

On 21 November 2020, about 30-40 masked protesters entered classes in Dasoupoli High School in Nicosia scattering fliers. The content of the slogans on the fliers was not reported. The protesters left without causing any damages.

assoc_actor_1: Labor Group (Cyprus); Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus); Police Forces of Northern Cyprus (2020-)
notes: On 20 November 2020, customs officers with the support of their unions participated in a protest-strike outside the Customs Office in Northern Nicosia due to lack of personnel.

assoc_actor_1: Cyprus Green Party; Government of Cyprus (2013-2023)
notes: On 19 November 2020, residents of Agioi Konstantinos kai Eleni in Dali demonstrated spontaneously when the smell became unbearable against pollution caused by the nearby asphalt plant by blocking its gate with their cars hindering the factory's operation. The mayor of Dali and a Green Party lawmaker also participated in the motorcade.

On 17 November 2020, 6 of the 16 asylum seekers at the migrant reception center in Kofinou, who were found positive to the coronavirus, refused to be transferred to another facility and started vandalizing the reception center. Local police officers called for reinforcements from Larnaca.

assoc_actor_1: CTP: Republican Turkish Party; TDP: Communal Democracy Party; Independence Road; UCN: Unite Cyprus Now; Labor Group (Cyprus); Lawyers (Cyprus); Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus)
notes: On 15 November 2020, on the day Turkish President Erdogan organized a picnic in Varosha/Maras at Famagusta in Northern Cyprus, Turkish Cypriots protested in three separate marches in Northern Nicosia holding banners with the slogan 'No picnic over pain'. CTP Youth organized the action 'Struggle for Peace and Democracy' and marched holding a banner reading 'Let us remind you, this country is ours'. CTP leadership also participated. TDP Youth organized the action 'Unity, Struggle and Solidarity'. The 3rd march was organized by Independence Road, Left Movement and Baraka Cultural Center with the participation of Unite Cyprus Now, labor groups and members of the Union of Turkish Bar Associations. Protesters shouted 'Block Erdogan, not people' when police barricades prevented them from reaching the Turkish embassy. They also chanted 'Erdogan take your hands off our collar'.

On 15 November 2020, on the day Turkish President Erdogan organized a picnic in Varosha/Maras at Famagusta in Northern Cyprus, Greek Cypriot students marched to the Lidras checkpoint in Nicosia protesting against the opening of Varosha beachfront against UN resolutions, the arrival of Erdogan on the island, and the provocative picnic in Varosha. Strong police forces were observing the march.

assoc_actor_1: Cyprus Green Party; Government of Cyprus (2013-2023); Greek Ethnic Group (Cyprus); Students (Cyprus)
notes: On 15 November 2020, on the day Turkish President Erdogan organized a picnic in Varosha/Maras at Famagusta in Northern Cyprus, the municipal council of Famagusta walked to the checkpoint in Deryneia to protest against Erdogan's plans to impose a two-state solution to the Cyprus problem. In a statement, the mayor admitted that Greek Cypriots also made mistakes, but called for unity at the last moment, and asked of the UNSG to stop being neutral as Turkey is violating UN resolutions. Students and representatives of the Green Party also participated in the walk and planted olive trees as a symbol of peace.

On 14 November 2020, following stricter local coronavirus lockdown measures in Limassol and Pafos, hundreds demonstrated in Limassol against the government's restrictions. 130 police officers were deployed. Some demonstrators turned violent setting fire to garbage bins, using firecrackers and hurling rocks at shop windows. Police responded by using a water canon and tear gas. More than 20 rioters were arrested. 3 police officers were injured lightly. Police discovered 6 petrol bombs hidden nearby.

On 11 November 2020, members of the Cyprus Turkish Teachers' Union (KTOS) protested over the continuing lack of teachers in primary schools at the school yard of Mandres (Hamitkoy) primary school, where the KTOS president read a press release.

Weapons seizure: On 11 November 2020, Cyprus police following information tips located 5 incendiary devices in the Larnaca region likely connected to the 14 November riots in Limassol against the government's coronavirus measures and lockdown.

assoc_actor_1: CTP: Republican Turkish Party; TDP: Communal Democracy Party; Government of Northern Cyprus (2020-); Labor Group (Cyprus); DP: Democratic Party; Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus)
source: Greek Reporter; LGC News; Yeniduzen; Philenews; SigmaLive; Detay
notes: On 10 November 2020, more than 3,000 protesters organized by the 'Democracy and Will' platform marched to Inonu Square in Northern Nicosia against Turkish political intervention in the democracy of Northern Cyprus following what transpired during and after the 2020 presidential elections and ahead of a visit to Varosha/Maras by Turkish President Erdogan. Former Turkish Cypriot President Mustafa Akinci, leaders and members of political parties CTP, TDP, DP, the mayor of the Nicosia Turkish Municipality (NTM), and members of the trade union platform participated in the protest. The organizers held a speech. The protesters were holding placards reading 'Cyprus is secular, it will remain secular' and 'Cypriots have the Last Word in Cyprus', 'Self-Determination, Not Intervention' among many slogans for freedom, peace and unity, and they raised their phone lights in the air singing Bella Ciao.

assoc_actor_1: AKEL: Progressive Party of Working People
notes: On 7 November 2020, members of AKEL rallied outside the Presidential Palace in Nicosia protesting over the passports scandal brought to light by the Al Jazeera network, and they accused the government of attempting to cover it up.

On 6 November 2020, members of the Movement 'Active Citizens ' and of the Platform 'End Corruption' rallied outside the Presidential Palace in Nicosia demanding the resignation of those responsible for the passports scandal brought to light by the Al Jazeera network, and they accused the government of attempting to cover it up.

On 6 November 2020, senior high school students in Nicosia protested at their school yard holding a banner with the slogan 'ARTSAKH STRONG' to express their solidarity with Armenians fighting against Azerbaijan. The students were holding Greek and Armenian flags.

Elections/referendum: On 5 November 2020, in the middle of proceedings to elect the new leader of ruling party UBP, who would also become automatically the next Prime Minister of Northern Cyprus [coded to Nicosia], both candidates withdrew from the elections before the second round without offering any reasonable explanation. Elections for the next Prime Minister were postponed for 10 months and Ersin Tatar, the former Prime Minister until he was recently elected President of Northern Cyprus, appointed the General Secretary of UBP as temporary party leader and Prime Minister, and gave him the mandate to form a government. There were widespread allegations of interference by Turkey and organizations affiliated to UBP started resigning from the party.
On 5 November 2020, residents of Liopetri rallied against the construction of a sewage pumping station near their community and demanded that it is constructed 500 meters further away.

Movement of forces: On 4 November 2020, just a few hours after the first meeting between the President of Cyprus and the new Turkish Cypriot leader, Turkey issued a Navtex for seismic survey in parts of offshore blocks 5 and 6 [coded to Coast of Pafos] until 16 February moving Barbaros and its supporting military vessels from blocks 6 and 7, undermining attempts to create space for dialogue. The Turkish Navtex reserves part of the maritime area, which has been legally demarcated between the Republic of Cyprus and Egypt with a bilateral EEZ boundary agreement in 2003.

Security measures: On 4 November 2020, the Government of Cyprus announced a partial lockdown in the Republic of Cyprus [coded to Nicosia] with a 10-person maximum for gatherings at home or any public space among other measures, and a night curfew from 11pm starting on 5 November, due to a resurgence in the coronavirus pandemic. Additional measures were imposed on Pafos and Limassol that had a worse epidemiological profile. On 12 November, a travel ban was imposed to and from Pafos and Limassol and a stricter curfew from 8pm. The measures will be valid until 30 November.

assoc_actor_1: AKEL: Progressive Party of Working People; DIKO: Democratic Party; Cyprus Green Party
notes: On 30 October 2020, members of AKEL, DIKO and the Cyprus Green Party participated in an anti-corruption rally outside a new academic institute in Pafos, while the opening ceremony was taking place inside and where the President of Cyprus was present, in the wake of the passports scandal brought to light by the Al Jazeera network.

On 29 October 2020, dozens of Polish women dressed in black rallied outside the embassy of Poland in Nicosia to protest against an almost-total abortion ban ruling and to express their solidarity with demonstrations in their home country. Some of the protesters were holding black umbrellas.

On 29 October 2020, business owners of evening private schools for sports, social and cultural extra-curricular activities for minors, protested in Limassol against the government's latest coronavirus measures, which suspend these activities.

On 28 October 2020, around 1,000 demonstrators, who were organised online, rallied in Limassol against the government's coronavirus measures, against corruption, and against 5G technology. About 400 hooded demonstrators rioted with a subgroup of 100 making use of flares and fireworks, and setting trash cans on fire. They hurled rocks and other objects at police and torched a police vehicle using petrol bombs. The officers in the vehicle escaped unharmed, but 4 other officers and a firefighter were injured and transferred to hospital. Other patrol cars and private vehicles in the area were also damaged. 7 suspects were detained briefly.

On 27 October 2020, senior high school students of Dali protested at their school against the opening of part of uninhabited Varosha in Famagusta violating UN resolutions. The students shouted slogans and waved Greek and Cypriot flags.

On 27 October 2020, more than 150 Muslims, who arrived from Limassol and Nicosia, rallied outside the French embassy in Nicosia to demonstrate against the government of France following the beheading of a teacher and the projection of Charlie Hebdo cartoons onto government buildings in France, and the reaction of Turkish President Erdogan against French President Macron. About 20 of the demonstrators clashed with police after they took down the embassy's French flag and destroyed it. There were 4 arrests.

On 25 October 2020, members of the Armenian community of Cyprus participated in a motorcade in Nicosia to protest against Azeri attacks at Nagorno-Karabakh. The protesters drove by the embassies of the United States, Russia, France and Israel.

On 24 October 2020, protesters against the governments coronavirus measures rallied outside the Presidential palace in Nicosia holding banners and placards with messages against the use of face masks and against vaccines.

On 24 October 2020, people participated in an anti-corruption rally in Nicosia in the wake of the passports scandal brought to light by the Al Jazeera network, demanding justice and a legal investigation on the matter.

On 23 October 2020, members of the Cyprus Green Party rallied in Nicosia demanding the dissolution of parliament after lawyers and officials involved in the Cyprus passport scheme were exposed as corrupt in an undercover Al Jazeera video.

On 22 October 2020, some 350 people marched from the Ministry of the Interior to the Presidential palace in Nicosia in the wake of the passports scandal brought to light by the Al Jazeera network, which resulted in the resignations of an AKEL lawmaker and of the President of the House of Representatives. The protesters, who were organized by 'Active Citizens', a non-partisan loose grouping of concerned citizens, placed a mock-up coffin on the perimeter wall of the presidential palace, with the words 'Integrity, Transparency and Honesty.'

assoc_actor_1: Government of Cyprus (2013-2023); Health Workers (Cyprus); Labor Group (Cyprus); PEO: Pancyprian Federation of Labour
notes: On 22 October 2020, tens of employees at the Famagusta coronavirus reference hospital, mostly nurses, protested outside the hospital to express their solidarity with 3 nurses about to lose their jobs. The mayor of Deryneia and a representative of PEO also participated in the protest, as well as many citizens, who joined the protest spontaneously wanting to express their gratitude to nursing staff at the hospital.
On 21 October 2020, members of the administrative staff in state schools protested in Nicosia, demanding permanent positions.

On 21 October 2020, about 150 school and university students protested in Nicosia against the opening of part of Varosha in Famagusta by Turkish Cypriot leader Ersin Tatar violating UN resolutions. The protest took place outside the Presidential palace during a trilateral summit between Nicosia, Cairo and Athens.
On 20 October 2020, members of EDON protested at the Deryneia checkpoint for the liberation and unification of Cyprus and for Greek Cypriots and Turkish Cypriots to live together in a federal Cyprus.

On 19 October 2020, hundreds of protesters marched to the Presidential mansion in Nicosia following new revelations after lawyers and officials involved in the Cyprus passport scheme were exposed as corrupt in an undercover Al Jazeera video. The protesters, who were holding banners - some of them reading 'Refugees welcome' - shouted slogans against corruption, against institutional and social racism, and demanded the President of the Republic of Cyprus resign.

assoc_actor_1: Greek Ethnic Group (Cyprus); Isaak-Solomou Memorial Initiative
notes: On 17 October 2020, hundreds of motorcyclists from all major cities of the Republic of Cyprus, all members of the 'Initiative in Memory of Isaak-Solomou', rallied at the Deryneia crosspoint with the slogan 'We are all from Famagusta - We are all from Kyrenia' to protest against the opening of part of Varosha in Famagusta violating UN resolutions. The organizers refused the participation of anyone carrying partisan insignia. There was strong police and military presence on both sides, including members of the peacekeeping force in the buffer zone. On the other side of the crossing point, citizens of Northern Cyprus, both Turkish Cypriots and settlers from Turkey, including young children, rallied in a counter-protest. They were shouting 'Cyprus is and always will be Turkish' and performed with their hands the symbol of the Turkish ultra-nationalist organization Grey Wolves. Neither side was allowed to approach the checking point. 20 members of the Water Sports Federation of the Republic of Cyprus protested in their speed boats to express their solidarity to the motorcyclists. The coast guard of Northern Cyprus was observing them from a distance.

Akinci and the leader of CTP, attended the march with their followers, as well as other political party leaders, young people and members of NGOs.

source: Detay; Ekathimerini; LGC News; Philenews; The National Herald; Yeniduzen
notes: Elections/referendum: On 11 October 2020, Northern Cyprus held presidential elections [coded to Nicosia} - that would affect the future of Cyprus peace talks - under allegations of an unprecedented level of Turkish interference aiming to influence the election's outcome in favor of its preferred candidate and leader of the UBP party, Ersin Tatar, against independent candidate and moderate Mustafa Akinci. Tatar advocates fully aligning Turkish Cypriot policies with those of Ankara, such as pursuing a two-state deal for Cyprus, which means permanent partition of the two communities, while Akinci is an advocate for a bi-communal, bi-zonal federation to reunify the ethnically divided island. Neither garnered the required majority to win outright. On 18 October, in the second round of the elections, Tatar defeated Akinci.

Some of the demonstrators breached the police checkpoint and moved into the buffer zone (aka the Green Line). Greek Cypriot reports also pointed to the fans of a Greek Cypriot Famagusta football club. The rioters were holding bats and sticks and they were chanting 'Cyprus is Greek'. They lit torches and hurled flares causing fires in nearby fields. They also caused damages to other properties. Police arrived an hour later and dispersed the demonstrators. In the following days, there were 9 detentions of which 6 turned into arrests.

The other presidential candidates and journalists accused Turkey of interfering with elections in Northern Cyprus and of threatening press freedom. Labour groups and the Famagusta Initiative also opposed Tatar's move as a provocative action that does not reflect the political will of the Turkish Cypriot community as it violates UN resolutions and might derail the resumption of Cyprus talks.

On 13 July 2020, about 40 residents and business owners based on a main road in Limassol protested outside City Hall against the construction of a road dividing island.

assoc_actor_1: KTOEOS: Cyprus Turkish Secondary School Teachers Union; Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus); Teachers (Cyprus)

The protesters attempted to enter the building, but they could not pass through the police cordon.

On 10 July 2020, police forces of Northern Cyprus fired shots at a group of 30 refugees - most of them Syrian - arriving at Morphou/Guzelyurt Bay. Two of the refugees were injured and needed medical attention. There were also two women from Africa in the group.

On 8 July 2020, members of 18 environmental organizations, movements and groups protested in Nicosia following the cutting of trees to open space for a car park without consulting Nicosia's citizens. The protesters demanded more green urban spaces, protection of national parks, transparent procedures during decision making and prioritizing the people's well-being over developments.

On 7 July 2020, members of the 4 unions of Turkish Cypriot health workers and doctors rallied in Northern Nicosia during a strike-protest over lack of staff and equipment in the combat against coronavirus. The protesters requested a pandemic hospital among other demands.

On 6 July 2020, residents of the Greek Cypriot village of Kato Pyrgos in Tylliria protested over what they consider are inconsistent coronavirus instructions by the administration excluding them from crossing the Limnitis crosspoint and isolating them from the rest of the Republic of Cyprus, while Turkish soldiers are allowed to pass through Tylliria without any restrictions. The protesters rallied at Mansoura blocking the road to the Kokkina/Erenkoy coastal exclave preventing Turkish military vehicles from passing through.

Property destruction: On 3 July 2020, early in the morning, unidentified arsonists burned four telecommunication antennas in the wider Limassol area, likely in connection to opposition to 5G networks.

On 2 July 2020, members of the United Action Committee of tradesmen and craftsmen marched from Kyrenia to Nicosia to protest for fairer state support due to the coronavirus pandemic. The demonstrators joined their colleagues outside the Prime Ministry in Northern Nicosia and met with the Prime Minister.

On 2 July 2020, health workers rallied outside a major hospital in Northern Nicosia to demand new hospital infrastructure to weather the coronavirus pandemic and to protest over the existing hospital being repurposed into a pandemic hospital causing great disruptions in the treatment of non-COVID cases.

On 1 July 2020, on the first day of a two-week protest, members of the United Action Committee of tradesmen and craftsmen set up their tents outside the Prime Ministry in Northern Nicosia to protest for fairer state support due to the coronavirus pandemic.

On 28 June 2020, groups of activists protested outside the Pournara migrant reception centre in Kokkinotrimithia to express their solidarity with unaccompanied minors following reports of harassment in the camp.

On 27 June 2020, tens of Belarusians protested in Limassol as part of an international action for peaceful change expressing their solidarity with imprisoned Belarusian bloggers and opposition politicians.

assoc_actor_1: Cyprus Green Party; Government of Cyprus (2013-2023)

On 26 June 2020, Turkish Cypriot doctors and nurses supported by their unions marched in Nicosia against the TRNC administration's decision to resume flights on 1 July. The protesters believe that North Cyprus is not ready to combat another wave of the coronavirus pandemic.
On 26 June 2020, legal officers and other staff at the Law Office of the Republic of Cyprus protested spontaneously in Nicosia over the circumstances under which the Attorney-General had to resign.

On 23 June 2020, dozens of members of the United Action Committee of tradesmen and craftsmen rallied in Famagusta to protest for government support due to the coronavirus pandemic.

There have been similar incidents in recent months, but the latest developments were described as an escalation of tensions.

On 29 April 2020, unknown arsonists torched a 20 year old telecommunications mast in Limassol in the wake of an online campaign against 5G that alleges in social media posts that emissions from the network's antennas pose a serious health risk and may be linked to the spread of coronavirus by weakening the human immune system. This is the second incident of torching an older installation in Limassol in the space of two weeks.

On 12 April 2020, unidentified assailants torched a 20 year old telecommunications mast in Limassol, disrupting the communications of thousands of users because they mistakenly believed that it is a new 5G mast. The attack occurred in the wake of conspiracy theories circulating in social media connecting 5G masts and the spread of coronavirus.

They said that the tension caused by political developments in the Eastern Mediterranean should be transformed into benefits for the inhabitants of the region, which should offer a life of religious and intercultural peace, not be a burial ground for people fleeing wars.

On 21 January 2020, members of the World Peace Association protested for an end to geopolitical power games and casted olive wreaths into the sea of Famagusta. They said that the tension caused by political developments in the Eastern Mediterranean should be transformed into benefits for the inhabitants of the region, which should offer a life of religious and intercultural peace, not be a burial ground for people fleeing wars.

On 20 January 2020, Turkey dispatched drillship Yavuz to conduct a drilling operation inside an exploration area south of Cyprus that the Republic of Cyprus has already licensed to energy companies Eni of Italy and Total of France. This is Turkey's 4th such drilling effort since July 2019 when it dispatched a pair of warship-escorted drill ships to the island's west and east. It also marks the second time a Turkish ship is drilling in a block licensed to Eni and Total. The Turkish military also conducted four days of exercises in Northern Cyprus using live ammunition.

assoc_actor_1: KTAMS: Cyprus Turkish Civil Servants Trade Union; Labor Group (Cyprus); Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus)
notes: On 16 January 2020, members of KTAMS protested at the Prime Ministry in Nicosia over the immigration law.

On 16 January 2020, student union PSEM organised a mass protest over the four-monthly exam system. Hundreds of students marched to the Presidential Palace in Nicosia shouting slogans and holding banners in Greek, English, Russian and Spanish. This is an ongoing protest.

On 15 January 2020, up to 2000 Turkish Cypriots rallied in the northern part of Nicosia to protest over the steep rises (30% to 35%) in road taxes, while the bad state of roads remains the same. The protest was organised by a Facebook group with the slogan 'No roads, no road tax' on 2 January without any involvement of political parties or unions and in two weeks reached 38000 members. The protesters wore yellow vests and many of them expressed their grievances over the low minimum wage.
On 15 January 2020, the Trade Union Platform in Northern Cyprus protested over the low minimum wage in front of the Ministry of Labour.

On 15 January 2020, an activist and volunteer member of the Committee Against Bird Slaughter (CABS) was attacked by two poachers while he was leading the British base's police towards two illegal mist netting sites. The attackers, who drove a car without a license plate number, shouted death threats and punched the activist in the face in front of the police officers. On 22 January the two poachers turned themselves in to the police.

Arrests: On 15 January 2020, 33 Syrian migrants including women and children were arrested by Morphou police for entering Northern Cyprus without permission. On the same day, 101 migrants who reached the Republic of Cyprus were hosted in a refugee camp.

assoc_actor_1: KTOEOS: Cyprus Turkish Secondary School Teachers Union; Teachers (Cyprus)
notes: On 10 January 2020, the Turkish Cypriot Secondary Education Teachers' Union KTOEOS protested at the Ministry of National Education and Culture n Nicosia asking for intervention against fake allegations and attempts to discredit teachers in Northern Cyprus and attempts to eliminate teachers' trade unions.

On 9 January 2020, tens of residents of Yiolou near Pafos and the municipal authority protested to offer an alternative solution to redirecting traffic through a lengthy route while work is being carried out due to subsidence of the main road. Their recommendation to use a shorter route through private land was accepted.

assoc_actor_1: Protesters (Israel); Women (Greece); Women (Israel); AKEL: Progressive Party of Working People
notes: On 7 January 2020, about 150 protesters organised by the Network Against Violence Against Women chanted outside Famagusta court to express their solidarity with a British teenager on the day she was sentenced after being found guilty on 30 December of 'public mischief' for reporting that she was raped by 12 Israeli teenagers while on holiday in Ayia Napa and then retracting her statement. Of the 150 almost 60 women activists flew from Israel to support the teenager, who was given a suspended sentence. A female MP of AKEL was also present.

source: Philenews; AFP; AP; The National Herald
notes: On 30 December 2019, 20 to 30 members of the Network Against Violence Against Women - some wearing strips of cloth with stitched lips drawn on them over their mouths - sat in court in Famagusta to support a British teenager accused of 'public mischief' after reporting that she was raped by 12 Israeli teenagers while on holiday in Ayia Napa, but then retracted her statement. The judge found her guilty and a protest took place outside the court building with the protesters chanting 'The rapist is you'.

On 25 December 2019, Syrians living in Pafos marched under extremely bad weather from the Medieval Castle to the Lower Beach in Pafos to protest against the ongoing war situation in Syria. There was discreet police presence.
On 21 December 2019, many women of 11 women's organizations participated in a performance in Famagusta inspired by the Las Tesis global feminist action.

On 17 December 2019, primary school students from Dali supported by their parents did not go to class, but protested in Nicosia instead against the asphalt factories operating near residential areas. This is part of an ongoing protest.
On 17 December 2019, members of the Movement Against Foreclosures and the social platform 'a Roof for Everyone' rallied outside the Bank Association in Nicosia to protest against electronic auctions.

Movement of forces: On 16 December 2019, Turkey began to use the Lefkoniko (Gecitkale) airport in Northern Cyprus for UAVs or drones both unarmed and armed with SIHA weapons. Turkish Cypriot organizations and political parties KTOEOS, KSP and BKP reacted against this move on the grounds that it will increase tension in the region.

assoc_actor_1: Cyprus Green Party; Government of Cyprus (2013-2023); Orthodox Christian Group (Cyprus)

The protest was organized by the municipality of Dali, the church committee and other citizens. The president of the Green Party also participated. This is part of an ongoing protest.

notes: On 10 December 2019, on Human Rights Day, members of KYSOA, the Cyprus Confederation of Disability Organisations, protested outside the Presidential Palace and parents of children with disabilities protested outside the Labour Ministry in Nicosia for disability benefits and socioeconomic inclusion.

On 7 December 2019, residents of Agia Fyla in Limassol blocked the main avenue to protest over traffic problems in the area and generally the delay in carrying out much needed infrastructure works.

On 7 December 2019, family, friends and fellow pupils of a ten-year-old girl that was hit by a car and lost her life, marched from the hospital to the site of the traffic incident to protest for a full and transparent investigation into the circumstances of the girl's death.

On 7 December 2019, residents of Agioi Konstantinos kai Eleni in Dali, which is surrounded by five industrial areas, protested against the unbearable smells and noise by blocking the gates of one of the nearby asphalt factories preventing vehicles from entering or leaving. The Mayors of Dali, Latsia and Yeri, also participated in the protest. This is the second protest this week over these ongoing problems.

On 5 December 2019, more than 100 residents of an apartment complex in Pafos blocked the road symbolically in a spontaneous demonstration to protest over a water supply cut-off that was going on for ten days.

On 3 December 2019, residents of Agioi Konstantinos kai Eleni in Dali, which is surrounded by five industrial areas, protested against the unbearable smells and noise by blocking with 60 vehicles the gates of one of the nearby asphalt factories. The Mayor of Dali and an employee of the Department for the Environment also participated in the protest. These problems exist for years and this is a follow-up of previous protests.

On 2 December 2019, ahead of the International Day of Disabled Persons on 3 December, the Cyprus Paraplegic Organisation rallied outside the House of Representatives to protest over being ignored and not being included in parliamentary discussions that affect their lives on issues regarding accessibility to buildings and open spaces.

On 2 December 2019, social workers of the Social Welfare Services launched a strike protest and rallied at the Ministry of Labour over lack of infrastructure, being understaffed and working under extremely difficult conditions. This is after they have been accused of not preventing the suicide of a teenage boy.

On 28 November 2019, employees of the Forestry Department protested outside the Parliament in Nicosia over being understaffed.

On 27 November 2019, members of seven Turkish Cypriot business organisations rallied on the Turkish Cypriot side of the Ayios Dhometios crossing in Nicosia to protest for more crossing points between north and south that are better staffed and for other improvements to combat delays and problems during crossing that harm their businesses.

The Cyprus Republic Defence Minister confirmed the incident on 16 December without specifying the exact area, but sought to downplay it saying that these incidents occur throughout the world.

On 15 November 2019, students in Larnaca protested against the 36th year since the unilateral declaration of independence of Northern Cyprus.
On 15 November 2019, students in Pafos protested against the 36th year since the unilateral declaration of independence of Northern Cyprus.

On 4 November 2019, students at the Kykkos Lyceum of Pafos protested against the application of a new school exam system.

On 2 November 2019, about 100 parents of children with speech disabilities rallied outside the Episkopi police station in solidarity with a father that had to report to the police because his child was not attending school due to the lack of support staff.

On 30 October 2019, students in Lakatamia of Nicosia protested spontaneously by not entering their classrooms over disagreements related to the school uniform regulations and the expulsion of the president of the student council.

On 29 October 2019, farmers from Kato Polemidia in Limassol protested outside the Presidential Palace and the Parliament for the relocation of their livestock as promised by the government and compensation. This is a follow-up of the 15 October protest. After the protests the government said they would delay on acting on the court order for the demolition of the farms.

assoc_actor_1: AKEL: Progressive Party of Working People; Cyprus Green Party; Government of Cyprus (2013-2023)

The Mayor, city councillors, an AKEL MP and the Green Party regional secretary also participated in the protest.
On 26 October 2019, residents of Zakaki in Limassol marched and distributed fliers to protest against the recent addition of more cranes at the port and the noise they produce.
On 23 October 2019, residents and local authorities protested at the Geroskipou Municipal Hall against the administrative merging of their municipality with Pafos.

On 22 October 2019, culinary students at the Higher Hotel Institute rallied in front of the Filoxenia hotel building in Nicosia to protest against its conversion to a court and asking that it be used by their school instead.

assoc_actor_1: Teachers (Cyprus); KTOEOS: Cyprus Turkish Secondary School Teachers Union
notes: On 22 October 2019, secondary school teachers supported by their union KTOEOS rallied at Famagusta Canbulat Freedom Secondary School to protest over a shortage of mathematics teachers and a general lack of infrastructure and support for the growing student population many of which do not speak Turkish or English. This follows up protests at Erenkoy school for the same reasons.
On 22 October 2019, students at the Technical School of Avgorou protested against Turkey's operations in Syria by rallying in their schoolyard and building the peace sign with their school bags.

assoc_actor_1: Teachers (Cyprus); KTOEOS: Cyprus Turkish Secondary School Teachers Union
notes: On 21 October 2019, 40 secondary school teachers supported by their union KTOEOS rallied at Erenkoy High School (Kokkina exclave) to protest over a shortage of teachers, admin and other staff in all schools of Northern Cyprus, but particularly in Karpaz and Lefke, and over a general lack of infrastructure. They ask from the Ministry of Education for qualified staff in a secular education environment. This is a follow-up from last week's protests.

On 20 October 2019, about 200 residents of Deryneia rallied at the road leading to Paralimni and obstructed traffic for a few minutes to protest over the high number of mobile phone and WiFi masts in their municipality, where the number of cancer cases has increased to more than 50.

On 20 October 2019, Lebanese nationals who are permanent residents in Cyprus rallied outside the Lebanese embassy in Ayios Dhometios to express their solidarity with anti-government demonstrators in Lebanon who are protesting since 17 October.

On 19 October 2019, tens of students and teachers marched in Kyrenia in Northern Cyprus to protest over climate change after a severe storm and flood.
On 19 October 2019, employees at the Health Insurance Organisation OAY held a two hour strike and protest over their health insurance cover.

This exercise took place a week after a French frigate joined Cypriot forces in a smaller exercise.

On 15 October 2019, members of the Nationalist Democracy Party (MDP) and of organisations TMT and UHH in Northern Cyprus left a black wreath at the presidential palace calling on Turkish Cypriot leader Akinci to quit his position after he posted on his social media account in relation to Turkey's operations in Syria that the Fountain of Peace pours blood and not water.
On 12 October 2019, members of the Pancyprian Council marched in Nicosia in solidarity with the Kurdish population in north-eastern Syria that is under attack by Turkey.

Cyprus is encircled with almost 20 vessels, including frigates and submarines. Two French frigates joined Cyprus to conduct naval manoeuvers before heading to Syria.

On 9 October 2019, the Trade Union Platform (TC) and the Cyprus Turkish Civil Servants Trade Union (KTAMS) protested in Nicosia against the Turkish administration's financial protocol and claimed that their policies are against the Turkish Cypriot community.

On 3 October 2019, residents of Ayia Marina Xyliatou entered the shooting range of the nearby field disrupting the military exercises of the National Guard to protest against its proximity to their village.
On 3 October 2019, activists set up tents opposite the Presidential Palace in Nicosia to protest against inequality and high rising costs.

On 16 August 2019, a Syrian national was attacked in Pafos and was hospitalised with a broken nose. Pafos police has started an investigation.

assoc_actor_1: Police Forces of Northern Cyprus (2015-2020) Prison Guards; Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus)
notes: On 9 August 2019, 34 prison employees supported by their unions KTAMS and KAMUSEN rallied in front of the Northern Cyprus central prison in Nicosia over the lack of personnel and the increased workload of existing staff, as well as the delays in transferring to a new prison.

assoc_actor_1: Greek Ethnic Group (Cyprus); Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus)
notes: On 8 August 2019, on the eve of the informal meeting between the Cypriot President and the Turkish-Cypriot leader, members of the 'Bi-communal Peace Initiative - Unified Cyprus' and the 'Initiative Group - Famagusta Our City' marched on either side of the UN buffer zone in Nicosia holding lit torches and banners with slogans such as 'Solution, Reunification, Peace' and 'Cyprus belongs to its people'.

source: Philenews; The National Herald; To Vima; Ekathimerini
notes: On 6 August 2019, the Turkish drillship Yavuz began operating south of the Karpasia (Karpaz) Peninsula. The report coincided with the visit of the Turkish Energy Minister to the Northern Cyprus, who told reporters that a second exploration vessel, the Oruc Reis, would begin work in the area by the end of August and that the Republic of Cyprus faces a heavy price, if it does not agree to the co-administration of the island's hydrocarbons deposits with Ankara. The exploratory activities in the East Mediterranean are taking place under the protection of the Turkish Armed Forces and has been causing increased tensions throughout the year.

On 2 August 2019, members of the Movement Against Foreclosures and the social platform 'a Roof for Everyone' rallied in front of Parliament in Nicosia, while this issue is being discussed in the House of Representatives, to protest against foreclosures with the slogan 'housing is a human right'. More than 50 police officers with 20 police cars were present.

assoc_actor_1: Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus); YDP: Rebirth Party; Government of Northern Cyprus (2015-2020)
notes: On 2 August 2019, two days after the suspended march that set off from the district of Iskele, protesters from the Karpaz peninsula with the support of their municipal leaders and the Rebirth Party (YDP) marched in Northern Nicosia and left a black wreath in parliament to protest over the indifference of the administration of Northern Cyprus for the problems of their region with the slogan 'If there is no Karpaz, there is no TRNC'.

assoc_actor_1: YDP: Rebirth Party; Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus)
notes: On 31 July 2019, 100-150 protesters from the Iskele district in the Karpaz peninsula supported by the Rebirth Party (YDP) rallied at the Ziyamet-Gelincik junction [coded to Famagusta], where they started marching towards Nicosia to protest over the indifference of the administration in Northern Cyprus for the problems of their region, which remains underdeveloped. When protesters reached the village of Cayirova and tried to reach the hotels' area because of a fainting protester, they were intercepted by police.

assoc_actor_2: ELAM: National Peoples Front; Military Forces of Cyprus (2013-2023)
notes: On 31 July 2019, unidentified assailants riding a large motorcycle without a license plate attempted to murder an ELAM councillor of Limassol and staff member of the National Guard, who was previously investigated by police on bombing related cases. He was shot in the back once and the gun was jammed during the second shot. His life was saved, but he became paraplegic.

assoc_actor_1: Cyprus Green Party; EDEK: Movement for Social Democracy; ELAM: National Peoples Front; Movement for the Right to Housing
notes: On 29 July 2019, protesters against foreclosures, who rallied outside parliament while the issue was being discussed in the House of Representatives demanding amendments to the law, reported that police pushed them away because they wanted to continue protesting during the scheduled visit of the Greek Prime Minister, who was visiting Cyprus. The protesters were supported by the Movement for the Right to Housing, the Cyprus Green Party, EDEK and ELAM. A disabled man was reportedly hit and a member of the Green party fainted.
On 25 July 2019, young Turkish-Cypriots who are members of the Nicosia Folklore Association marched in northern Nicosia to protest over the high number of deaths due to traffic accidents.

On 25 July 2019, the movement Independence Road protested in front of the Prime Ministry in northern Nicosia against the financial protocol and education agreement between the administration of Northern Cyprus and the Republic of Turkey. Turkish Cypriots, who are secular, perceive this protocol as forced Islamisation and favouritism over Turkish migrant settlers.

Movement of forces: On 25 July 2019, the Prime Minister and the Foreign Minister of Northern Cyprus accompanied by Turkish military and a team of experts entered Varosha, the 'ghost town' of Famagusta, to inspect the area ahead of resettlement plans under Turkish Cypriot administration, which are against UN resolutions and continuous efforts of the legitimate citizens of Famagusta to return to their city.

On 25 July 2019, for the second week in a row, the community leader of Argaka accompanied by locals obstructed international experts from placing special aluminum cages above nests to protect turtle eggs and hatchlings from foxes at Argaka beach. The environmentalists complained that police is siding with the locals who construct illegal beach bars and place sun-beds and umbrellas in protected beaches.

On 23 July 2019, around 50 people at the Menogeia Immigration Detention center in Larnaca protested over 'a corrupted system' of the immigration department, claiming they are detained unjustly without being given a satisfactory reason. They also complained that they are being served the same food daily and went on hunger strike.

assoc_actor_1: Labor Group (Cyprus); PEO: Pancyprian Federation of Labour; SEK: Cyprus Workers Confederation
notes: On 23 July 2019, the 16 staff at a home for the elderly in Larnaca supported by their unions Pancyprian Federation of Labour (PEO) and Cyprus Workers Confederation (SEK) protested over the lack of staff and security in their facility, which previously hosted only 10 elderly people and now it accommodates another 40 unaccompanied minors due to lack of space in migrant facilities.

On 23 July 2019, as announced by Turkish Defence Ministry, Turkey's drillships near the coast of Pafos are being constantly monitored by the Turkish military navy with the use of Bayraktar TB-2 type drones, helicopters and airplane of the Turkish port authority, and by submarines and corvette warships at sea. This was after Turkey's Foreign Minister stated that no further energy exploration or drilling ships would be needed in the eastern Mediterranean in a conciliatory move ahead of the first meeting in six months between the Turkish and Greek Cypriot leaders in August.

On 19 July 2019, the Head of Argaka municipality and local residents protested at Argaka beach, which is within the Natura 2000 Network area, against a group of international experts who were licensed by the Department for Fisheries and Marine Research to place special cages for the protection of turtle eggs on the beach. The residents of Argaka tried to prevent the cage placement and demanded to see the turtle eggs. Police was called and the protesters were removed from the beach. The Head of Argaka municipality questioned the existence of turtle eggs and claimed the programme was launched under false pretenses.

assoc_actor_1: Kurdish Ethnic Group (Cyprus); Cyprus Green Party
notes: On 13 July 2019, members of the Kurdistan Cultural Centre Theofilos and other supporters including members of the Green movement gathered at Larnaca court in solidarity with a Kurdish recognised refugee and resident of Cyprus on the day the court would decide after lengthy procedures whether to extradite him to Germany on 'terrorist' charges after the latter issued an international arrest warrant. The verdict was that he was being targeted for his political beliefs and he was set free.
On 12 July 2019, members of the Pancyprian Federation of Labour rallied in Limassol to protest against the fourth labour accident this year that resulted in a worker's death.

As reported on 11 July, a Turkish Cypriot bus driver was attacked by Greek Cypriot drivers with stones and water bottles when he was collecting 25 tourists from Hungary that were staying in the north of the island. He was then chased out of the airport. The incident gained prominence when the Turkish Cypriot president brought it to the attention of the Greek Cypriot President through the UN representative and an investigation was launched through the bicommunal crime committee. The Greek Cypriot account of events differs.

Non-violent activity: On 11 July 2019, the Turkish Cypriot administration deported by boat to Turkey 51 Syrian refugees including a pregnant woman and four children, who were staying at an abandoned building in Ercan airport [coded to Nicosia], which Greek Cypriots refer to as the illegal Tymbou airport, in Northern Cyprus.

On 10 July 2019, members of the Movement Against Foreclosures prevented the foreclosure of three homes in Larnaca by creating a human chain around the residences and preventing with their presence bidders to enter the properties.

source: Greek Reporter; Ekathimerini; Philenews; The National Herald
notes: On 8 July 2019, Yavuz, a second drillship for exploration of gas and oil positioned itself 20km south of the coast of Cape Apostolos Andreas in Karpasia (Karpaz) peninsula in the territorial waters of Cyprus. It is accompanied by two supporting ships and a warship. Yavuz is also supported by TB2 army drones. This triggered a strong response from the internationally recognised Republic of Cyprus supported by the newly elected Greek government, the US, Russia and Egypt. The EU issued a series of warnings to Turkey and by the end of the week all 28 member states agreed on a draft of sanctions against Turkey, which Cyprus considers to be soft.

source: AP; Philenews; Ekathimerini; Cyprus News Agency
notes: Non-violent activity: On 5 July 2019, a Turkish military submarine reported to be protecting the two Turkish drillships and the research ship Barbaros anchored at Kyrenia in Northern Cyprus. The Cyprus Defence Minister said this is an unrelated event and there is no need for alarm. In the meantime, Turkey announced that the second drillship Yavuz will be deployed in the Karpaz peninsula in Northern Cyprus the following week despite a statement by the Cyprus Defence Minister that the same procedure as with Fatih will be followed and international arrest warrants will be issued against companies cooperating with the state-owned Turkish petroleum company.

assoc_actor_1: AKEL: Progressive Party of Working People; DISY: Democratic Rally
notes: On 5 July 2019, residents of Mammari and the surrounding area in the outskirts of Nicosia protested against the 'unbearable smell' of livestock and chicken farms in close proximity to their homes. Representatives of political parties AKEL and DISY were present at the protest.

source: To Vima; The National Herald; Philenews; Ekathimerini; Cyprus News Agency
notes: On 3 July 2019, Turkey transported 42 German Leopard-2A4 tanks along with their ammunition from Turkey's First Army in the Evros region to Kythrea in Northern Cyprus. This violates the ban by Germany and the US forbidding the transfer to Cyprus of weapons systems that they have constructed. The next day the Turkish President and the Turkish FM made statements threatening the use of force. The President of Cyprus called for Turkey to respect international law and for a sense of conciliation to prevail so that once tensions have come to an end, a resumption of negotiations will be possible.

Non-violent activity: On 2 July 2019, the prime minister of Turkish-occupied Northern Cyprus announced that considering the current situation in the Eastern Mediterranean, Varosha, the southern quarter of Famagusta, will not be part of the Confidence Building Measures any more and it will be opened for settlement, despite the fact that it is protected by a 1984 UN Security Council resolution according to which the empty town can only be resettled by its original mostly Greek Cypriot inhabitants. The announcement signals further deterioration of Cyprus-Turkish relations in the context of an escalating drilling dispute off the Cyprus coast.

assoc_actor_1: AKEL: Progressive Party of Working People; Citizens Alliance; Cyprus Green Party; DISY: Democratic Rally; Government of Cyprus (2013-2023); Journalists (Cyprus); Women (Cyprus)
notes: On 2 July 2019, hundreds of men and women rallied outside police headquarters in Nicosia holding black banners with the slogan 'Not One Less' to protest against domestic violence and the recent killings of women. They placed 39 red shoes on the pavement, a symbolic number, one for every woman killed by their husbands or ex-husbands since 2000, as well as the number of calls the helpline receives daily. Members of the Green Party, AKEL, DISY, Citizens Alliance, the Union of Cyprus' Journalists and the government council Voice also participated.

source: AP; Haravgi; Ekathimerini; To Vima; Philenews
notes: On 1 July 2019, early in the morning a stray S-200 Russian-made Syrian missile struck the mountain village of Vouno (Tashkent) in Northern Cyprus starting a fire. The accidental incident occurred during military operations in the Middle East between Israel and Syria more than 300km away. The explosion was thought to have occurred before impact because there were no craters, and debris was found at several different points. Police cordoned off the main debris field and some homes were evacuated. No injuries were reported and there were no toxic emissions.

On 1 July 2019, dialysis patients supported by their local MPs protested outside Pafos hospital against serious problems facing the renal unit, which they claim is operating against EU health standards. The protesters demanded the government overcomes bureaucratic delays and speeds up the construction of the new unit.

On 29 June 2019, tension in the Eastern Mediterranean and the Aegean continued with Turkey sending a second drillship to Cyprus for the exploration of oil and gas. The drillship Yavuz set off for the Karpaz peninsula in Northern Cyprus. Cyprus issued a Navtex for military exercises in the area using real fire as a response to this move and to a similar Navtex by Turkey. In the meantime, Turkey has also been violating Greek and Cyprus airspace more often than usual and the USA Senate voted overwhelmingly in favour of the East Med Act reforming their geopolitical strategy in the area including lifting the arms sales embargo on Cyprus and monitoring Turkish violations in Cyprus' exclusive economic zone.

On 28 June 2019, after the recent incidents regarding Varosha hundreds of people rallied outside the presidential palace in Nicosia waving flags with the word 'peace' in both Greek and Turkish to protest for the need for Famagusta to return to the forefront of discussions of the UN Security Council and for the return to the negotiating table and reunification of the island. Members of ultranationalist ELAM attempted to replace the protesters' banner with one of their own creating a disruption but they were pushed away.

source: Cyprus Mail; Ekathimerini; Greek Reporter; Philenews
notes: Non-violent activity: On 18 June 2019, amid tension in the Eastern Mediterranean and on the same day as the EU General Affairs Council meeting deciding to draw up measures against Turkey for its drilling activities, the administration in the Turkish-occupied northern part of Cyprus decided to open Varosha, the southern quarter of Famagusta, for settlement, although it is protected by a 1984 UN Security Council resolution, stating that the empty town can only be resettled by its original inhabitants. On 21 June the administration of Northern Cyprus said it never spoke of opening Varosha, only of cataloguing the condition of properties.

source: AP; Cyprus News Agency; Detay; Ekathimerini; Greek Reporter; Philenews
notes: On 14 June 2019, the FM of Turkey confirmed the Turkish drilling vessel Fatih had started drilling for oil and gas 'right in the west of Cyprus' and that Turkey would be sending a second vessel. The previous day Cypriot officials had confirmed that Cyprus had issued arrest warrants against companies, company executives and crew who are involved in the operations of the Fatih. International crew withdrew. Ankara said Nicosia 'crossed a line' and they would give 'the necessary response', if Fatih employees are arrested.

On 5 June 2019, about 250 members of the Bondholders' Association rallied at the roundabout outside of the Presidential Palace in Nicosia blocking traffic to demonstrate against the government and demand compensation. There was unrest when a police officer suggested they move on from the road for their safety.

On 5 June 2019, shop owners of a central street in Nicosia about to be pedestrianised protested against this by rallying at the street, although 3,000 citizens signed a petition supporting the pedestrianisation plans. The city council voted for the street to remain pedestrian.

assoc_actor_1: Movement for the Right to Housing
notes: On 5 June 2019, members of the Movement for the Right to Housing rallied in Limassol unfurling a large banner at the Germasogeia roundabout with the slogan 'Limassol, the city of homeless people' to protest for the rights of hundreds of citizens that cannot afford housing. The Movement protested against the government that portrays Limassol as an affluent city ignoring the social exclusion of a large part of the population and claims that they reneged on their promise for the establishment of a Homeless Centre.
