On 3 June 2019, a group of Kurdish people, also supported by members of political parties in Cyprus, rallied in front of the Larnaca district court holding flags of Cyprus, Kurdistan and of Kurdish leader Abdullah Ocalan, to protest against the arrest of a recognized Kurdish political refugee and resident of Cyprus after a Hamburg court issued an arrest warrant on alleged terrorism-related charges. He was initially arrested in April sparking protests, released briefly and arrested again on an international arrest warrant.
On 1 June 2019, residents of Kato Moni protested against the illegal expansion of a nearby abattoir, which they believe is responsible for the increased number of cancer cases in their village.

Movement of forces: On 31 May 2019, military forces of Northern Cyprus entered the buffer zone at the Greek Cypriot village of Deneia and blocked the way with two military vehicles, while accompanying settlers in North Cyprus from Turkey, who came in with agricultural machines and harvested the wheat crops of Greek Cypriots. United Nations Forces arrived at the area but could not prevent the harvesting. Similar tension occurred on 16 November 2018.

On 30 May 2019, residents of Deutera and priests of a nearby Monastery protested against the building of a petrol station above the monastery cave that is of historical significance. The protesters holding banners and shouting slogans blocked traffic in front of the land where the petrol station is to be built by resting a coffin in the middle of the road.

assoc_actor_1: AKEL: Progressive Party of Working People; DIKO: Democratic Party; ELAM: National Peoples Front
notes: On 29 May 2019, members of the Movement Against Foreclosures formed a human block in front of a property in Larnaca belonging to three families preventing prospective buyers from entering to protest against a law they believe is facilitating aggressive foreclosures. At the same time, members of parliament and members of political parties AKEL, DIKO, ELAM and other citizens rallied in protest over the same issue outside the offices of the foreclosures organisation in central Larnaca.

On 19 May 2019, three Nigerian nationals were arrested in Nicosia for the killing in the early hours of the morning of an asylum seeker from Cameroon when he went to a night club frequented by migrants. He was stabbed with a broken wine bottle and he bled to death. Contrary to the initial impression that it was a drug related crime, it was revealed that the Nigerians did not want other nationalities in what they perceived as their own area. One of the three confessed.

As reported on 17 May, a group of gay people were targeted outside a bakery because of their sexual orientation. The unidentified assailants hurled insults at them and punched them. The victims reported that police was unhelpful. The event was highlighted on the occasion of the International Day Against Homophobia, Transphobia and Biphobia.

On 16 May 2019, tens of Pafos citizens rallied in front of the central branch of the Bank of Cyprus to protest against foreclosures and unfair bank charges accusing also the state and Parliament of doing the banks' bidding. The demonstrators shouted slogans and threw eggs at the entrance of the Pafos branch.

On 13 May 2019, around 100 public service contract workers marched from the finance ministry to the presidential palace in Nicosia as part of their 48 hour strike to protest for getting the same treatment as their colleagues with permanent posts according to EU law. Two more days of action followed with a march preceded by motorcycles and protesters using drums and bullhorns, and holding placards and banners and hundreds of protesters rallying in front of the presidential palace.

On 12 May 2019, women part of the Mothers Rise Up campaign in Cyprus marched from the House of Representatives to the Presidential Palace in Nicosia to protest against climate change. Similar events inspired by the students' movement were held internationally.
On 12 May 2019, residents of Dali, which is surrounded by five industrial areas, protested against air pollution in their area because of the unbearable smells.

On 9 May 2019, scouts, elementary school students and their marching band, organised by the Traffic Accident Prevention Association marched in Iskele (Trikomo) in North Cyprus [coded to Famagusta] with the slogan 'Notice Me in Traffic' to protest against drink driving and other traffic violations.

On 8 May 2019, employees of Citizen Service Centres supported by trade union Isotita (Equality) in combination with a country-wide strike rallied in front of the finance and trade ministries in Nicosia, while those in other towns gathered outside the citizen service centres, to protest for the government to comply with the EU directive on fixed-term employment. This calls for equal treatment of contract staff with the comparable permanent staff that perform the same or similar duties.

On 7 May 2019, scouts, elementary school students and their marching band, organised by the Traffic Accident Prevention Association marched for the first time in Kyrenia with the slogan 'Notice Me in Traffic'.

On 5 May 2019, a memorial and solidarity march with the migrant communities of Cyprus was organised in Limassol by the collective Spirithkia to protest against 'the racist face of Cyprus society' in the aftermath of a series of killings of female migrant workers by a captain of the National Guard. In the march participated members of the Filipino community of Cyprus and other migrants.

On 3 May 2019, Youth for Climate Cyprus organised a silent protest in front of Parliament with the slogan 'Do you drink water? Do you breathe air? Then this is of immediate concern to you'. The young protesters had covered their mouths with ribbons reading 'Help Me'. Other citizens also protested against climate change in front of the Ministry of Agriculture and against the President of the Parliament, who did not allow them to protest in front of the Parliament building.

assoc_actor_1: AKEL: Progressive Party of Working People; Women (Cyprus)
notes: On 3 May 2019, a protest event titled 'Protest for the ignored women' took place in front of the presidential palace in Nicosia for the victims of the captain of the Cyprus National Guard. Political party AKEL referred to institutional racism and sexism.

On 3 May 2019, the government of Turkey announced that the Turkish drill Fatih will start exploratory drilling for oil and gas 40 nautical miles off the coast of Pegeia, Pafos, in the Exclusive Economic Zone of Cyprus setting in motion a chain of diplomatic reactions. All 28 EU foreign ministers confirmed their support for Cyprus calling Turkey to refrain from illegal action. In addition to EU member states, USA, Russia, China and Egypt also expressed their support. Ten days later Ankara announced they will be sending the drill ship Yavuz to join the Fatih off the coast of Cyprus. No actual drilling has occurred yet.

assoc_actor_1: Filipino Group (Cyprus); Labor Group (Cyprus); PEO: Pancyprian Federation of Labour; Women (Cyprus)
notes: On 1 May 2019, after the recent killings of Filipino women by a captain of the Cyprus National Guard, women from the Philippines working in Cyprus participated en masse at the Labour Day march in Limassol organised by the Pancyprian Federation of Labour (PEO).

assoc_actor_1: Filipino Group (Cyprus); Government of Cyprus (2013-2023); Journalists (Cyprus); Women (International)
notes: On 26 April 2019, hundreds to 1,000 people of all ages and nationalities including politicians, artists, journalists, members of Filipino organisations, rallied in front of the presidential palace in Nicosia for a protest vigil to mourn 5 women and 2 girls who according to the police were killed by a captain of the National Guard that confessed. The protesters questioned the way police handled the disappearance of migrant women workers, mostly Filipinos, and decried 'sexist, misogynist and racist' attitudes. A group of Filipino women held prayers.

assoc_actor_1: Kurdish Ethnic Group (Cyprus); Cyprus Green Party; AKEL: Progressive Party of Working People; EDEK: Movement for Social Democracy
notes: On 24 April 2019, members of the Kurdistan Cultural Centre Theophilos supported by the Cyprus Green Party, AKEL and EDEK, protested once more against the arrest of a recognised Kurdish political refugee and resident of Cyprus after Germany issued a European arrest warrant on alleged terrorism-related charges. The protesters gathered in front of the Larnaca district court holding Cyprus flags, a photograph of Kurdish leader Abdullah Ocalan and banners reading among other slogans 'Europe fulfil your democratic values'.

assoc_actor_1: ELAM: National Peoples Front; Government of Cyprus (2013-2023); Greek Ethnic Group (Cyprus); Labor Group (Cyprus)
notes: On 23 April 2019, 70 Greek Cypriots - originally from the north of Cyprus and former managers of a Larnaca estate that originally belonged to Turkish Cypriots - rallied in front of the estate holding banners and briefly raising a Turkish flag as a protest against the Ministry of Interior and the Guardian of Turkish Cypriot property, which ruled that they were trespassing and using the estate illegally. A city councillor of Larnaca and members of ELAM supported the rally.

assoc_actor_1: Greek Ethnic Group (Cyprus); Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus); AKEL: Progressive Party of Working People; Cyprus Green Party; YKP: New Cyprus Party; BKP: United Cyprus Party; KSP: Cyprus Socialist Party; PEO: Pancyprian Federation of Labour; Teachers (Cyprus); EDON: United Democratic Youth Organisation; POGO: Womens Movement; Pancyprian Peace Council
notes: On 22 April 2019, Greek and Turkish Cypriots protested in Nicosia against plans for a nuclear plant in Akkuyu, Turkey, opposite Kyrenia. Members of AKEL, Cyprus Green Party, YKP, BKP, KSP, PEO, the Association of Cyprus Turkish Teachers, EDON, Women's Movement POGO and members of the Pancyprian Peace Council held each other forming a human chain and read a common statement against nuclear power both in Greek and in Turkish. Many were wearing yellow vests.

On 16 April 2019, asylum seekers protested in Nicosia for more rights and opportunities regarding their employment status. They marched from the Ministry of Labour to the European Union House and then rallied in front of the Parliament of Cyprus.

On 15 April 2019, two camps of protesters holding banners and placards rallied in front of the Municipal Hall of Pafos during the city council's meeting regarding the erection of a church cathedral in the Municipal Gardens. Unlike supporters of the Metropolitan Church, citizens' groups ask that the gardens remain a green space. The city council had previously decided against this motion on 22 March and 4 April but after lobbying by church groups and city councillors the decision was overturned.

assoc_actor_1: Cyprus Green Party; Government of Cyprus (2013-2023); Orthodox Christian Group (Cyprus)
notes: On 14 April 2019, the Initiative Group of Pyrga-Kornos and the Friends of the Stavrovouni Monastery rallied in front of the Presidential Palace holding banners and shouting slogans to protest against the building of a new factory for the production and recycling of asphalt in their area near a protected NATURA 2000 forest. They were joined by their MPs, MEPs, municipal authorities, mayors, representatives of political parties and green organisations. There were allegations that President Anastasiades attempted to 'buy out' the environmental activists.

On 12 April 2019, members of the Initiative for Saving the Natural Coastline and members of the movement Save Akamas/Save Cyprus protested outside the Department for the Environment in Nicosia. The protest took place a day after a decision was announced allowing building on the coastline at a distance shorter than 100 meters from the sea in the natural habitat of the Mediterranean seal Monachus Monachus, which is an endangered species.

On 9 April 2019, residents of Orounta in the district of Nicosia managed to break through a police cordon and prevent employees of a mobile phone company to install a mobile phone mast in their village.

On 7 April 2019, 6-7 activists protested against animal torture in Nicosia. They protested at a main city street wearing animal masks and lay on sheets full of 'blood' while animal cries could be heard through speakers.

On 7 April 2019, four asylum seekers from Cameroon, Nigeria, Egypt and Turkey hosted at the Menogeia reception center demonstrated demanding to be released. The demonstrators kicked plastic bins and threw garbage on the walls, they overturned garbage bins in the hallway and in the restaurant, and one of them broke a wall frame and started shouting in the corridor. The reception center manager with the help of the Head of the Immigration Office and Larnaca police negotiators managed to calm them down.
On 4 April 2019, Limassol public transport bus drivers (EMEL) and their unions PEO and SEK protested all day outside the transport and labour ministries over non-payment of wages and benefits.

On 3 April 2019, members of the Turkish Cypriot Secondary Education Teachers' Union (KTOEOS) participated at a sit-in protest in front of the Public Service Commission in Nicosia to draw attention to the lack of teacher job vacancies in Northern Cyprus.

On 2 April 2019, the ultra-nationalist political party National People's Front (ELAM) reported that their offices in Nicosia were attacked by an unidentified group of people , who wrote slogans on the walls and caused material damages.

assoc_actor_1: Kurdish Ethnic Group (Cyprus); Cyprus Green Party
notes: On 2 April 2019, in Larnaca, members of the Kurdistan Cultural Centre Theophilos supported by the Green Party MP , protested against the arrest of a recognised Kurdish political refugee and resident of Cyprus after Germany issued a European arrest warrant on alleged terrorism-related charges.

assoc_actor_1: AKEL: Progressive Party of Working People; Citizens Alliance; Cyprus Green Party; DIKO: Democratic Party; EDEK: Movement for Social Democracy; Farmers (Cyprus); Labor Group (Cyprus); Police Forces of Cyprus (2013-2023); Students (Cyprus); Teachers (Cyprus)
notes: On 27 March 2019, 2,000-4,000 people in Nicosia marched under the sound of music with five tractors leading the way to the presidential palace to protest the closure of the Cooperative Bank of Cyprus. The march was organised by farmers' unions, teachers' unions and the Cyprus Police Association. The protest was also supported by the Union of Cyprus Pensioners (EKYSY), the student union (PSEM), taxi drivers, and political parties AKEL, DIKO, EDEK, Citizens Alliance and the Cyprus Green Party.
Property destruction: On 25 March 2019, on Greek Independence Day, unidentified perpetrators set fire to an abandoned Turkish Cypriot house in the village of Kofinou.

On 24 March 2019, 6-7 activists protested against animal torture in Nicosia. They protested at a main city street wearing animal masks and lay on sheets full of 'blood' while animal cries could be heard through speakers.

assoc_actor_1: AKEL: Progressive Party of Working People
notes: On 23 March 2019, AKEL organised an anti-fascist and anti-racist march in Nicosia for 'the rights of every human to life and to dignity' on the occasion of the International Day for the Elimination of Racial Discrimination.

assoc_actor_1: AKEL: Progressive Party of Working People; Government of Cyprus (2013-2023); Protesters (International)
notes: On 23 March 2019, the Municipal Committee of AKEL organised an anti-fascist and anti-racist rally at Finikoudes in Larnaca. The Municipal Secretary was the main speaker and a representative of the Russian Cultural Centre also gave a speech. A Bulgarian dance group and Palestinians that read poetry participated at the event and children drew paintings with anti-racist themes.

On 22 March 2019, citizens' groups in Pafos protested against the erection of a church cathedral in the Municipal Gardens. They gathered in front of the Municipal Hall during the city council's meeting. The council voted against this motion.

On 19 March 2019, restaurant owners of Lady's Mile beach supported by the municipal authorities of west Limassol, MPs of Limassol and representatives of political parties, protested at the Limassol roundabout over the lack of road maintenance and over general lack of infrastructure.

assoc_actor_1: AKEL: Progressive Party of Working People
notes: On 18 March 2019, AKEL organised a march in the city of Limassol to protest against what they refer to as the 'sell-out of the Cooperative Bank' by the government.

On 15 March 2019, a group of asylum seekers from Iraq - among them families with young children - had already been camping for more than a week on Makariou Avenue in Nicosia to protest against the rejections of their asylum applications.

On 15 March 2019, students and young people in Cyprus protested against climate change in front of the House of Representatives in Nicosia in an international event that was simultaneous in 40 countries and was inspired by the international student movement Climate Strike.

On 15 March 2019, women refugees from Somalia protested in front of the Ministry of Interior in Nicosia against systematic racism, gender-based violence and degrading treatment. They also reported to KISA that they suffer discrimination based on their colour, religion and residence status in all aspects of their lives.

On 15 March 2019, driving examiners in Limassol rallied for two hours outside the Road Transport Department offices to protest against understaffing which means that candidates wait for up to five months to take a test.

Property destruction: On 11 March 2019, unknown perpetrators set fire to the desks in the offices of the Nationalist Liberation Movement (EAK) in Limassol. The fire was deliberate as police found flammable material.

On 8 March 2019, residents of Nicosia holding placards with the slogans 'are we a European capital?' and 'listen to your constituents, not big interests' organised a protest in favour of a main street remaining pedestrian during the City Council's meeting to deliberate on this issue. The protesters had already presented to the Mayor of Nicosia a petition with 3,000 signatures.

On 7 March 2019, during the traditional carnival parade in Limassol members of the Initiative of Active Citizens of Limassol against High Rise Buildings protested against the government's policy to give licenses for the erection of high rises on Limassol beach.

On 28 February 2019, on their second day of action, Turkish Cypriot farmers protesting for subsidies for the prices of barley and milk, and being prevented by police from entering Nicosia, started spilling tens of liters of milk rather than 'giving it to the state for free'. The farmers accused the state of denying them their democratic right to protest.

On 27 February 2019, Turkish Cypriot farmers protesting on their tractors attempted to reach the TRNC Ministry of Agriculture and Natural Resources in Nicosia to request subsidies for the prices of barley and milk, but police prevented them from entering the city.

assoc_actor_1: AKEL: Progressive Party of Working People; EDEK: Movement for Social Democracy; DIKO: Democratic Party; Cyprus Green Party; APC: Animal Party Cyprus
notes: On Feb. 16 2019, in Limassol, the 'Movement for the Right to Housing', supported by AKEL: Progressive Party of Working People, EDEK: Movement for Social Democracy, DIKO: Democratic Party, Cyprus Green Party, APC: Animal Party Cyprus protested against the lack of sufficient measures to help vulnerable groups, to raise awareness over problems faced by the homeless and people with serious financial problems and aiming 'to finally restore dignity to people'.

On Feb. 15 2019, members of the Movement for the Right to Housing and their supporters protested against 'the continuing indifference of the government and of the local authorities' regarding the issue of homelessness and also intending to raise public awareness by setting up their tents in front of the District Administration building and getting ready to spend the night there.

On Feb. 15 2019, about 30 Kurdish Cyprus residents and members of the Cultural Centre of Kurdistan 'Theofilos' participated in a protest march on the 20th anniversary of the imprisonment of their political leader by Turkish authorities. The protesters stopped at the Ministry of Interior before moving on to the Greek embassy, where they laid a black wreath as an indication of mourning, and making a final stop at Parliament, where they also highlighted the case of an imprisoned female Kurdish MP on a hunger strike.

On Feb. 12 2019, in Nicosia, members of the Pancyprian Peace Council protested in front of the United States embassy against what the Council's General Secretary called 'the coup in Venezuela'. He also turned against the European Union for 'hypocrisy and tolerating authoritarian allies in the Arab Gulf'.

On 11 February 2019, in northern Nicosia, the President of the Cyprus Turkish Secondary Education Teachers' Union (KTOEOS) joined in protest the KTOEOS Action Committee, which consisted of some members of the board of directors and a group of teachers who were victims of the Cyprus immigration law, wearing black T-shirts with the slogan 'Stop the Immigration Law' at the General Assembly of the TRNC. When the Parliament proceedings started the protesters were removed from the premises.

On Feb. 7 2019, in Nicosia, thousands of Cypriot pupils with the support of teachers' organisations and trade unions protested holding banners and shouting slogans in front of the Ministry of Education against a proposed exam system. University students also participated demanding an increase of state student support.

On Feb. 7 2019, in Nicosia, the PanCyprian Group against Injustice and Inflation and the Gilets Jaunes of Cyprus rallied in front of the Parliament with banners proclaiming 'GRECO we are sorry you came all this way to clean their mess' referring to the Group of States against Corruption (GRECO) of the Council of Europe visiting Cyprus regarding the crisis related to the Cypriot justice system.

On Feb. 6 2019, in Nicosia, there was a demonstration in front of the Parliament by local initiative groups against the decision of the Department for the Environment to approve the building of a new factory for the production and recycling of asphalt at Stavrovouni.

source: Cyprus News Agency; To Vima; Ekathimerini; Haravgi; Philenews; Cyprus Mail
notes: On Feb. 1 2019, Turkish military forces moved their positions even further in the buffer zone blocking the way of the Greek Cypriot community of Strovilia in what the United Nations describe as permanent violations of the status quo. The UN force in Cyprus liaised with both sides to reduce tension. Part of Strovilia resides in the British RAF Base of Ayios Nikolaos. The British High Commission replaced the Turkish barrier with their own and said it is meant to prevent smuggling.

assoc_actor_1: Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus); Former Military Forces of Northern Cyprus (2015-2020); YDP: Rebirth Party
notes: On 1 February 2019, members of the Turkish Peace Forces (TBK) Veterans Association gathered in front of Turkey's Embassy in Nicosia to read a statement against the comments made by the Turkish Cypriot Teachers' Union (KTOS) during a visit the previous week of Turkey's Foreign Minister. The leader of the Rebirth Party also came to support TBK and warned KTOS to change its attitude.

On Jan. 29 2019, Cyprus Police organised a large security operation for the protection of the MED 7 meeting participating the Mediterranean countries of the European south (France, Italy, Greece, Spain, Portugal, Malta and Cyprus). More than 800 police officers were deployed in Nicosia with the Anti-Terrorist Team taking the lead. All the major roads were blocked. Port and Navy Police were also mobilised and helicopters and drones were used. There were security measures in Larnaca airport as well.

assoc_actor_1: EDON: United Democratic Youth Organisation; Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus); AKEL: Progressive Party of Working People
notes: On Jan. 28 2019, hundreds of Greek and Turkish Cypriots participated in the anti-imperialist march outside the British bases in Troodos to protest for a Federation of Cyprus as the only solution for reunification. The march followed by an excursion was organised by EDON, the political youth wing of AKEL. The General Secretary of AKEL hailed this annual gathering on its 60th year and the General Secretary of EDON said this is the answer against nationalism on both sides, as well as against Turkey and American and NATO imperialism, who all aim to establish themselves in the area indefinitely.

assoc_actor_1: Cyprus Green Party; Government of Cyprus (2013-2023); Orthodox Christian Group (Cyprus)
notes: On Jan. 26 2019, 700 hundred residents of the villages Pseudas, Kornos, Pyrga supported by local government marched in the main road in Kornos holding banners and wearing surgical masks to protest against the building of a new factory for the production and recycling of asphalt. The MP of The Movement of Ecologists - Citizens' Cooperation commented that factories should not be built in forest areas, particularly this one that is the only green space near Larnaca. The monastic community of Stavrovounio also objects to the factory plans.

On Jan. 18 2019, the Conscientious Objection Initiative organised a demonstration in front of Central Prison in Nicosia, TRNC, in support of the Turkish Cypriot poet that was imprisoned for refusing to go to the army on ideological grounds, as well as refusing to pay the fine. The Writers' Union also supported the Initiative. The protest took place while the military court was deliberating on the conscientious objector's appeal. They decided to reduce his sentence from 20 days to three and set him free for the time being.

On Jan. 17 2019, a trade union platform consisting of Turkish Cypriot hotel employees and employees of a historical hotel of Greek Cypriot ownership in Kyrenia protested asking for a renewal of their contract that expired in May. On the same day, the National Unity Party counter-protested for invitations to tender regarding the management of the hotel and not just renewing the previous contract.

On Jan. 16 2019, the Organising Committee for Greece Avenue called residents and business owners of Greece Avenue in Pafos to protest one more time against the construction of a traffic island dividing the Avenue as part of the urban planning that will regenerate the area. They believe it will affect commerce in the area and create traffic problems. Protesters demonstrated outside Pafos City Hall, where the majority of City Council members voted against the construction of the traffic island, however, the final decision lies with the relevant government departments.

assoc_actor_1: Orthodox Christian Group (Cyprus); AKEL: Progressive Party of Working People; DIKO: Democratic Party; EDEK: Movement for Social Democracy; Labor Group (Cyprus); Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus)
notes: On Jan. 16 2019, the People's Initiative for retaining the Municipality status of Geroskipou organised a rally at the 2nd Primary School of Geroskipou to protest for their municipality to keep its administrative independence and not be unified with Pafos. The rally was also attended by the Pafos Metropolitis Georgios, political parties AKEL, DIKO, EDEK, the small businesses group 'Movement for saving Pafos', a representative of Geroskipou Emigrants and a solidarity message was read by the Turkish Cypriot residents of Geroskipou.

On 12 January 2019, a peaceful, artistic demonstration on veganism and animal cruelty organised by the newly created Cyprus-based team of global street activists Anonymous for the Voiceless (AV) took place in Nicosia. The demonstration, called A Cube of Truth, aims to trigger public interest through a combination of local standard-practice animal exploitation footage and conversation. This is one of the simultaneous events taking place in Melbourne, Seoul, Darmstadt, Bangkok and other international cities.

On Jan. 9 2019, the Cultural Centre of Kurdistan 'Theofilos', organised a march of the Kurdish people who live in Cyprus to bring attention to the killing of three Kurdish fighters in Paris in 2013, gathering in front of the Ministry of Interior, moving on to the French Embassy and then the offices of the European Union, in order to meet officials and present their case, as well as to highlight their concerns about a Turkish invasion in Syria and ask for an EU intervention.

On 28 December 2018, the 9th day that 30 employees of the liquidated CAS company are on hunger strike at the entrance of Ercan (Tymbou) Airport to protest about their 6-month unpaid salaries and that they did not receive compensation, two of the CAS employees climbed on a meter board at Ercan (Tymbou) Airport in north Nicosia causing the mobilization of police, civil defense, fire brigade and ambulance crews that were dispatched to the area. The day before they had climbed on a billboard but were persuaded by family and friends to come down.

assoc_actor_1: Health Workers (Cyprus); Labor Group (Cyprus); Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus)
notes: On 24 December 2018, in a joint statement 3 Cyprus Turkish medical associations called for a solution after 4 hunger strikers were admitted at the Nicosia State Hospital Intensive Care Unit - one of them not accepting any liquids. This is the 5th day that employees of the liquidated CAS company are on hunger strike at the entrance of Ercan (Tymbou) Airport to protest about their 6-month unpaid salaries and that they did not receive compensation.

On 20 December 2018, 30 employees of the liquidated CAS company began a hunger strike at the entrance of Ercan (Tymbou) Airport in north Nicosia to protest about their 6-month unpaid salaries and that they did not receive compensation. Their spokesperson said that the number of hunger strikers will rise.

Explosive remnants of war: On 15 December 2018, a 13-year-old boy was killed in Morphou in Northern Cyprus after a Turkish army projectile that remained dormant since the invasion exploded when he touched it. The boy's family is originally from Kyrgyzstan.
On Dec. 2, 2018: A group of Greek Cypriots held a demonstration at Dherinya checkpoint, Famagusta, in opposition to opening the border gates.
On Dec. 2, 2018: Citizens gathered outside the presidential palace in Nicosia to protest against the high rents in the country and the low living standards.
On Nov. 25, 2018: Citizens protested in Nicosia opposing violence against women to mark the International Day for Elimination of Violence against Women.

On Nov. 20, 2018: Hotel workers held a mass protest outside the finance ministry in Nicosia over a bill for parliament discussion, which aimed to abolish the obligation of employers to hire a minimum number of employees in all departments.
On Nov. 15, 2018: Citizens in Pafos protested the 35th anniversary of the Unilateral Declaration of Independence (UDI) in the north.

On 15 November 2018, students marched in central Nicosia condemning celebrations in the north on the 35th anniversary of the Unilateral Declaration of Independence by Ankara and Turkish-Cypriots in the Turkish-occupied northern part of Cyprus and protested against separatist aspirations as a solution to the Cyprus problem.
On Nov. 15, 2018: Citizens in Famagusta protested the 35th anniversary of the Unilateral Declaration of Independence (UDI) in the north.
On Nov. 15, 2018: Citizens in Larnaca protested the 35th anniversary of the Unilateral Declaration of Independence (UDI) in the north.
On Nov. 15, 2018: Citizens in Limassol protested the 35th anniversary of the Unilateral Declaration of Independence (UDI) in the north.

On Nov. 12, 2018: Citizens in Cyprus demonstrated walking at the newly opened crossing point in the south-eastern village of Dherynia, Famagusta to oppose the crossing that might entrench ethnic division between Greek and Turkish Cypriots.
On Nov. 2, 2018: Two education syndicates held a demonstration outside the education ministry in Nicosia to protest the transfer of teachers from Turkey.

On Oct. 31, 2018: Two Turkish Cypriot Civil Servants Unions protested in Nicosia against the administration's decision to suspend paying cost of living adjustments to public employees and public retirees to the end of 2018.

On Oct. 30, 2018: Turkish Cypriots held a demonstration outside the interior ministry in Nicosia to protest the administration's policy on citizenship, claiming that Turkish Cypriots are becoming a minority in their homeland because of the transfer of population from the mainland and drawing attention to the rising crime rate in north Cyprus.
On Oct. 27, 2018: A Limassol action group organized a protest against the social and environmental consequences of high-rise buildings, dumping muddy water in the sea, and soaring rents in the city.

On Oct. 27, 2018: The Union of Building Contractors held a demonstration in Nicosia to protest the administration's failure to pay their dues. The protesters marched to the prime minister's office and finance ministry with 250 vehicles

assoc_actor_1: Greek Ethnic Group (Cyprus); Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus)
notes: On Oct. 25, 2018: Greek and Turkish Cypriots held a peaceful demonstration during the President's and the leader of the breakaway Turkish Cypriots, Mustafa Akinci's meeting organized by the UN peacekeeping mission in Nicosia.
On Oct. 21, 2018: Citizens in the countryside of Limassol (Saitta) protested against the abandonment of the region and demanded an improvement in their economic and social prospects.

On Oct. 17, 2018: Port workers and labour unions in Limassol went on a two-hour strike demanding better working conditions. Allegedly, the strike ended when the Labour ministry mediated with the workers.

October 8-12, 2018: About 60 Iraqi refugees protested outside the labour ministry in Nicosia, expressing their concerns about not being able to find homes and jobs. The refugees requested to be sent to the Kofinou centre where they would have better prospects.

On Oct. 12, 2018: Citizens organized a march in Nikosia in memory of Zak Kostopoulos, Greek drag performer and activist of the LGBTIQ+ and HIV positive movements, who was murdered on September 21, in Athens

On Oct. 10, 2018: Residents (Greek Cypriots) of the Morphou neighbourhood in Nicosia made a round of the embassies of the five permanent residents of the UN Security Council. They protested Turkish occupation of their town and sought help to secure a Cyprus solution.
On Oct. 1, 2018: Two Turkish Cypriot labour unions held a demonstration outside the Republican Assembly in Nicosia to protest the hiking prices and the living costs.

On Sept. 28 2018, the rural community of Lymbia (Nicosia) protested one more time in front of the Coop, the only bank in Lymbia, on the last day of its operation, against the decision by the Greek bank to close their local cooperative bank branch.
On Sept. 21, 2018: The Communal Liberation Party held a demonstration outside the Ministry of Finance in Nicosia to protest the price hikes and blamed the government for the financial crisis.

On Sept. 21, 2018: Citizens, organized in a social media group, protested outside the Presidential Palace in Nicosia against the early release of a convicted child molester due to presidential pardon.

On Sept. 19 2018, teachers on strike rallied in front of the A' Lyceum of Pafos in protest against government measures for state schools and distributed information material regarding their views on the crisis in education of the past few months.

On Sept. 19, 2018: About 30 mostly retired residents from the village of Lymbia, Nicosia protested outside the only bank in Lymbia over the decision to close their local cooperative bank branches. The protesters carried placards reading 'Don't make our life an ordeal' and '28 illiterate people founded the co-op bank in 1928, while in 2018, educated people dissolved it.'

On Sept. 19 2018, teachers on strike rallied in front of Lanitio Lyceum in Limassol in protest against the government measures for state schools and distributed information material regarding their views on the crisis in education of the past few months.

On Sept. 16, 2018: Over 500 residents of the Dromolaxia-Meneou municipality in Larnaca demonstrated against the closing down of the local cooperative bank branch. The protest was organized by the local authorities. Mayor of Dromolaxia-Meneou, Kypros Andronikou, said that the closing down of the branch would cause problems to the two communities as it used to serve more than 20,000 people.

On Sept. 15, 2018: Rural communities from the villages of Lymbia and Xylofagou, Nicosia protested outside the only bank in Lymbia over the decision to close their local cooperative bank branches, likening it to 'a second [Turkish] invasion'.

On 7 September 2018, Turkish Cypriot farmers and livestock breeders demonstrated for a third day in northern Nicosia against economic hardship and the depreciation of the Turkish lira. They tried to cross the dividing line to get support from Greek Cypriots. Turkish riot police used teargas to disperse the demonstrators and blocked access to the crossing.

assoc_actor_1: Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus); Greek Ethnic Group (Cyprus)
notes: On Sept. 6, 2018: Several hundred Turkish Cypriots demonstrated in the northern part of Nicosia against economic hardship after the slide of the Turkish lira by 40% of its value against the US dollar and the Euro. Greek Cypriots joined the demonstration in solidarity and the protesters marched in front of a building used as the seat of the ambassador of Turkey to demand an end to the control of their economy.

assoc_actor_1: BKP: United Cyprus Party; YKP: New Cyprus Party; TKP-YG: Communal Liberation Party-New Forces
notes: On 6 September 2018, about 500 citizens held a demonstration under the slogan 'March for Communal Existence' in Nicosia, chanting slogans for the establishment of a united federal structure and criticizing the imposed economic packages. The United Cyprus Party, New Cyprus Party and TKP-YG: Communal Liberation Party-New Forces were present at the demonstration.

On 6 September 2018, Turkish Cypriot farmers and livestock breeders continued their demonstrations in Nicosia against the devaluation of the Turkish lira. They drove through north Nicosia with more than 500 tractors and trucks and damaged streetlights outside the Ministry of Agriculture. Riot police intervened to prevent the demonstrators from entering the ministry.

On Sept. 5 2018, unidentified assailants caused an explosion with a makeshift device at a side building of the residence of the Mayor of Paralimini, which was used by staff. At the same time, there was a blast at a nearby beach and a connection between the two cases is being investigated.

On 5 September 2018, Turkish Cypriot farmers and livestock breeders demonstrated against the plummeting of the Turkish lira with their vehicles in northern Nicosia. Upon their arrival at the Agriculture ministry in northern Nicosia, they threw stones that broke windows and injured a police officer. The demonstrators then stormed the building and clashed with Turkish riot police.

On Sept. 4 2018, in Limassol, five youths followed a 27-year-old Syrian in front of his residence and assaulted him beating him on the face and body until his life partner and passers by intervened and the attackers fled.

assoc_actor_1: Teachers (Cyprus); Labor Group (Cyprus); Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus)
notes: On Sept. 3, 2018: A Turkish Cypriot teacher union held a demonstration outside the Republican Assembly in Nicosia against the administration's economic measures leading to depreciation of the Turkish lira and called for its replacement with the European currency.

On Sept. 2, 2018: Hundreds of animal lovers marched through a park in the Molos area of Limassol to protest against being banned to walk their dogs in the area. Protesters were discontent with the Mayor's decision to ban dogs in the Molos park, claiming they were a health hazard to the public and particularly children.

On Aug. 31, 2018: Turkish Cypriots parked their vehicles in the centre of Famagusta protesting against the depreciation of the Turkish lira and the bad effects on citizens' livelihoods. Drivers were fined for obstructing traffic.

On Aug. 31, 2018: Turkish Cypriots parked their vehicles outside Government in Nicosia protesting against the rise in fuel prices. The demonstration was organized by drivers of taxis, buses, and private cars protesting against the effects the depreciation of the Turkish lira was having on their livelihoods
On Aug. 29, 2018: Turkish Cypriot teachers held a protest outside the Turkish Cypriot assembly dissatisfied that the economic crisis had a bad effect on them.

On Aug. 28 2018, in Nicosia, more than 10,000 teachers and their supporters protested against the government's decision on measures to streamline education in state schools and shouted slogans asking for the Minister of Education to resign.

On Aug. 26, 2018: At least 100 people, organized by the Animal Party, demonstrated in Limassol after the municipality decided to ban dogs from the Molos area. Protesters said they were following regulations for their dogs' litter collection and disposal and expressed concerns if the ban would extend to blind people with guide dogs.

On Aug. 25, 2018: Limassol dog owners, supported by the Animal Party, demonstrated in Limassol after the municipality decided to ban dogs from the Molos area. Protesters said they were following regulations for their dogs' litter collection and disposal and expressed concerns if the ban would extend to blind people with guide dogs.
On Aug. 23, 2018: The Independence Road held a demonstration outside the Prime Ministry in Nicosia to protest the rising prices and the economic crisis in the country.

On Aug. 23, 2018: Thousands of teachers organized a protest march which ended up outside the presidential palace against government's education reform, which would limit teaching hour exemptions and result in hiring less teachers than previously expected.

On Aug. 21, 2018: The remains of eleven people who died in a bombing at a psychiatric hospital in Nicosia by the Turkish Air Force 44 years ago were discovered and identified. The remains would be handed over to their relatives. Cypriot authorities said other victims had been buried in a cemetery.

On Aug. 17, 2018: A Turkish Cypriot labour union placed a black wreath at the Ministry of Finance to protest Finance Minister Serdar Denktas' failure to invite the union to the talks he held with the other trade unions on financial and economic measures in Cyprus.

assoc_actor_2: Former Military Forces of Turkey (2016-); Gulen Movement
notes: Arrests: On 27 July 2018, 19 former members of the military forces of Turkey, nine women and 17 children including a 6-month baby, accused by Turkey of being part of the Gulen movement, were arrested in Kyrenia in the context of an agreement between Turkey and TRNC, while attempting to travel to Greece. The 45 Turkish citizens were held for three days before they were transferred under guard to Turkey.
On 25 July 2018, 2018: Citizens protested in Limassol, calling for the suspension of construction works on a petrol station on Dimokratias Street due to health and environmental concerns.

On 24 July 2018, in Larnaca, after a fight, a 26-year-old refugee from Iraq attacked with a sword a 32-year-old Syrian refugee. The Syrian victim sustained serious injuries on his left arm and was taken to hospital for surgery. The refugee from Iraq escaped and is now wanted by the authorities.

On 21 July 2018, 2018: Representatives of many associations gathered in the capital of Cyprus and placed a black wreath at the Prime Minister's office to protest increasing prices, including the cost of electricity.

On 19 July 2018, 2018: Socialist party EDEK organized a protest against the planned opening of a crossing point at Dherynia, Famagusta and called on government to reconsider its decision. According to EDEK, this crossing would hurt financially Greek Cypriot businesspeople living in Dherynia, given the 'unfair' competition from cheaper goods on the other side.

On 18 July 2018, 2018: A group of truck drivers disrupted the operations of the Limassol port by blocking its entrance over the introduction of a new type of entry pass. The submission of a clean criminal record certificate as a requirement for the issue of the new passes, angered the truck drivers.

assoc_actor_1: Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus); Labor Group (Cyprus); Teachers (Cyprus)
notes: On 13 July 2018, in Nicosia, members of the civil servants union KTAMS with the support of the Turkish Cypriot teachers union KTOS and the union of customs officers Guc-Sen left a black wreath and protested in front of the office of the prime minister of TRNC against increases in prices, particularly in electricity bills, in a time of daily depreciation of the Turkish Lira and also considering people's low wages.

On 13 July 2018, 5000 teachers from all districts in South Cyprus demonstrated in front of the Ministry of Education in Nicosia against measures by the council of ministers to streamline the education budget for state schools.

assoc_actor_1: Teachers (Cyprus); Labor Group (Cyprus); Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus)
notes: On 7 July 2018, 2018: A Turkish Cypriot teacher union demonstrated outside the Turkish Embassy in Nicosia against President Erdogan's visit on 10 July. The union said it protested the visit because the continuing state of emergency prevented democratic elections in Turkey.

On 6 July 2018, 2018: Turkish Cypriot teachers demonstrated at the opening of a Turkey-funded mosque in Nicosia under the slogan 'put schools and hospitals first'. The protesters were also worried that Ankara was increasing its dominance over the north of the divided island.

assoc_actor_1: Cyprus Green Party; EDEK: Movement for Social Democracy; Citizens Alliance; Solidarity Movement
notes: On 30 June 2018, a protest was held in Nicosia after the withdrawal of approximately over 70 million euros from the state owned Cooperative Bank in Cyprus following the Co-op sell-off to Hellenic bank and statements suggesting that if the deal did not go ahead the Co-op could be liquidated. The protest was joined by the Cyprus Green Party; EDEK, Citizens Alliance and Solidarity Movement.

assoc_actor_1: Labor Group (Cyprus); CyCPOVEK: Cyprus Confederation of Professional Craftsmen and Shopkeepers
notes: On 26 June 2018, 40 former employees of a fruit market in Larnaca rallied with members of the Cyprus Confederation of Professional Craftsmen and Shopkeepers (CyCPOVEK) in front of the Metropolitan Church that owns the land where they used to work and distributed fliers asking to go back to work. The fruit market's owner owes thousands in rent to the church, which took him to court and shut the business down.

On 25 June 2018, a Cypriot mother and her family protested again this time in front of the Supreme Court of the Republic of Cyprus to highlight the fact that after 13 years of her son's death during his military service there are no definitive findings by the police investigation into the cause of death. The family believes that he was murdered and there was a cover-up.

On 23 June 2018, an unofficial local group called 'Limassol for All' organised a demonstration outside the Limassol district administration office to protest against a 25 per cent increase in rents in the city in under two years and a housing market policy that is pricing out local residents in favour of attracting foreign capital.

assoc_actor_2: KKE: Communist Party of Greece; Labor Group (Greece)
notes: On 22 June 2018, Golden Dawn supporters working in construction near Limassol beat and threatened the life of one of their colleagues, who is a Communist Party of Greece (KKE) member, in grievances relating to their work conditions. All involved are Greek citizens.

On 21 June 2018, more than 2,000 protesters from Larnaca and Livadia gathered chanting slogans at the EKO gas station at the outskirts of Larnaca to protest for moving the oil refinery to the region of Vasiliko instead of the city's coast. The Mayors of Larnaca and Livadia were leading the protest. The protesters also blocked both lanes of the Larnaca - Dekeleia highway.

On 21 June 2018, on the same day that protesters from Larnaca and Livadia gathered to protest for moving the oil refinery to the region of Vasiliko instead of the city's coast, the residents of nine villages in the region of Vasiliko gathered for their own protest against government plans that did not include the citizens of the area. With their local authorities leading the protest they marched on the road from Vasiliko to Mari.

On 14 June 2018, a Cypriot mother and her family protested in front of the Law Office of the Republic of Cyprus to highlight the fact that after 13 years of her son's death during his military service there are no definitive findings by the police investigation into the cause of death. The mother of the soldier was holding placards with police photographs of her dead son and shouted that he was murdered and there was a cover-up.

assoc_actor_1: Protesters (Syria); Protesters (Serbia); Pancyprian Peace Council; The Left in the European Parliament - GUE/NGL; Greek Ethnic Group (Cyprus); Turkish Ethnic Group (Cyprus)
source: Xinhua; Cyprus News Agency; Cyprus Mail; Haravgi
notes: On 10 June 2018, thousands of people wearing T-shirts with peace slogans participated in the 8th Pancyprian Peace March, organized by the Pancyprian Peace Council, to the British RAF base at Akrotiri to deplore its use for military operations against countries in the region and demand the abolition of the British bases in Cyprus. The march was joined by Greek and Turkish Cypriot political parties, peace movements from Syria and Belgrade, representatives of the European Left Group in the European Parliament and of the World Peace Council.

On 8 June 2018, three Turkish Cypriot organisations, the teachers' union KTOS, journalists BASIN-SEN, and the history and culture foundation, protested outside the EU House in Nicosia for the extension of the EU's acquis communautaire to the Turkish occupied north of the island warning that Turkey was implementing policies in the north that were leading the Turkish Cypriot community to extinction through systematic settlement of Turkish people and Sunni Islamic oppression from the Turkish government rendering the around 130,000 Turkish Cypriots a minority.

assoc_actor_1: Refugees/IDPs (International); KISA: Movement for Equality, Support, Anti-Racism
notes: On 25 May 2018, on the fifth day of their thirst and hunger strike, two members of the family of stateless Kurds from Syria protesting for acquiring internationally recognised refugee status and the Cypriot citizenship were rushed to Nicosia hospital in critical condition due to dehydration and exhaustion. On the same day, the Movement for Equality, Support, Anti-Racism (KISA), organised a solidarity protest for the family of stateless Kurds from Syria.

On 24 May 2018, a solidarity protest took place in Nicosia to support the family of stateless Kurds from Syria, who are on a thirst strike for the fourth day after they were already on a hunger strike, protesting for acquiring internationally recognised refugee status and the Cypriot citizenship.

On 21 May 2018, 4 out of 8 members of a family of stateless Kurds from Syria - members of the internationally recognised as persecuted group Ajanib - begun a thirst strike after they were already on a hunger strike for a week. The family had been camping in protest for a year outside the presidential palace and the Ministry of Interior waiting for their citizenship applications to go through but despite official promises they were denied because they lack documents proving they had been residing in Cyprus for the required amount of years. This is the last in a series of protests and hunger strikes they went through since 2014.

assoc_actor_1: PEO: Pancyprian Federation of Labour; Labor Group (Cyprus)
notes: On 17 May 2018, PEO, the Pancyprian Federation of Labour, organised a march that ended at the Ministry of Labour, Welfare and Social Insurance in Nicosia, where they were received by the Minister to express their concern over the increasing number of work related accidents particularly in the sectors of the Hospitality industry, Commerce, Transportation and Storage facilities.

On 16 May 2018, members of the Cyprus Youth Symphonic Orchestra gathered in front of the Parliament for a musical protest against the board of the state symphony orchestra and with the slogan 'Hands off the Cyprus Youth Symphonic Orchestra'. The protesters believe decisions of the board during the last three years jeopardise the future of the youth orchestra. The President of the House received a delegation of students and parents and said that the matter will be discussed 'with transparency' at the House education committee.

assoc_actor_1: AKEL: Progressive Party of Working People; Protesters (Palestine)
notes: On 16 May 2018, in Nicosia, political party AKEL and many Palestinians - residents of Cyprus - marched with the slogan 'Cyprus - Palestine - Solidarity' in a peaceful protest to the Israeli embassy, where they read publicly and approved a party vote condemning the cycle of murderous violence of the state of Israel against the Palestinian people in Gaza, as well as condemning the U.S. decision to transfer their embassy in Jerusalem.

On 10 May 2018, hundreds of residents and business owners of Greece Avenue in Pafos protested against the construction of a traffic island dividing the Avenue as part of the urban planning that will regenerate the area. The protesters marched through the Avenue from north to south and blocked traffic for an hour demanding changes in the new urban plans.

On 8 May 2018, eight Greek Cypriots and one British citizen were protesting at Glossa beach in Famagusta for the return of the fenced-off ghost-town of Varosha to its lawful inhabitants, while waiting for the arrival of European Parliament lawmakers who were on a fact-finding mission regarding this issue. Turkish police interrogated the group of protesters and erased photos from the cameras and phones of all nine people before they forced them away claiming it was a military area.
On 23 April 2018, Pafos farmers protested about water shortages and expressed their concerns about the future of agriculture.
On 17 April 2018, the final march of a 3-day event organised by the Pancypriot organisation for the blind took place in Nicosia to protest the degrading living conditions of blind people In Cyprus.
On 16 April 2018, the second march of a 3-day event organised by the Pancypriot organisation for the blind took place in Limassol to protest the degrading living conditions of blind people In Cyprus.

assoc_actor_1: AKEL: Progressive Party of Working People; Arab Ethnic Group (Cyprus)
notes: On 16 April 2018, several hundred Cypriots, including a coalition of left-wing groups and the AKEL party, as well as Palestinian and Syrian protesters demonstrated in front of the U.S. Embassy in Nicosia, Cyprus to condemn the American-led airstrikes in Syria. A group calling itself the Syrian Arab Community unfurled a banner describing the airstrikes a 'reckless and irresponsible act' while a protester wrote 'Hands Off Syria' on the asphalt in green paint. A dozen riot police were present but kept a discreet distance. No violence was reported. The Cypriot government claimed it did not know a UK base on the island would be used as a launching pad for airstrikes on Syria using chemical weapons.

On 15 April 2018, Paralimni in Famagusta District was the starting point of a 3-day event of marches organized by the Pancypriot organization for the blind to protest the degrading living conditions of blind people In Cyprus.

On 6 April 2018, an unidentified group set fire to the Social Grocery shop of Lemesos on Friday evening damaging a warehouse where grocery products where collected for the relief of hundreds of families.

On Mar. 15, 2018: Protesters gathered outside the presidential palace in Nicosia to express their concern over possible decisions that favour banks over borrowers. Protesters delivered a memo to the president containing their position on foreclosures and the protection of primary residences and small businesses.

On Mar. 5, 2018: Port workers in Limassol gathered outside the port to protest over health and safety hazards in their workplace, demanding changes in procedures and an improvement of safety levels within the port.

On Mar. 4, 2018: Demonstrators, including Green Party activists, gathered in front of the sea caves in Peyia, near Pafos to protest against the construction of residences and voice their environmental concerns.
On Feb.28, 2018: Demonstrators gathered outside Pafos to protest against the construction of residences at the sea caves in Peyia, which host an endangered species.
On Feb.28, 2018: Demonstrators gathered outside the Parliament in Nicosia to protest against the construction of residences at the sea caves in Peyia, which host endangered species.

On Feb. 27, 2018: Municipal cleaners from the Nicosia districts gathered with their trucks outside the GSP stadium near the capital city to protest against outsourcing their service to private companies and called for organizing garbage collection services among local authorities.
On Feb. 26, 2018: Municipal cleaners protested in Larnaca against outsourcing their service to private companies and called for organizing garbage collection services among local authorities.
On Feb. 22, 2018: Municipal cleaners from the Pafos districts gathered at the Stelios Kyriakidis parking lot in Pafos to protest against outsourcing their service to private companies.
On Feb. 20, 2018: Parents of pupils at the Ayios Lazarus primary school in Larnaca protested against the ageing school building and demanded its demolition or renovation.

On 16 February 2018, 25 Eritrean refugees in Kofinou, Larnaca demonstrated against their living conditions, hurling stones at the police and blocking the main road of the refugee centre with chairs, desks, and rubbish bins.

Movement of forces: On 9 February 2018, Turkish warships forced the drillship of an Italian energy company to halt its course to the south east of Cyprus, off the Coast of Famagusta. The ship was on its way to perform drillings in Block 3 within the Exclusive Economic Zone (EEZ) of the Republic of Cyprus. The Turkish warships continued to prevent the Italian rig from approaching for 2 weeks, citing naval exercises in the area. The Turkish government claimed that a large part of Cyprus's EEZ is part of its continental shelf and warned Nicosia not to take unilateral actions in the area. On 13 February, the Italian government sent a frigate of the Italian Navy, which was already participating in NATO's Sea Guardian maritime operation, to approach the EEZ of Cyprus. Nicosia issued a Navtex for an exercise on 14 February with live ammunition. On 23 February, 4 or 5 Turkish warships threatened to sink the Italian ship, which was forced to make the necessary maneuvers so as to avoid a collision, and subsequently left the spot setting a course for Morocco.

On 26 January 2018, several thousand Turkish Cypriots representing about 20 left-wing groups marched in Nicosia against 'fascist' and 'extremist' segments of society and 'Turkey's unwanted influence that has emboldened hard-right groups to try and silence opposing views'. The march came in response to an attack on the offices of left-wing paper Afrika four days earlier by supporters of Turkey's president over its criticism of Ankara's military offensive against a Kurdish enclave in northern Syria. No violence was reported.

On 25 January 2018, some 100 Syrian Kurds protested against the Afrin operation outside the US and Russian Consulates in Egkomi part of the capital Nicosia of Cyprus. The rally asked for the Turkish army to retreat and end the operation. No violence was reported.

On 22 January 2018, about 200 to 500 Turkish Cypriot rioters attacked the daily Afrika newspaper offices in Nicosia (a centre-left daily critical of Turkey's presence in Cyprus and supportive of unified EU accession) after Turkish President Erdogan called upon 'his northern Cypriot brothers' to respond to a story critical of Turkish operations in the country. Rioters brought down the nameboard of the newspaper, put up a Turkish flag, threw stones through the windows and caused 'serious material damage'. According to reports, the police did not intervene. No casualties were reported.

On 22 January 2018, following an attack by rioters on the Afrika newspaper on the same day, demonstrators gathered outside the Republican Assembly in Nicosia chanted slogans and made insults against CTP deputy Dogus Derya. Two of the demonstrators climbed to the roof of parliament and hung a Turkish flag on it. The demonstrators carried many Turkish flags, posters of Turkish President Erdogan and placards. A brawl took place between the police and the demonstrators when they tried to enter parliament. The demonstration ended after the political party leaders got out of the parliament and tried to calm them down. No casualties were reported.
On Jan. 21, 2018: Citizens of Pafos protested and requested the removal of the iron structures protecting the ancient tombs that came to light recently in the historical city centre.
